title: China gives grant to Liberia Inactive
description: China lends Mozambique another R418.6-m103 words4 March 2009FT NowFTNOWEnglish(c) 2009 Now Media (Pty) Ltd. All Rights Reserved.   The Mozambiquan and Chinese governments signed three agreements in Maputo, under which China is to provide a total of R418.6-million in loan and grant finance. News agency AIM reports that the largest sum is a loan of R224.2-m for the fourth funding phase in the construction of Mozambique's new national sports stadium. A second loan, for R183.6-m, is to support agricultural projects in the Zambezi Valley, while the third agreement is for a grant of R30.6-m to be used in basic development sectors yet to be identified.

title: Chinese company interested in Ugandan refinery (Not a project)
description: Uganda to woo China money for energy, infrastructure533 words4 November 200908:19 AMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2009 Reuters Limited* Wants investment in nuclear energy, high-speed rail* Chinese investors already interested in refineryBy Elias BiryabaremaKAMPALA, Nov 4 (Reuters) - Uganda intends to woo Chinese investment to boost the country's efforts in adding value to exports and to tackle energy and infrastructure handicaps, government officials said.China's commercial footprint has been expanding in Uganda over the last five years. It was the third biggest FDI source in the third quarter of 2009 after India and Britain, according to the Uganda Investment Authority (UIA).'Our prime economic interest in China is if they can invest in our processing industry, infrastructure and energy, including nuclear energy, as the president has emphasized in the past. That would be a good partnership,' President Yoweri Museveni's spokesperson, Tamale Mirundi, told Reuters.He said Museveni plans to attend a China-Africa Summit in Egypt later this month. Trade between the continent and China has grown at 30 percent a year, climbing to $107 billion in 2008 to eclipse the United States for the first time.Museveni has previously named modern, high-speed railways and a refinery for Uganda's newly-found petroleum deposits as some of the immediate projects the Chinese can invest in.Landlocked Uganda still depends for a great deal of its external trade on the derelict and inefficient Uganda-Kenya rail line to get its exports to sea, blunting the goods' competitiveness and stifling economic growth.The volume of trade between Uganda and China remains relatively small and heavily imbalanced in favour of China.Uganda imported goods worth $274.2 million from China in 2007 compared with 138.2 million in 2006, according to a Uganda Bureau of Statistics report that did not give export figures.REFINERY FOR UGANDAN OILA delegation from the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China -- which holds a 20 percent stake in Standard Bank, Africa's biggest bank by assets, -- met Museveni in June and said it was interested in a partnership for the refinery.Uganda is locked in a dispute with the exploration companies Tullow Oil, Heritage Oil and Gas of Canada over whether the country should refine its petroleum, an option the government prefers, or export crude.The east African country has estimated reserves of 2 billion barrels and levels are forecast to grow substantially over the next few years.'The exploration companies don't want us to refine our oil but we're saying no. The president thinks the Chinese can come in with their vast expertise to help us acquire refining capacity,' Tamale said.Uganda mainly exports cotton, leather, coffee, fish, and minerals to China and buys textiles and garments, footwear, porcelain, enamel, mechanical and electrical goods.Keith Muhakanizi, a top Treasury official, told Reuters that Uganda was targeting China's huge investment funds.China has 'enormous investment funds capable of undertaking huge infrastructure projects in energy and infrastructure and these are the areas where we're focusing our efforts,' he said. (Editing by Helen Nyambura-Mwaura; Editing by Ron Askew)UGANDA-CHINA/|LANGEN|ABN|M|D|Z|O|OIL|ELE|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|ABX|DNP|PEN|SXNADocument LBA0000020091104e5b40017q
donor_agency_count: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-Owned Company

title: Chinese-constructed hospital and malaria centre (Duplicate)
description: China Donates Sh1 Billion Malaria Drugsby Josephine Maseruka295 words10 October 201009:38 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2010 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedKampala, Oct 10, 2010 (New Vision/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Chinese government has donated anti-malaria drugs worth sh1.25b to Uganda. The drugs were officially handed over to health state minister Dr. Richard Nduhura on Friday.This is the fourth donation of anti-malarial drugs from the Chinese government at the request of Uganda in an attempt to cut down on the estimated 320 daily deaths caused by malaria.According to the Uganda Bureau of Statistics, between 70,000 and 110,000 annual child deaths are due to malaria.Handing over the consignment, the Chinese ambassador to Uganda, Sun Heping, said medical care and health were a priority in the China-Africa cooperation.'African people have long been plagued by malaria. To help them improve health care and enhance the capacity to prevent malaria, treat it and deliver better health services to the people, China has intensified its efforts to cooperate with African countries in the field of health over the past three years,' Heping said.He also commended the good relations between Uganda and China. China is constructing a hospital and malaria research centre in Naguru, a Kampala suburb.'We will also continue to provide Uganda with medical equipment and anti-malarial resources to improve the capacity for diagnosis and treatment, and to ensure that China aid projects are sustained to better serve Ugandans.'Nduhura thanked the Chinese government for continued support to Uganda in many fields, including the construction of the Naguru hospital.Malaria accounts for 40% of Uganda's public health expenditure.The Government is distributing free treated mosquito nets to households and introduced free anti-malarial drugs to its health centres across the country to contain the disease.Document AFNWS00020101011e6ab0007n

title: US$4m grant to Zambia (duplicate)
description: Chinese Firms Keen to Invest in Zambia589 words13 November 200303:03 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2003 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedNo13, 2003 (The Times of Zambia/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --MORE than 70 Chinese companies in textile manufacturing, construction, telecommunications and agricultural businesses are interested in exploring investment opportunities in Zambia.President Mwanawasa disclosed this yesterday at the Lusaka International Airport on arrival from a six-day State visit to that country.He said he was pleased that next month Zambia would be accorded the status of 'final destination' for Chinese tourists in order to boost the tourism industry.He described his visit to China as fruitful and a further demonstration of good and strong bilateral relations that existed between the two countries.President Mwanawasa, who was accompanied by First Lady Maureen, was welcomed on arrival by Vice-President Nevers Mumba, several Cabinet ministers, their deputies, defence chiefs and several party members.He said his visit to China coincided with an investment promotion mission from Zambia, and he was also privileged to officiate at the first Zambia-China investment seminar which was attended by more than 70 Chinese companies.'All these are keen to establish themselves in Zambia through direct investment or through joint ventures with Zambian companies,' the President said.The two governments have also signed a US$ 6 million grant, some of it in cash form, and the rest to be used for projects mutually agreed upon.Giving a breakdown of the grant, Mr Mwanawasa said US$ 2 million would be in cash form and US$ 4 million would go towards various projects to be initiated in the country.President Mwanawasa said the assistance had come at an opportune time and the money would be utilised effectively and efficiently as Government was in need of resources to implement the Poverty Reduction Strategic Paper (PRSP).On debt relief, the two countries had agreed on possibilities of discussing a further debt relief to Zambia.China last year cancelled a US$ 10 million debt to Zambia.'Given the huge burden the country continues to face and the difficulties we have in servicing these loans due to financial constraints, I requested my counterpart for further debt relief. Technical experts from our two countries will consult on this,' he said.President Mwanawasa said the Zambian Government had signed a letter of intent with Sinohydro Corporation, among other companies who are interested in investing in the energy sector, especially in the hydro power plant projects in Kafue Gorge Lower for 600 megawatts and in the Itezhi Tezhi for 180 megawatts.Another agreement was signed with the municipal people's government of Quindao on the establishment of the Mulungushi industrial park as a joint venture project.Quimdao Kailan group of companies also signed an agreement for the establishment of a chemical fertiliser and pesticides project at a cost of US$ 10 million with an expected production of 200,000 tonnes and 10,000 tonnes, respectively.Meanwhile, President Mwanawasa says he has not yet received a report on the revocation of title deeds from Minister of Lands Judith Kapijimpanga and Copperbelt Minister Webby Chipili by the lands tribunal.Responding to a query, Mr Mwanawasa said he was yet to be briefed on the matter before he could make a decision.The lands tribunal in its ruling on Monday revoked titles for a commercial plot jointly owned by the duo through their companies Pineland Investment and WC Engineering.The two ministers have since indicated that they would be appealing to the Supreme Court against the decision of the tribunal, which was chaired by Mr Sebastian Zulu.

title: Oil Plant contruction (Duplicate of 1996)
description: 'BEIJING, June 05, SinoCast -- Chinese oil titan China National Petroleum Corporation (PetroChina Group) plans to invest USD 5 billion in the following three years to develop Niger's Agadem oil block jointly with the Nigerian government, in line with an agreement signed on June 2, 2008, said China's Ministry of Commerce yesterday.The Agadem oil block is the largest one in the African country and is proven to have considerable oil reserve, according to the Chinese ministry. PetroChina Group will also build a plant capable of refining 1 million tons of crude oil every year and also a 2,000-kilometer pipeline in the country.Zhang Shengli, an official from the Chinese ministry, said there was not any third party in the project.PetroChina Group is expected be benefited in terms of profitability by forming a complete industry chain from exploitation to oil transportation in the project, said Guotai Junan Securities analyst Yang Wei.The Chinese oil titan has been prospecting the Blima block and the Tenere block in Niger. '

title: Dabola Groundnut Oil Factory [commitment year before 2000]
description: The ambassador of China to Guinea announced to the deputies at the end of last week that his government promised to Guinea 50 luxury cars for the 50th anniversary of independence, observed Guineenews at the National Assembly.In addition to the cars, China promised to build a 150-bed modern hospital in Conakry, specifically at Kipe. According to the ambassador, the construction works will begin this year and will be put to use in 2009. 2009.'The hospital will relieve to some extent the physical sufferings and charges of Guineans. China will construct soon three rural schools in the Conakry suburb', he added.We can cite, among the investment of China in Guinea, ENTAG [cigarette manufacturing firm], the Macenta Tea Factory [in southeastern Guinea], the Dabola Groundnut Oil Factory [in south central Guinea], Boffa Sugar and Sugar Cane Factory [in southwestern Guinea], the Kankan Brickyard [in northeastern Guinea], the Bordo (Kankan) Agriculture School, Mamou Agricultural Tool Factory [in southwestern Guinea], the Kaback Water Development Works [in southwestern Nigeria], the Boffa Water Cooperation Project [in southwestern Guinea], the Kindia Agriculture Extension Works [in southwestern Guinea], the People's Palace [in capital], the Sekhoutereya Palace [in capital] and the new RTG House [Guinean Radio-Television], which became today the symbols of Chinese-Guinean friendship.In line with the strengthening of their cooperation, China launched the construction of a 50,000-capacity stadium costing 50m dollars on 18 September 2007. According to the ambassador, the stadium will be the biggest project ever to be built by China in Guinea as a development aid since the beginning of the Chinese-Guinean relations. [Passage omitted].Source: Guineenews website in French 15 May 08a8325366The British Broadcasting CorporationDocument BBCAP00020080516e45g001gt

title: Oil Pipeline and Refinery (Duplicate of 1998)
description: 203 words3 June 200801:10 PMAgence France PresseAFPREnglishCopyright Agence France-Presse, 2008 All reproduction and presentation rights reserved.Niger has granted China's national oil company rights to prospect, explore and produce petroleum in the northern Agadez region, state radio reported Tuesday.The pact, signed Monday between the Niger government and the China National Oil and Gas Development and Exploration Corporation (CNODC), will see the company invest about 300 million dollars (194 million euros) to explore and drill 18 new wells in the coming eight years.Western companies have been prospecting for oil in Niger's Agadem region in the northern area of Agadez since 1985.They have concluded that the estimated 324 million barrels there were not lucrative enough to prospect and drill.The Chinese firm has also pledged to invest 1.2 billion dollars in Niger's petroleum sector to build a pipeline and a refinery near the second city of Zinder with a daily capacity of 20,000 barrels.It will sell a part of its production locally at 'affordable' prices, according to the contract.Since 2006, China has reinforced its economic ties with Niger helping the former French colony to tap its vast uranium wealth, one of the largest in the world.bh/jlh/ach/rtNiger-China-oilDocument AFPR000020080603e46300aj7

title: Chinese-funded hospital in Lugogo, Uganda (Duplicate)
description: China Tightening Grip On Trade With Countryby Charles Mwanguhya1235 words18 October 201105:05 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2011 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedOct 18, 2011 (The Monitor/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- At a street corner in the small town of Fort Portal, 300 kilometers west of Kampala, the old illuminated sign has been removed and a new one in English, complete with its Chinese translation, beckons brilliant against sun.Inside the Supermarket, the managers and workers do not understand each-others' language. The local workers as well as most customers neither speak English nor Chinese or Mandarin. Equally the supermarket managers hardly speak any English and know nothing of the local language, yet this store opens every morning and is apparently doing brisk business.The Mukwano Shopping Arcade, a large circular two-storey arcade opposite the main taxi park in downtown Kampala, is a beehive of activity with people of all walks of life squeezing for space. The shops here teem onto the verandas and the vendors, who started on the verandas, are pushing more into the road already crammed by the 14-seater minibus taxis that is the common transport in Kampala.The traders that mix here are a medley of all nationalities from Congolese traders to South Sudanese and Kenyans. But recently traders say they have noticed a new competition, not just increasing volumes of cheap Chinese-made products but of Chinese traders dealing exclusively in 'Made in China' products. At night when the crowds reduce, Chinese families that have set camp on the two top floors are a common site, staring down at the large open yard that turns into bars.This same situation can be said of many towns in Uganda as is the case of Fort Portal - the penetration of China seeking new markets and opportunities for its billion plus population has spread wide and deep across the African continent.At this year's Uganda Manufacturers Association (UMA) Trade Fair at the Lugogo Show Grounds, some 70 odd Chinese companies exhibited. Industrial players said these largely constituted 'new opportunity' seekers and less of already established businesses.'Chinese are investing both downtown and uptown; they are everywhere,' says Mr Awel Uwihanganye, the chief executive officer of the Uganda National Chamber of Commerce and Industry.Mr Uwihanganye says he is amazed that in the few months he has been at the chamber, he has experienced a sheer volume of Chinese delegations, traders, and officials seeking opportunities in the country.'It is true China is engaging with Africa heavily,' he says.Mr Dennis Kawuma, the Business Editor at the Independent newspaper, the Daily Monitor, which is part of the Nation Media Group says; ' if you were to use South Africa-the biggest economy in Africa- as a bellwether, it is obvious that Chinese influence is growing on the continent. Today, China is South Africa's largest trading partner.'In Kampala, Fang Fang Restaurant was the flagship enterprise opened in the upscale Nakasero suburb by an enterprising woman, Fang Min, more than 15 years ago for Kampala's choosy A' Class clientele.Today another branch has opened but more importantly is 'Chinese Restaurants' are becoming a common site with new ones of various grades to cater for various clienteles are opening almost all over town.Just like the open market where China is chasing customers like any other trader to efforts to woe government monies, China's aggressiveness is the same. Large Chinese construction companies are in the countryside opening new highways at multi-billion dollar contracts. The Chinese construction firm, SBI rebuilt a 75-kilometer stretch of tarmac road from Fort Portal to Kasese Town just after they had completed a longer, over 100 kilometer Mbarara--Kasese Road through Bushenyi District.The construction firm is now working bitumen on a $152 million Kabale--Kisoro road project near the Rwandan and Congolese borders.Mr Kevin Chen, the CEO of a $15m digital TV investment project, Star Times, says China's aggressive drive into Africa is driven by largely two factors; the money for capital investment and the technological knowhow.'The driving force now is capital; we have the money, enough capital and because of this we have to look for investment opportunities to make more money,' says Mr Chen, adding rather brusquely; 'China is opening up and expanding. When you open up you have advantages, for a long time we were closed but now we are opening.'Because of the sudden turn-around, Chinese investors are not blind to the challenges of infrastructural inadequacies in Africa, as Mr Chen says the potholes might be a menace but not as bad and, therefore, tolerable. He, however, notes that intermittent power supplies and a high cost of fuel to run diesel engines coupled with erratic mobile telephone networks still present major obstacles.Does China care about political stability? Mr Chen says it does, especially for its investment projects.'(Political) stability is important, now it is difficult for Chinese investors to go into a country such as Libya. Uganda is much more stable.'Investment is not like trading, Chen says, but the Chinese are doing both here and elsewhere. The numbers have grown so big in a very short period of time that recently, a Chinese event was held at the five-star Kampala Serena Hotel.Pioneer Chinese investor Fang Min, who arguably opened the door for Chinese investment and trade in Uganda, is seen here as an iconic figure. Her country even honoured her on its postage stamps.When Chen begins to reel off Chinese businesses in Uganda at the snap off the finger--his countrymen are into steel rolling and are exploring investing in mineral exploration and expanding into the hospitality industry more aggressively than the cautious Fang Min.Mr Uwihanganye says China is pushing in all directions and, in his view, appeasing African governments with not only cheap credit but large construction projects.Evidence abounds to vindicate this view. The Ugandan Ministry of Foreign Affairs is housed in a gleaming six-storey block donated and constructed by China.Two new towers that will house the President's Office are nearing completion on a plot between the Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA) and Parliament and overlook the ministries of finance and foreign affairs. The two towers dwarf all the other buildings.In nearby Lugogo, a new hospital is nearing completion to ease the pressure on the country's only national referral hospital, Mulago.Mr Uwihanganye says government seems to have been blinded by apparent extreme Chinese generosity to put any checks. There are hardly any local partnerships between the Chinese investors and local people; they are taking all.'They are finding a culture which is too liberal, which does not require them to partner,' he says, noting that Africa has not learnt from the experiences of exploitation first by colonial invaders and later by Indian and Asian business people who invest and repatriate all their profit while keeping closed communities of their kith and kin without integrating into the local communities.But China has been willing to engage, to negotiate without putting conditions like their western rivals who put human rights and governance as key to their aid or pre-conditions they wave at their companies seeking opportunities in Africa. China is also not know for issuing sometimes distabilising advisories to its citizens venturing into Africa, a position many African leaders fancy as they battle to re-assert their authority in the post-independence era.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020111018e7ai000g3

title: Chinese constructing hospital in Uganda (Duplicate)
description: China Tightening Grip On Trade With Countryby Charles Mwanguhya1235 words18 October 201105:05 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2011 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedOct 18, 2011 (The Monitor/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- At a street corner in the small town of Fort Portal, 300 kilometers west of Kampala, the old illuminated sign has been removed and a new one in English, complete with its Chinese translation, beckons brilliant against sun.Inside the Supermarket, the managers and workers do not understand each-others' language. The local workers as well as most customers neither speak English nor Chinese or Mandarin. Equally the supermarket managers hardly speak any English and know nothing of the local language, yet this store opens every morning and is apparently doing brisk business.The Mukwano Shopping Arcade, a large circular two-storey arcade opposite the main taxi park in downtown Kampala, is a beehive of activity with people of all walks of life squeezing for space. The shops here teem onto the verandas and the vendors, who started on the verandas, are pushing more into the road already crammed by the 14-seater minibus taxis that is the common transport in Kampala.The traders that mix here are a medley of all nationalities from Congolese traders to South Sudanese and Kenyans. But recently traders say they have noticed a new competition, not just increasing volumes of cheap Chinese-made products but of Chinese traders dealing exclusively in 'Made in China' products. At night when the crowds reduce, Chinese families that have set camp on the two top floors are a common site, staring down at the large open yard that turns into bars.This same situation can be said of many towns in Uganda as is the case of Fort Portal - the penetration of China seeking new markets and opportunities for its billion plus population has spread wide and deep across the African continent.At this year's Uganda Manufacturers Association (UMA) Trade Fair at the Lugogo Show Grounds, some 70 odd Chinese companies exhibited. Industrial players said these largely constituted 'new opportunity' seekers and less of already established businesses.'Chinese are investing both downtown and uptown; they are everywhere,' says Mr Awel Uwihanganye, the chief executive officer of the Uganda National Chamber of Commerce and Industry.Mr Uwihanganye says he is amazed that in the few months he has been at the chamber, he has experienced a sheer volume of Chinese delegations, traders, and officials seeking opportunities in the country.'It is true China is engaging with Africa heavily,' he says.Mr Dennis Kawuma, the Business Editor at the Independent newspaper, the Daily Monitor, which is part of the Nation Media Group says; ' if you were to use South Africa-the biggest economy in Africa- as a bellwether, it is obvious that Chinese influence is growing on the continent. Today, China is South Africa's largest trading partner.'In Kampala, Fang Fang Restaurant was the flagship enterprise opened in the upscale Nakasero suburb by an enterprising woman, Fang Min, more than 15 years ago for Kampala's choosy A' Class clientele.Today another branch has opened but more importantly is 'Chinese Restaurants' are becoming a common site with new ones of various grades to cater for various clienteles are opening almost all over town.Just like the open market where China is chasing customers like any other trader to efforts to woe government monies, China's aggressiveness is the same. Large Chinese construction companies are in the countryside opening new highways at multi-billion dollar contracts. The Chinese construction firm, SBI rebuilt a 75-kilometer stretch of tarmac road from Fort Portal to Kasese Town just after they had completed a longer, over 100 kilometer Mbarara--Kasese Road through Bushenyi District.The construction firm is now working bitumen on a $152 million Kabale--Kisoro road project near the Rwandan and Congolese borders.Mr Kevin Chen, the CEO of a $15m digital TV investment project, Star Times, says China's aggressive drive into Africa is driven by largely two factors; the money for capital investment and the technological knowhow.'The driving force now is capital; we have the money, enough capital and because of this we have to look for investment opportunities to make more money,' says Mr Chen, adding rather brusquely; 'China is opening up and expanding. When you open up you have advantages, for a long time we were closed but now we are opening.'Because of the sudden turn-around, Chinese investors are not blind to the challenges of infrastructural inadequacies in Africa, as Mr Chen says the potholes might be a menace but not as bad and, therefore, tolerable. He, however, notes that intermittent power supplies and a high cost of fuel to run diesel engines coupled with erratic mobile telephone networks still present major obstacles.Does China care about political stability? Mr Chen says it does, especially for its investment projects.'(Political) stability is important, now it is difficult for Chinese investors to go into a country such as Libya. Uganda is much more stable.'Investment is not like trading, Chen says, but the Chinese are doing both here and elsewhere. The numbers have grown so big in a very short period of time that recently, a Chinese event was held at the five-star Kampala Serena Hotel.Pioneer Chinese investor Fang Min, who arguably opened the door for Chinese investment and trade in Uganda, is seen here as an iconic figure. Her country even honoured her on its postage stamps.When Chen begins to reel off Chinese businesses in Uganda at the snap off the finger--his countrymen are into steel rolling and are exploring investing in mineral exploration and expanding into the hospitality industry more aggressively than the cautious Fang Min.Mr Uwihanganye says China is pushing in all directions and, in his view, appeasing African governments with not only cheap credit but large construction projects.Evidence abounds to vindicate this view. The Ugandan Ministry of Foreign Affairs is housed in a gleaming six-storey block donated and constructed by China.Two new towers that will house the President's Office are nearing completion on a plot between the Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA) and Parliament and overlook the ministries of finance and foreign affairs. The two towers dwarf all the other buildings.In nearby Lugogo, a new hospital is nearing completion to ease the pressure on the country's only national referral hospital, Mulago.Mr Uwihanganye says government seems to have been blinded by apparent extreme Chinese generosity to put any checks. title: Investec Group wins Chinese Contract
description: 171 words26 June 2000African Mining MonitorAFMMEnglishCopyright 2000 M2 Communications, Ltd. All Rights Reserved.Investec Group, a South African bank, has won a contract to supply the Peoples Bank of China - China's central bank - with about a ton of gold from the Rand Refinery every three weeks.Under the agreement Investec will airfreight the gold from South Africa to Shenzen, China from where the Peoples Bank, which controls all gold buying and allocation in China, will supply the gold to customers such as jewellery manufacturers. Investec will not be paid until the manufacturer has sold his products.The agreement is for an unlimited period of time. The amount of gold shipped can be negotiated upwards.(Business Day, 16 Jun 2000; Platt`s Commodity News, 15 Jun 2000). African Mining Monitor includes paraphrased and abstracted material with the source, which is deemed to be reliable and duly identified. AMM is unable to provide full-text copies of these original documents.((Comments on this story may be sent to info@m2.com))Document afmm000020010802dw6q0008q

title: Semi-Arid Maize Cultivation Training, Pilot Project
description: In Lanzhou, Xinhua, May 28 (Reporter Zhang Wenjing) an exploration and practice pioneered by Gansu, dry farming techniques can increase grain output is currently Kenya trials, demonstration, and will gradually be extended.    Local reporters learned from Lanzhou University of Arid and Grassland Ecology, Ministry of Education Key Laboratory, the laboratory has repeatedly led his team, Professor Fengmin Bear Youcai to fieldwork in Kenya, and Kenya, University of Nairobi, Kenya National Agricultural Research Institute research institutes, academic exchanges and communication with local agricultural officers and farmers, promotion of the Gansu dry farming techniques to Kenya.    Kenya and other African countries, food production is less able to cope with drought. In 2011, Kenya suffered a severe drought in 60 years, farming and animal husbandry has suffered a huge loss. Gansu for the actual situation of the drought and water shortage in recent years, and vigorously promote corn whole film double furrow sowing dry farming techniques, development of rainfed agriculture, its grain production increased from 161.6 billion kilograms in 2006 to 202 in 2011. 9 billion pounds.    The Bear Youcai, Gansu and Kenya there are some similarities, belonging to the arid climate of the semi-arid climate resource conditions, natural and geographical conditions, but the drought situation is slightly different, with four distinct seasons, Gansu Kenya Four Seasons Fuzzifying the. In addition, the different nature of the two soil Gansu belongs to the alkaline soil, Kenya, compared with acidic soil. 'To this end, we have carried out the localization of improvement and innovation to make it adapt to the natural and geographical conditions of the African native.'    According to reports, Lanzhou University researchers in Kenya to establish a test base of over 4000 square meters, more than 100 ha Experiment Station, the use of the whole film double furrow sowing technology and Straw covering technology dryland corn and wheat, to carry out rainwater harvesting technology development and demonstration, and actively training local agricultural officers and farmers to encourage them to conduct technical trials in their own farmland.    Bear Friends said before, the two sides will also to yield key technology promotion and demonstration, as well as the training of local technicians cooperation in the efficient low dryland agriculture water-saving technology research and development, promotion and demonstration, high yield and drought-resistant corn, wheat. The project after the implementation of the promotion in Kenya, Ethiopia, Zambia and other African countries will also step-by-step promotion.

title: Chinese-Zimbabwean exchange for arms

title: Apple and pear sanitation agreement
description: In 2007, China and South Africa signed an agreement to set sanitation guidelines for the export of apples and pears to China. The agreement was meant to facilitate trade.

title: China, SA to boost economic/trade cooperation
description: 647 words7 February 2007Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2007 Xinhua News AgencyPRETORIA, Feb. 6 (Xinhua) -- China and South African agreed on Tuesday to view and develop bilateral ties from a strategic perspective and push forward their strategic partnership based on equality, mutual benefit and common development.Visiting Chinese President Hu Jintao and his South African counterpart Thabo Mbeki held talks here on Tuesday afternoon, at which they reached broad consensus on future development of bilateral relations.Hu said China firmly stood alongside the South African people during their struggle against apartheid and that the Chinese-South African ties have enjoyed fast, multi-facet and all-round growth since the two countries established diplomatic ties 10 years ago.The two countries have had fruitful bilateral cooperation in economy and trade, science and technology, education, culture, tourism and justice, he noted.Hu expressed China's appreciation for South Africa's adherence to the one China policy and its support for China's reunification cause.During the talks, Hu put forward a five-point proposal for further promoting China-South Africa ties, including ways of boosting political mutual trust, deepening economic and trade cooperation, expanding the scope of bilateral cooperation, increasing people-to-people contacts and intensifying multilateral cooperation.To build up political mutual trust, Hu suggested that the leaders of the two countries keep frequent contacts and have in-depth exchanges of views on major bilateral and global issues through both bilateral and multilateral channels.On economic and trade cooperation, Hu suggested that both sides optimize trade structures and create an environment conducive to the healthy growth in bilateral trade.He also proposed to explore ways to expand cooperation in vocational training, Chinese language teaching, infrastructure, mining, energy, information technology and crackdown on crimes.To boost people-to-people contacts, Hu announced that the Chinese government will invite 500 young people from South Africa and other African nations to visit China in the next three years.On international issues, Hu proposed that both countries enhance multilateral cooperation and safeguard common interests and said bilateral cooperation should also be enhanced within the framework of the United Nations and other multilateral organizations.Expressing his appreciation for the endeavors made by South Africa to resolve internal conflicts in Africa, Hu said China will continue to support and participate in peacekeeping operations in the region.For his part, Mbeki said South Africa and China have established a solid friendly and cooperative relationship and both countries share the resolve to enhance their bilateral strategic partnership.Through concerted efforts of both sides, the South African-Chinese relationship will be further consolidated and developed, Mbeki noted, adding that he fully agreed with Hu's proposals to advance the strategic partnership between the two countries.Economically, China is one of South Africa's most important partners; politically, the consultation and cooperation with China is an asset to South Africa in meeting various challenges, he stressed.China's attention to and cooperation with Africa is of great significance for the rejuvenation of the African continent, he said.Mbeki hoped that both sides will deepen cooperation in the areas of trade, investment, technology, agriculture and natural resources, and increase people-to-people contacts.He applauded China's determination and actions to implement measures adopted at the Beijing Summit of the Forum of China-Africa Cooperation last November, saying the African people have been encouraged by China's follow-up moves.After the talks, Hu and Mbeki witnessed the signing of five documents on bilateral cooperation in economy and technology, plant quarantine and other fields.Hu arrived in Pretoria earlier Tuesday from the Namibian capital of Windhoek for a three-day state visit to South Africa.South Africa is the sixth leg of Hu's current eight-nation African tour that has already taken him to Cameroon, Liberia, Sudan, Zambia and Namibia. Hu will also travel to Mozambique and Seychelles.

Are: an interest-free loan of 30 million yuan (equivalent to 40.2 million dirhams) economic and technical cooperation agreements, to cancel double taxation agreements and urbanizationLiving Agreement; There are two exchange of letters: one on the use of the 5 million yuan (equivalent to 6.7 million dirhams) grants funded GOULININ-SMARA chemical mapping project, one is shutIn donated materials worth 800,000 yuan (equivalent to 1,072,000 dirhams).General Agreement of October 2002, the Moroccan government and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a 50 million yuan (equivalent to 64 million dirhams) concessional loans. The loan is that China invested 130 million yuan (equivalent to 167 million dirhams) in Ifrane, sand mild Hou Jockey part of the construction of three small dams.There are also plans in 2005 completed a $ 5 million yuan three geochemical mapping project and the value of 165 million yuan medical clinic project, this one of the 80 million interest-free loan models.Finally, in the field of energy, the China National Offshore Oil Corporation and the Moroccan National Oil and Gas Mining Authority signed a joint license offshore exploitation of oil in the north of Agadir RASTAFEINEY region, Chinese oil companies for the first time into the Moroccan oil and gas exploration market.

title: Stake in Lender (duplicate of 16439)
description: 329 words7 January 200801:37 PMAssociated Press NewswiresAPRSEnglish(c) 2008. The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (AP) - Chinese foreign minister Yang Jiechi began a two-day visit to South Africa Monday, marking 10 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries.Yang paid a brief courtesy visit to President Thabo Mbeki before meeting with foreign affairs minister Nkosazana Dlamini Zuma in Pretoria. It was the start of a tour of Africa, where China foreign ministry officials have traditionally started the year in a sign of the importance they place on the resource-rich continent.Yang was also to visit Congo, Burundi and Ethiopia.Yang said the China-South Africa relationship is 'of great importance,' the South African Press Association reported.Since South Africa, the continent's economic powerhouse, dropped Taipei for Beijing 10 years ago, China has become the country's largest trading partner.Trade between South Africa, the continent's economic powerhouse and a major gold-producing country, and China reached US$240 million in the first 11 months of 2006, an increase of 34.5 percent from the previous year.Last year China's biggest bank, the state-owned Industrial   Commercial Bank of China Ltd. bought a 20 percent stake in South Africa's biggest lender, Standard Bank Group Ltd. in one of China's biggest foreign corporate acquisitions to date.Chinese investments into South Africa amount to US$130 million, mostly in a chromium mine while South African investments in China stand at about US$400 million including investments by Anglo American, SAB Miller and a US$120 million investment by a property group.Yang's visit comes a year after Chinese President Hu Jintao visited South Africa in early 2007.South Africa and China on Monday established a diplomatic mechanism to enhance political, economic and trade relations.Yang and Dlamini Zuma were also expected to discuss co-operation between the two countries in international affairs as well as Chinese support for peacekeeping operations in Africa.7Document APRS000020080107e41700378

title: Pledge to strengthen military ties
description: China, South Africa pledge to strengthen military ties208 words29 August 2006Hindustan TimesHNTMEnglish(c) 2006 The Hindustan Times LtdIndo-Asian News Service Beijing, Aug 29 -- The Chinese armed forces will make joint efforts with the South African military to push forward bilateral friendly cooperation, said a senior Chinese officer Tuesday.Liang Guanglie, chief of the general staff of the Chinese People's Liberation Army, made the remarks after meeting with visiting Chief of the New South African National Defence Force G.N. Ngwenya.Ngwenya is on a six-day official goodwill visit to China from Aug 27.The two armed forces have kept high-level exchanges of visits and friendly cooperation in recent years, he said.Liang said the two countries have shared a deepening political trust since the establishment of diplomatic ties eight years back. The two sides have also made substantial progress in the fields of trade, technology, education and culture.Ngwenya said the South African armed forces are willing to continue to enhance cooperation with the Chinese side in various fields including personnel exchanges.'Strengthening the bilateral friendly and cooperative relations between the two countries and the two armed forces is in the interest of the two countries,' he said.Published by HT Syndication with permission from Indo-Asian News Service.HTS ir 060829-319033Document HNTM000020060829e28t000uo© 2012 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.

title: (Pre-2000) President Mugabe Inaugurates Sino-Zimbabwe Cement Plant
description: HARARE, October 26 (Xinhua) - Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe on Friday officially inaugurated the Sino-Zimbabwe Cement plant in Gweru, about 300 kilometers south of Harare.Speaking at the opening ceremony, Mugabe disclosed that at present, the plant has a production capacity of 700 tons of cement per day and it is expected to achieve full capacity by January 2002 when it will produce 900 tons per day.He also said that the project has created employment for 215 permanent and 109 contract workers.Under a joint venture agreement between Zimbabwe's Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) and the China Building Material Industrial Corporation for Foreign Economic-Technical Corporation (CBMIC) in June 1994, the cement plant was completed in September 2000 with a total cost of 51 million U.S. dollars.Among those present at the opening ceremony were Zimbabwean Minister of Industry and International Trade Herbert Murerwa, Minister of Finance and Economic Development Simba Makoni and ChineseAmbassador to Zimbabwe Hou Quingru.Document xnews00020011026dxaq004u2---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Construction - Zimbabwean cement industry in crisis533 words16 February 2003Economist Intelligence Unit - Business AfricaEIUBFBusiness AfricaNumber: 304English(C) 2003 The Economist Intelligence Unit Ltd.Zimbabwe's cement industry is on the verge of closure because of inadequate coal supplies. United Portland Cement (Unicem) stopped production at its Colleen Bawn plant in mid-February while Circle Cement, a subsidiary of France's Lafarge group, suspended sales and deliveries early in the month because it had no stocks. The firm comments that rail- delivered coal supplies have been 'erratic and inadequate' since mid-2001. While a number of alternatives have been investigated, including the use of road transport, the cost is 'totally prohibitive,' especially when the government has imposed controls on the sale price of cement.Unicem, a subsidiary of South Africa-based Pretoria Portland Cement, says Wankie Colliery has been unable to supply coal because of production and loading problems at the colliery as well as an inadequate supply of rail wagons. Unicem adds that the supply of fuel from local sources has 'virtually stopped,' forcing the firm to import its own diesel fuel.It adds that since price controls were imposed on cement in August 2001 it has been allowed only one price increase -- of 50% -- while input costs have escalated by 500%. 'At current controlled prices the industry is no longer viable,' it says.Between them Circle and Unicem account for some 90% Zimbabwe's cement production, some of which is exported, mostly to neighbouring Zambia. Such sales have proved controversial, since the state media claims that Circle Cement continues to export to Malawi, and that domestic cement deliveries have been suspended because of price controls rather than the coal shortage. Circle denies this, however, and points out that the country's newest and smallest supplier, Sino-Zimbabwe Cement -- a joint venture between a Chinese group and Zimbabwe's state-owned Industrial Development Corporation -- has also suspended production.No funds for maintenanceLast month the country's sole coal producer, Wankie Colliery, said it was operating at 50% of capacity. It has not been able to source adequate foreign currency to repair and maintain the dragline at its open-cast mine, which produces 85-90% of its coal. 'More than half of major mining equipment is on breakdown' according to Wankie. As a result, the firm's ability to supply coal to the country's Hwange Thermal Power Station has been 'severely compromised'. Coal deliveries are also constrained by the inadequate supply of railway wagons from the state-owned National Railways of Zimbabwe, which is providing only 55% the agreed 150 wagons per day. Wankie is using road transport to send out some 45% of its deliveries, but this is very costly and suitable only for smaller products.The cement shutdown is likely to hit the construction sector, while it is only a matter of time before the coal shortage gives rise to load-shedding by the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA); this will have knock- on effects across industry and mining. ZESA has warned industry that power shedding will become necessary from April onwards. Other construction- related businesses are being affected. Turnall Fibre Cement, which makes asbestos sheeting, says it is now sourcing some of its products from South Africa.

title: Powerstar Motors Joint-Venture
description: In October 2010, Powerstar was restructered into a joint venture between South African and Chinese principals. Powerstar has the support of both the China Development Bank Corporation and the China Africa Development Fund, both of which pledged financial backing. Powerstar has sold 1500 units to South African operators. The deal involves China North Vehicle Corporation, known also as Norinco Motors, which has a 78.3% equity in the new company.

title: Duplicate: Energy and Minerals Deal
description: CAPE TOWN, Nov 17 (Reuters) - Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping signed an energy deal with resource-rich South Africa on Wednesday in a visit aimed at obtaining minerals the Asian giant needs to fuel its blistering growth.China is South Africa's biggest bilateral trading partner and the focal point of its plan to divert more trade and investment from traditional markets in Europe and North America to the world's fastest growing economies.Xi, touted as China's next president, on Tuesday began a three-day visit to Africa's largest economy, which is seeking to reduce a deficit in trade with China that hit $2.7 billion last year, skewed in Beijing's favour.South African Deputy President Kgalema Motlanthe and Xi co-chaired the 4th China-South Africa bilateral commission and signed a number of agreements, including an energy deal.No monetary details were released.'The Chinese government undertook to encourage more imports from South Africa, especially value added products and will urge Chinese companies to invest in infrastructure development, automotive manufacturing, energy and information and communication technology,' Motlanthe said in a statement.South Africa has also signed a deal with China's Yingli Solar to build a $435 million manufacturing plant with a local partner, a senior government official said.Yingli will partner with a local company and aimed to start building the plant within 12 months.South African exports about $5.5 billion a year in minerals to the state and has been increasingly a destination of Chinese foreign direct investment.BRICSA?Beijing sees South Africa, a global mining power and regional financial services leader, as a vital source of commodities and a stepping stone to access other African states.Motlanthe said the help of countries including China is vital for South Africa's new economic growth path, which aims to create millions of jobs, mainly in the private sector.For South Africa, China also serves as a model of state action in the economy, with Pretoria hoping to join it in the BRIC -- Brazil, Russia, India and China -- group of fast emerging economies.But a 'BRICSA' grouping seems unlikely for now with South African growth projected at 3 percent this year, hardly the blistering pace of the other members. Its economy is also less than a quarter of the size of the smallest BRIC economy.South Africa's ruling African National Congress has rolled out plans to tackle a massive unemployment problem, with many ANC officials seeing the success of the BRICs as evidence that the state should intervene more.But experts said the ANC, in a governing alliance with organised labour, is loath to loosen a rigid labour market to make it easier for its companies to hire and fire staff with the ease of Chinese firms.'There are things to be learned but that can only come if one is willing to listen. Around labour policy, there is no translatability of a China or U.S. approach to labour and labour flexibility,' said Martyn Davies, CEO of Frontier Advisory and an expert on Africa-China relations. (Additional reporting by Jon Herskovitz; Editing by Mark Heinrich) (For a graphic on South Africa-China trade, see http://r.reuters.com/qew65q [http://r.reuters.com/qew65q])SAFRICA-CHINA/ (UPDATE 2, PIX, TV, GRAPHICS)|LANGEN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|RNA|ABX|BNX|FUN|SXNADocument LBA0000020101117e6bh000nt

title: Nuclear Cooperation
description: **On April 27, 2012, China Daily ran an article stating that South Africa was inviting tenders to build six nuclear plants for which the total cost would equal roughly $38 billion U.S. dollars. We have not yet found evidence that China's has been awarded a contract or has committed financial resources to this.**On August 24, 2010, Standard Bank Group signed an memorandum of understanding with Industrial   Commercial Bank of China Ltd. to promote nuclear cooperation. The two banks have led engagements by China Guangdong Nuclear Power Co. with the Chinese and South African governments. A R1 trillion contract to build six new nuclear reactors by 2030 is up for bid among five companies, from France, China, South Korea, Russia, and a joint US-Japanese consortium. The French and the Chinese had also considered a joint-bid based on South African encouragement. The contract was finalized in 2011, and bidding for it was planned to begin in 2012. The status of the project is uncertain.

title: Chongqing Chang'an Automobile Co., Ltd. (duplicate of 16820)
description: Automobiles; Automobile DealingChery, JAC, Chang'an Auto Eye on Overseas Marketswww.163.com447 words23 July 2009SinoCast Transportation BeatSTRANB1EnglishCopyright 2009 SinoCast LLC. All Rights Reserved.SHANGHAI, July 23, SinoCast -- Chinese automakers like Chery Automobile Co., Ltd. and Great Wall Motor Co., Ltd. (SEHK: 2333) are strengthening their presence in the global markets.Chery Automobile will put Tiggo into the Brazilian market and the SUV model will start marketing in stores of 27 dealers in 25 Brazilian cities at the end of July 2009, according to its sales subsidiary.Equipped with 2.0-liter engine and priced at about USD 25,000, the model will be the first Chery-branded product that enters Brazil. The Chinese automaker will bring more products to the country in the years ahead.Chery Automobile will drive China-made QQ and A3, and Uruguay-built A1 into the Brazilian market at the end of this year, disclosed one of its deputy general managers. By 2010, the four models will have a total sales volume of 10,000 there.Last week, Great Wall Motor just brought its three products to Australia, and their sales volume is expected to hit 300 a month and top 1,000 at the end of this year.The automaker has just gained an order for 3,300 pickup trucks from Libya. The order is of great importance when China exported only 61,000 vehicles in the first quarter of 2009, slumping 62.06 percent year on year, according to the Chinese Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM).As the biggest pickup truck producer in China, Great Wall Motor has ranked first by sales and export for 11 years. It exported 4,500 pickups to Cuba last year.Now, more than 160,000 pickups of the Chinese automaker have been sold in the global markets. These products have become available in 128 countries and regions.Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Co., Ltd. (JAC, SHSE: 600418) plans to set up a joint venture in Vietnam, an effort to sharpen its competitive edge in the global markets. Moreover, the Chinese automaker will likely build plants in its major overseas markets, Middle East and South Africa.The Vietnam-based venture will be responsible for the manufacturing, marketing, service of JAC's light trucks and some light engineering products and parts. It will possibly expand its business to more JAC products, which depends.Chongqing Chang'an Automobile Co., Ltd. (SZSE: 000625) plans to invest more than USD 80 million in South Africa within the following five years.The Chinese automaker will set up a sales firm in the country, form an auto financing company with its partner, and create an auto subsidiary with a yearly production capacity of over 50,000 vehicles.(USD 1 = CNY 6.83)Document STRANB0020090723e57n00007

title: Zimbabwe granted Approved Tourism Destination status for Chinese
description: In December 2003, the government of China granted the 'Approved Tourism Destination' status onto the country of Zimbabwe. This status indicates that the Chinese government will compel its citizens to visit the country in question while the Zimbabwean government and companies, such as airlines, hotels, tour operators, are permitted to market itself to tourists inside of China. This status is also recognized by the World Tourism Organization and the World Travel and Tourism Council. The Zimbabwean government was represented at the agreement ceremony at the China-Africa Summit in Addis Ababa by President Robert Mugabe while the Chinese government was represented by Premier Wen Jiabao.

title: Nairobi-Thika Road Project - please check Chinese
description: A project to upgrade works of the Nairobi-Thika highway involves expansion of the highway to eight lanes as well as construction of interchanges at six locations to replace roundabouts. The project  also involved improvement of major arteries — Outering, Ngara, Murang’a and Forest roads linking Pangani to Uhuru Highway as well as rehabilitation of drainage and bridge Construction.A blog written about the road's construction reveals that the project's implementation is approaching completion, currently scheduled for July 20, 2012. This road project forms part of a massive infrastructure/road project currently being undertaken in Kenya and financed with Chinese assistance. Connected projects include #1027 and #1112.目前，胜利油田在肯尼亚共有三个项目，分别是内罗毕—西卡道路升级改造项目、援肯尼亚莫伊体育中心维修项目和肯尼亚西部成品油管道扩建工程项目。    内罗毕—西卡道路升级改造项目。该项目位于距肯尼亚首都内罗毕约20公里处，全长23.88公里，是肯尼亚国道主干线A2道路的一部分。该项目业主为肯尼亚政府，中标价约10.7亿元人民币。2008年9月19日，胜利油田胜建集团正式收到肯尼亚道路公共事业部发出的中标通知书，工期30个月，从2009年1月26日到2011年6月25日。目前项目正按计划正常运行，已完成项目部驻地建设、拌合站场地建设。施工内容全合同段路基清表工作，填筑路基土方20万立方米，完成道路设计15公里。    肯尼亚莫伊体育中心维修项目。该工程主要包括体育场、体育馆、游泳馆和运动员宿舍四部分的维修、加固、破损更换及重新装修。该项目中标价约1220万美元，由我国商务部无偿援助。2009年11月14日，胜利油田胜建集团正式收到商务部发出的中标通知书，约定工期12个月，从2009年12月24日至2010年12月23日。目前办公设施及施工用水、用电已经完成，正在做材料和设备物资的准备工作。    肯尼亚西部成品油管道扩建工程项目。2007年7月11日，胜利油田勘察设计院与肯尼亚管道公司签订401万美元的管道扩建工程。根据合同，胜利勘察设计院将承担管道增容的设计咨询、施工招标和施工监理工作，合同工期18个月。监理工作已于2009年11月16日开始，目前正处于监理准备阶段。

title: Zim to Import Telecom Equipment from Huawei (Dup of 17592 and 17650)
description: On June 17, 2004, the government of Zimbabwe's state-owned telecommunications firms NetOne and TelOne announced the signing of contracts with Chinese private telecom company Huawei Technologies for the supply of fixed and mobile telecommunications equipment to both firms back in Zimbabwe. The Zimbabwean government was represented by Minister of Transport and Communications Christopher Mushohwe. It is noted that the flow of financial resources in this project is in reverse with Zimbabwe using government funds to purchase equipment directly from China.

title: Zimbabwe Army receives vehicles from China (Duplicate of 17628)
description: ZNA Receives 22 Vehicles From China365 words13 January 200503:05 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2005 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedHarare, Jan 13, 2005 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --THE Zimbabwe National Army (ZNA) yesterday received a total of 22 Troop Carrying Vehicles (TCV) from the Chinese government as a gesture of fostering the cordial relations between China and Zimbabwe.The vehicles are set to transform the ZNA into a well-equipped, highly-mobile and hard-hitting force.Speaking at a ceremony to handover the vehicles at KGV1 Barracks in Harare, the Chinese Embassys charge daffaires Mrs Ma Deyun said the vehicles were procured after the two countries signed an agreement for co-operation in different areas of interest.She said China and Zimbabwe have enjoyed good relations since the days of the liberation struggle and they have always supported each other in times of need.'We are proud of the achievements we have made in various areas of co-operation,' said Mrs Deyun.ZNA Commander Lieutenant General Philip Valerio Sibanda, who received the vehicles on behalf of the army, thanked the Chinese for the donation.He said the vehicles would go a long way in alleviating transport problems that the army has experienced of late.Lt General Sibanda said most vehicles the ZNA had been using were obtained from Western countries but they were now grounded because spare parts could not be acquired owing to sanctions imposed against the country.Sanctions have been imposed on Zimbabwe by Western powers, particularly Britain and the United States after Zimbabwe embarked on the Land Reform Programme which saw thousands of blacks being allocated land acquired from white former commercial farmers.'We will be holding elections in March so the army vehicles are coming at an appropriate time. This is testimony to our increasing co-operation with China,' said Lt. Gen. Sibanda.He urged the ZNA personnel to look after the vehicles properly.Trade and economic co-operation between Zimbabwe and China has grown tremendously.Under the partnership with China, several joint venture companies have been established in the country.China also remains the biggest buyer of Zimbabwes tobacco.Under the Zimbabwe-China Joint Commission, Zimbabwe has benefited through the Chinese Governments concessionary and interest free loans and grants.Document AFNWS00020050113e11d0018m
donor_agency_count: Zimbabwe National Army (ZNA), Government Agency
verified: Zimbabwe National Army (ZNA), Government Agency

title: Zimbabwe Purchases Chinese Fighters and Missiles
Zimbabwean entrepreneurs fact-finding trip to China
description: Marketing Agency Organises Business Trip to China369 words27 June 200504:05 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2005 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedHarare, Jun 27, 2005 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --A LEADING local marketing agency, African Business Communications (ABC), is organising a seven-day business trip to China that is set to benefit young Zimbabweans seeking to start their own businesses.The business trip, scheduled for the last week of July, would be open to about 100 young entrepreneurs drawn from various sectors of the Zimbabwean economy.China has traditionally offered immense opportunities to Zimbabweans from all walks of life to learn from its political, military, cultural and economic experiences. According to ABC the visit by the delegation would act as a catalyst in facilitating trade links between local businesses headed by young entrepreneurs and the Chinese business community.'The delegation will tour major industrial centres of China where they will visit companies with potential for trade. A number of events outside of the company tours will be organised to allow the local business people to network and interface with their Chinese counterparts,' said an ABC spokesman at the weekend.'Participants will have an opportunity to establish partnerships and linkages with Chinese business, access new markets and expand client base for export-oriented business and networking with Chinese companies wishing to invest in Zimbabwe.'At national level, the visit will cement the relations between Zimbabwe and China, and consolidate the 'Look East' policy that has been articulated by the Government in the face of Western-inspired economic sanctions.Since independence in 1980, Zimbabwe has signed numerous agreements covering economic and technical co-operation, trade, investment protection with China, currently the world's fastest growing economy.A joint economic and trade commission between the two nations has since been set up.'In preparation for the tour, an interactive breakfast meeting has been organised on June 27 (today) at a local hotel where all interested young business people will have a chance to get more information and apply to participate in the tour.'Present at the meeting will be the Deputy Minister of Youth Development, Gender and Employment Creation, Mr Saviour Kasukuwere, and executives from various banks who have committed to financeany business deals that result from the tour,' ABC said.Document AFNWS00020050627e16r002px
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: Telkom Kenya Facilities and Equipment Installation, ZTE (Commitment too early)
description: In 2002, ZTE was awarded a contract to install some telecommunications equipment in Thika, Gatundu and Ruiru. In February 2004, it donated transmission equipment to Telkom Kenya which was installed and commissioned at GPO, Embakasi, Kabete, Uthiru and Jamhuri in Nairobi. It has also donated some equipment, to be installed at Ngong, Karen and Langata.''Now that we have been listed in two stock markets, we have more capital for investment,' ZTE general manager for East Africa, Mr Hesse Dong, told BusinessWeek. The expansion plans have also come after an eight-year engagement with Telkom Kenya. where ZTE has installed facilities and equipment worth Sh400 million.

title: CICO wins bid for road project in Liberia
description: Chongqing Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Group Co., Ltd. announced on February 5, 2012 that its subsidiary, China Chongqing International Construction Corporation (CICO) won the bid for the No. 15 Gate of Public Engineering Department-Pa'anga Road Rehabilitation Project in Liberia. The project is for a 180.36 kilometer road. The cost of the project is US$166 million. This does not appear to be an 'aid' project, but a Chinese state-owned enterprise is implementing the project。

title: Chinese delegation in Zimbabwe to offer health and medicine assistance
description: China, Zimbabwe to boost cooperation on traditional medicine248 words5 April 2007Industry UpdatesBDUEnglishCopyright 2007 China Daily Information Company. All Rights Reserved.China and Zimbabwe should redouble the efforts to boost cooperation on projects of the two countries' traditional medicine, a visiting Chinese traditional medicine scholar said on Wednesday.Xiao Caisong, head of a Chinese delegation and executive officer of Changsha Taibao Pharmaceutical Group, said they were in Zimbabwe to inspect the industry and seek out investment opportunities.'We are happy to know some Chinese doctors specializing in acupuncture in the Chgituingwiza hospital when we toured the hospital,' he said.Xiao told Xinhua that they planned to introduce 25 Chinese medicines on the market, seven of them traditional.'We are engaged in talks with the Ministry of Health and Child Welfare that we hope will give us a better insight into Zimbabwe's common problem diseases. From our initial research we understand some of them are HIV/AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis and skin diseases,' Xiao said.The delegation is on a two-week tour of Zimbabwe's pharmaceutical industry to scout for investmentopportunities.On Wednesday, they met Zimbabwe's Health and Child Welfare Minister David Parirenyatwa and they will visit some Zimbabwean pharmaceutical companies, including CAPS and Varichem medicine processing plants.The visiting delegation is also expected to tour the National Pharmaceutical Company (NATPHARM) and several pharmacies in Harare.The Zimbabwean government has also urged the local health sector to make joint efforts with their Chinese counterparts to develop traditional Chinese medicine and local traditional medicine to meet the country's demands.Document BDU0000020070405e34500015

title: Kavumu Airport Road
description: The commitment for this project was made as a part of FOCAC 2006. The China Communications Construction Company (CCCC) is the contractor on the Kavumu Airport Road, which is financed by a donation from the Chinese government. The project, when finished, will connect Bukavu to the Kavumu airport, and will stretch 35 km long. The work was launched in Bukavu on May 26, 2008, and the most recently found status is implementation as of January 2010. The financial amount and current status are yet unknown.

title: Zimbabwe gets Chinese farm machinery
description: In 2007, China donated farm machinery worth $25 million USD to replace equipment damaged when President Robert Mugabe's government seized white-owned farms to resettle landless blacks. The total loan facility granted by China was $58 million USD (Project ID#19193), and these items comprise the first phase of this total loan. For the first phase of the project, comprising US$25 million of the grand total, the Chinese company CAMC Engineering will supply the agricultural equipment to Zimbabwe including 424 tractors, 65 dump trucks, 40 heavy duty harrows, and 8 bulldozers. Farmers' World, a Zimbabwean agricultural equipment dealer, was responsible for importing the equipment and was also responsible for loaning out the equipment to needy farmers on a five-year basis would service their loaned equipment with payments of harvested tobacco. Farmers' World operates this program in conjunction with the State Department of Agricultural Research and Extension Services, the Zimbabwe Farmers' Development Trust, and the Agricultural Development Bank of Zimbabwe. On April 12, 2007, a Chinese media report indicated that President Robert Mugabe oversaw a ceremony commissioning the 424 tractors, disc harrows, and planters imported from China from the first phase of the project. A Zimbabwe Reserve Bank report from January 2007 indicated that an additional 357 tractors, 65 dumper trucks, 50 thirty-tonne truck horses, 50 twenty tonne trailers, 8 bulldozers, and 86 water pumps were also purchased and imported under this loan facility. The Zimbabwean government, through the Zimbabwe Farmers' Development Trust, intends to repay the loan from the Chinese company through the delivery of 30,000,000 kilograms of tobacco for four straight years to China followed by an increase to 80,000,000 kilograms in the fifth year. The government of Zimbabwe was represented by Minister for Agricultural Engineering Joseph Made and the Vice President Joice Mujuru, CAMC Engineering was represented by Jia Qinglin, the chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, and Luo Yan, the company president, and Farmers' World was represented by company managing director Edward Raradza and company vice president Joseph Msika.The second phase of this project is outlined in ID#27714.

title: China provides loan for offices, research center
description: In 2008, the Chinese Vice-Minister of Commerce and the Ivorian Minister of Foreign Affairs signed an agreement worth 26 billion CFA provided by China to help rehabilitate ministerial offices and to build a Research Center to fight against malaria. Anti-malaria medicines were also provided by the Chinese government. Reporting on the same subject, Le Jour Plus (a daily close to the opposition) said that China donated 27.3 billion CFA to help with post-crisis reconstruction.

title: Zimbabwe signs US$5 billion platinum deal with China
description: On July 6, 2009, the Export-Import bank of China and the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe signed a memorandum of understanding for a US$5 billion loan to Zimbabwe that would be used to improve infrastructure and restore economic well-being in the country while China, on the other end, will receive 50 percent equity in the mining of platinum in Zimbabwe. Estimates suggest that China will collect up to US$20 billion, or 50%, of the estimated US$40 billion-worth platinum supplies in Zimbabwe. The government of Zimbabwe was represented by the Minister of Finance, Tendai Biti; the governor of the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe, Gideon Gono; Minister Tendai's chief adviser, Conrad Nyamoruva; Ministry of Finance official Mary Takavarasha; the deputy governor of the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe, Edward Mashiringwani, and Governor Gono's chief adviser Munyaradzi Kereke. A singular July 4, 2009 report from Zimbabwean media outlet ZimEye suggests, contrarily, that no such agreement occurred in the first place. A 2011 report stated that Eximbank's offer was for $3 billion rather than $5 billion. It also suggested that the deal was still being discussed, and no formal agreements had been made.

title: Sinopec Acquisition of Offshore Oil Block 18
description: In March 2010, Chinese company Sinopec signed a deal to acquire a stake in Oil Block 18 in Angola, from its parachute company, China Petrochemical Corporation. Under the terms of the agreement, Sinopec is to take a 55% controlling stake in Sonangol Sinopec International (SSI) from Sinopec Group subsidiary Sinopec Overseas Oil   Gas (SOOG). The firm is set to pay $1.68 billion USD and take on $0.78 billion of debt and interest payments owed by SSI to SOOG. This brings the sum total paid for SSI to $2.46 billion. As a result, Sinopec's oil reserves will have grown by 102 million barrels. Furthermore its production levels will increase by 72,520 barrels per day.

title: Duplicate: Chinese charity donates sweaters to African countries
description: Chinese charity to donate sweaters to abandoned, disabled African childrenrongyan241 words22 November 201006:45 AMXinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) 2010 Xinhua News AgencyBEIJING, Nov. 22 (Xinhua) -- A Chinese charity will this year give sweaters to abandoned and disabled children in six African nations - South Africa, Kenya, Nigeria, Sudan, Zambia and Zimbabwe.A spokesperson for the China Children and Teenagers' Fund (CCTF) said Monday 2,010 sweaters weaved by Chinese moms will be donated.'For the different climates on the African continent, sweaters are necessary to keep out the cold,' CCTF spokesperson Hu Wenxin said.The sweaters will be specially weaved by the volunteers with thin wool, since most of the children do not need thick sweaters.Over the past five years, more than 550,000 sweaters have been given to abandoned and disabled Chinese children under the charity program.'Everybody that can weave and that has spare time can show their love by knitting the sweaters,' said He Junyi, an official in charge of the charity program.He said he hopes the orphans and disabled children in Africa will feel the love of Chinese moms.Peter Oloishura Nkuraiyia, executive director of the NGO Coordination Board of Kenya, told He during a visit to Shanghai in July the generosity of the Chinese mom volunteers shows the love that exists between the Chinese and African peoples.Nkuraiyia's Shanghai trip unveiled the charity program's first donation to the six African nation's children - 2,010 Shanghai World Expo commemorative T-shirts.Enditem01Xinhua News AgencyDocument XNEWS00020101122e6bm0066j

title: Construction of KRC Friendship School (Duplicate)
description: In 2000, the newly-built Khartoum Refinery donated USD 700,000 to establish the KRC Friendship School. Located in the residential area for Sudanese employees around the refinery, the school occupies an area of 1,824 square meters, and consists of Pre-School, Primary and Secondary education divisions. At present, the school has 31 staff and faculty members and 687 students. Since the school began operating, the refinery donates about USD 10,000 in stationary supplies to the school each year. Over the ten years of the school’s operation, over 3,000 students have graduated, with a 100% graduation rate, and 104 graduates have been recruited into universities and colleges in Sudan. With such excellent results, the school is now well known far and widePossibly a duplicate of Project ID#20758

title: Highway Project (Inactive See Project 54)
description: >'Copyright 2005, Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved.>> >>A Chinese company, the China Roads and Bridge Corporation, has been awarded the contract to build or rehabilitate the 371 km highway between Kifangondo in the metropolitan region of Luanda and the town of Negage in the northern province of Uíge, via the the city of Caxito (Bengo Province). The announcement of the award was made by the Angolan National Roads Institute (INEA), which is overseeing the US$211 million project. According to O Apostolado, the first phase is focusing on the 58 km stretch between Kifangondo and Catete. Work on this stretch is reported to have begun last week. The entire project should be concluded within 27 months.>> >>Significance: The Luanda-Uíge road rehabilitation will be crucial to the revial of coffee production and copper mining in the northern provinces, which has been largely moribund since the outbreak of the civil war in 1975 and has shown few signs of recovery since the end of the conflict in 2002. The project also highlights the growing role of Chinese investment in Angola. The road rehabilitation programme is financed by the US$2 billion credit line provided by the Chinese Eximbank on extremely cheap terms. Under the agreement, Chinese companies must be awarded 70% of the resultant construction work, a small price for the Angolan authorities to pay for a loan so unburdened by conditions. The Chinese loan facility will be the main source of income for the Angolan government's public investment programme in coming years. Although the facility will hopefully improve the overall infrastructure and growth performance in the economy, it also has been the catalyst in the Angolan government's recent spat with the International Monetary Fund (IMF; see Angola: 16 February 2005: Angolan Government Unable to Comply with IMF Criteria). The substantial loan facility from China has opened up the opportunity for the Angolan government to ignore the IMF's loan conditions, so it remains to be seen if issues between the two parties can be resolved in the coming months (see Angola: 20 April 2005: Angolan Finance Minister Downplays IMF Disagreement). '>> >>'Luanda, Angola, 27 June – Chinese state company China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which is rebuilding 371 kilometers of the national road linking Kifangondo (Luanda), Caxito (Bengo), Uíge and Negage (Uíge) in Angola, is due to finish work in June 2008, officials told Angolan news agency Angpop.>> >>The project, work on which began in December 2005, is estimated to cost US$211 million.>> >>So far 140 kilometers of the road have been de-mined, which is the first stage of work required for rebuilding to go ahead.>> >>The rebuilding project, which involves over 3,000 Angolan and Chinese workers, includes 12 bridges, 10 of which will be new, and also requires over 200 aqueducts to be built.>> >>One of the main aims of the reconstruction of this road is to re-launch agricultural activities in the region. (macauhub)'>
