title: Duplicate: Malarial Research centre in Abidjan
description: See ID# 716Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Abidjan, 16 August: The problem of poverty is a big challenge for Africa and the fight against this scourge has been the main preoccupation of most governments on the continent.Most analysts have observed that China has been deeply involved in the fight against poverty on the continent besides African governments. China has also remained faithful on the side of the continent as witnessed in a number of initiatives that have been launched in various sectors.Among African countries, Cote d'Ioire is one of those which have benefited a lot from China's support and help.In the health sector, taking the case of malaria as an example, the means to fight against the disease have been reinforced in Cote d'Ioire thanks to Sino-Cote d'Ioire cooperation.Through collaboration with Cote d'Ioire's health ministry, the Chinese government has put up a research centre in Abidjan which will help in the fight against malaria. The Cote d'Ioire authorities have said that this malaria research centre came at the right time and it will help to improve the health status of the population.'Malaria is a real health problem in the country and it represents the first reason for medical consultations in our hospitals. A centre offered by a friendly nation (China) will help to relieve the pain of most of our people,' Patrice Konan, a doctor at a hospital in Abidjan, said in a recent interview with Xinhua.The impoverization of the people comes not only through the deterioration of health conditions, but also through food deficiency.Cote d'Ioire has also received support from China in her efforts to achieve food sufficiency through production of foodstuffs like rice.In March this year, China which is the biggest rice producer in the world gave Cote d'Ioire authorities over 200 tons of fertilizers and hundreds of agricultural machines whose cost was evaluated at 2 million euros.Still, following the appeal from Cote d'Ioire for the Chinese support on the strategies for reviing rice farming, a Chinese delegation of experts visited several Cote d'Ioire localities in 2010 to train rice farmers.The Chinese delegation in Cote d'Ioire was led by Director of the International Center for the Fight Against Poverty (LPRCC) Wu Zhing.'There's need to take advantage of the Chinese experience in order to increase food production,' a Cote d'Ioire investment expert Raymond Sibailly said recently.'The IPRCC is one of the biggest global institutions involved in the fight against poverty. This center also works with the universities of China and through its actions, this country has achieved miracles in the fight against poverty,' Sibailly said.The problem of housing is another big challenge for Cote d'Ioire. In the country, most of the people do not have decent houses to live. In most towns, there's a problem of slums which house the jobless people or those who earn little wages. Most families live in makeshift houses because of poverty.In order to help resolve the housing problem, China has partnered with the Cote d'Ioire government in the construction sector to try and reduce the housing shortage.During a recent meeting with a Chinese construction company, Cote d'Ioire Prime Minister Guillume Soro called for concerted efforts with Cote d'Ioire's Construction and Housing Company (SICOGI) to ensure that majority of the people live in decent houses.Recently Cote d'Ioire experienced a post-election crisis which resulted in the loss of lives and destruction of property. Soon after the crisis was over, the country's President Alassane Ouattara announced that reconstruction of the country would be one of his main priorities.China has expressed its willingness to help Cote d'Ioire in the reconstruction process.After several preliminary meetings with Cote d'Ioire's authorities during which the Chinese emissaries promised support from their country, Sino-Cote d'Ioire agreements regarding Chinese aid for Cote d'Ioire's post-crisis reconstruction were signed in June this year.Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Zhai Jun and Cote d'Ioire's Foreign Minister Daniel Kablan Duncan signed the documents which granted Cote d'Ioire loans and cancellation of Cote d'Ioire's debt.In addition, China has also given Cote d'Ioire 'urgent materials' worth 1.09 billion Fcfa.China has honoured the commitments she made to Cote d'Ioire.'The crisis increased poverty in Cote d'Ioire. The Chinese contribution is expected to help in the revial of activities in some of the country's sectors,' said Emmanuel Lohoues, an official at Cote d'Ioire's finance ministry.'On the path of development, Cote d'Ioire will always have China on her side,' Zhai promised.Chinese Ambassador to Cote d'Ioire Wei Wenhua has on several occasions reiterated his country's willingness to help Cote d'Ioire on her development path.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 0644gmt 16 Aug 11

title: PPIAF - Wind Power projects in Adama and Mesobo Harena- duplicate with 1380
description: (PPIAF) The Adama and Messobo Harrena projects will cost about 123 million and 127 million dollars, respectively. They will be financed by the Chinese Government through the Export-Import Bank of China. The contracts were signed between EEPCo and HydroChina. The signing oft he contracts was attended by Girma Biru, minister of Trade and Industry, Alemayehu Tegenu, minister of Mines and Energy, and Sinkinesh Ejigu, state minister of Mines and Energy. The two projects will generate 51 MW wind power each. The Adama wind farm is located 95 km east of Addis Ababa, near Adama in Oromia, while the Messabo Harrena project lies 763 km o the north near Mekelle. EEPCo plans to get 30 MW wind power within six months from the date of the contract.

title: Zhu signs five documents on cooperation
China seeks timber from Gabon (needs confirmation)
description: The new entrant to the scramble is China. Despite its large land area, it is a resource-poor country and Africa offers the natural resources vital to fuel its rapidly growing economy. China looks to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and Zambia for copper and cobalt, to South Africa for iron ore and platinum, and to Gabon, Cameroon and the Republic of the Congo (Congo-Brazzaville) for timber.//加蓬和中国林业国际合作公司建立了加蓬华嘉木业股份公司，这是一个合资的木材加工企，项目总投资为2 673.9万美元，建设规模为年产12万m3旋切单板和5万m3的制材厂。//自2004年以来，在两国元首互访的带动下，中加两国经贸合作的步伐越走越快，合作领域越扩越宽，特别是2006年中非合作论坛北京峰会之后，我与加在木材开发领域的互利合作更是跃上了一个新台阶。 　　中方投资企业由过去的两三家发展到现在的十来家，尤其是最近两年，中国木材加工出口企业响应加蓬政府关于林地整治规划、保证可持续开采、减少原木出口、增加就地加工、提高出口木材附加值、解决当地就业的号召，正在进入到大规模投资创业阶段。 　　据初步统计，中国企业在加蓬森林行业的投资额已超过1亿美元，拥有林地200多万公顷，已建成和在建木材加工厂10家，雇佣加蓬员工1500多人。　 　　大部分中国企业都与水森部签署了林地规划临时协议，开始进行林地规划和工厂建设。　 　　当前，中国木材企业遇到的最大问题是原木出口配额问题的困扰，去年开始，中国企业所得配额大量减少，主要是按加蓬新政策，出口配额和规划进展程度挂钩，而中国企业来加蓬落户较晚，大部分处在投资创业阶段，还没有来得及做规划，而做规划的投资相当昂贵

title: New Mosaics Unit in Guelma (duplicate of #22429)
description: On August 17, 2002 a Chinese delegation led by Prime Minister Zhu Rongjil, Algeria and China signed several agreements. One agreement provide for the construction of a new mosaics unit in Guelma and for the dispatch of a Chinese medical team to Algeria. Searching for this project did not reveal any new information.Other agreements signed at the same time include an economic and technical agreement with Algeria that regulates a USD 6mn (although some sources say 7mn) loan with 25 years maturity from China #272, an agreement for a medical dispatch team # 21879, an agreement to rehabilitate and modernize a Chinese-built factory started over in 1999 #22429, and an agreement to enhance the existing cultural cooperation, which covers the 2002-2004 period #22436.

title: Dam construction Burundi (Duplicate)
description: 'Text of report by Burundi news agency ABPBujumbura, 9 October: The economic context of Sino-Burundian cooperation is marked by six priority projects in various sectors, ABP has learnt from the department in charge of Asia at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.These projects include the construction of the presidential palace, the rehabilitation of the Mugere Hydroelectric Station, the construction of three rural elementary schools, including two in Karusi Province (eastern central Burundi) and another at the Bujumbura Town Hall, the construction of a general hospital, the installation of a malaria prevention and treatment centre and the supply of anti-malarial drugs.At the conclusion of the 10th session of the Joint Sino-Burundian Commission held from 11 to 13 September 2007, when both parties went through cooperation in the financial, technical and commercial plans with a fine tooth comb, it emerged that an agreement for a donation of 30m yuan, or 4,414,050 US dollars, was signed for the rehabilitation of Mugere Hydroelectric Station.In addition, the session ended with a draft agreement relating to the cancellation of Burundi's debts to China of 137,470,000 yuan, equivalent to [approximately] 15,210,455 US dollars.The two governments are currently in negotiation over the Mpanda power generation hydroelectric and irrigation project which is being built by the Chinese company Gezhouba Water and Power (Group) Company Limited (CGGC). This project was to be financed through a preferential loan, will be carried out at a cost of 40,920,157 US dollars. The Burundian Foreign Ministry department in charge of Asia stresses that Sino-Burundian cooperation is very diversified and also touches the education and health sectorsIn 2008 China offered to 10 scholarships to Burundi for post-graduate studies.In the medical field, China sends medical teams every two years to assist the Burundian people.Source: ABP news agency, Bujumbura, in French 1027 gmt 9 Oct 08a8f2d59fDocument BBCAP00020081009e4a9001xj'

title: Bus factory and bus provision (duplicate #328)
description: In March 2010 chairman of China's National Committee of the People's Political Consultative Conference Jia Qinglin and Cameroonian President Paul Biya signed a deal to provide for the construction of a car factory that produces buses in Cameroon. The operation will join private investors from China and Cameroon, and was expected to start producing buses by the end of 2010. The same agreement also calls for the delivery of 500 Chinese buses in July for use between and within Cameroonian cities. Wu Yue, vice president of China's National Machinery Import and Export Corporation and Zacharia Awanga, the deputy chief of International Development in Cameroon's Ministry of Economy and Planning both publicly commented on the deal.

title: Memve'ele hydropower station- duplicate with 289
description: 'SHANGHAI, April 26, SinoCast -- The Cameroonian government is to sign a contract to borrow about EUR 500 million from the Export-Import Bank of China at the end of April so as to fund the construction of Memve'ele hydropower station in the south of Cameroon, according to the country's finance minister ESSIMI MENYE Lazare.An executive with the Export-Import Bank of China confirms that the lender is indeed in talks with the Cameroonian government on the lending but he declines to comment on disclosure by the finance minister, airing that it is not convenient to unveil details before inking the contract.SINOHYDRO undertakes construction of the Memve'ele hydropower station. The Chinese company clinched a EUR 556 million construction contract with the Cameroonian government as early as 2009, and the government files with the Export-Import Bank of China for preferential loans to fund the project.The Memve'ele hydropower station, with an installed capacity of 200 megawatts, was previously predicted to come under construction in March 2010 and to come into official operation prior to December 2014. However, the financing has not been implemented to date.'

title: Energy package to Comorian islands (Not a project...yet...)
description: 'Copyrights 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedThe aid proposal formulated by the Chinese energy mission during its visit to Moroni in mid-August turned out to be controversial. The mission had come at the request of President Ahmed Abdallah Sambi and had been guided by the Union of the Comoros Minister for Energy Houmadi Abdallah, a native of the island of Anjouan. It had offered to supply four 1.6 MW electricity generators and 40 km of cable to the island of Ngazidja, two 1.6 MW generators and 40 km of cable to Anjouan and two 800 KW generators plus 30 km of cable to Mohéli. After the delegation left a dispute broke out between the government of Ngazidja and the island legislative assembly on one hand and the Minister Houmadi Abdallah on the other hand. The former accused the latter of having sidelined them from the meetings with the Chinese experts.According to the Ngazidja MPs, the original Chinese idea was to install an electricity power station on Grande Comore, but the office of President Sambi and Houmadi Abdallah had “denatured” this project “to the benefit of Anjouan and Mohéli” where the energy situation is nevertheless less alarming than on Ngazidja”. Hoping to calm down the debate, Houmadi Abdallah stated that “the Chinese proposal can only be put into effect after approval by the government of the Union”. The MPs were furious and insisted that the government of the Union ask the Ngazidja authorities for their opinion on this matter.33143440Document IOLET00020070921e39800006'

title: Copper for Infrastructure Deal
description: In September 2007, China and DRCongo signed a loan agreement for $5 billion for infrastructural and mining projects. The Congolese Infrastructure Minister Pierre Lumbi reported that $3 billion will be spent on infrastructure, including 2,000 miles of railway between Sakania and Matadi, a 2,000-mile road linking Kisanganiand and Kasumbalesa, a motorway between Lubumbashi and Kasumbalesa, 31 hospitals, 145 health centers, two international-standard universities, and 5,000 government housing units. The motorway between Lubumbashi and Kasumbalesa was completed by the CREC from March-November 2008, totaling 72 km of road. The transportation projects were planned to be completed within 36 months. The remaining $2 billion will be used for mining projects. An unnamed four Chinese SOEs will own a 68% stake in the joint venture with the DRC-owned Gecamines.THIS IS NOT A DUPLICATE WITH PROJECT ID#450, please consult http://www.sarwatch.org/component/content/article/126-headline-news-for-the-drc/258-china-eyes-congos-treasures-.html and http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFPR000020071206e3c6004nh

title: Egyptian-Chinese joint industrial venture (Duplicate)
description: 'ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, April 17 (AFP) - Chinese President Jiang Zemin held talks here Monday with his Egyptian counterpart Hosni Mubarak about the Middle East peace process and bilateral trade, Egyptian officials said.Before entering talks at a seafront palace in the Mediterranean city of Alexandria, Jiang issued a statement calling for 'more cooperation in politics, economics, culture and international relations' between Egypt and China.He recalled that when Mubarak visited China last year, the two leaders signed an agreement to start a 'strategic cooperation' paving the way for future relations.'Egypt is a very important state in the Arab and African area and it has special influence in regional and international relations,' Jiang said.'The international situation and the Middle East (have) become more complex and more volatile at a time when there is economic globalization, which creates more challenges for developing countries,' he added.The Chinese leader arrived from Israel in the morning on his second visit to Egypt.Beijing has been encouraging Chinese firms to invest in Egypt as they would get or will get tariff exemptions enjoyed in African and Arab regional economic groupings as well as the European Union.An Egyptian-Chinese joint venture has bought parcels in an industrial zone in the northwestern Gulf of Suez in order to build a petrochemical plant, oil refinery, fertilizer plant, automobile parts factory and a steel mill.The venture is made up of the Tingjin Economic Development Area Corporation and the Egyptian partners of Osman Ahmed Osman Arab Contractors, the Suez Canal Authority, the National Investment Bank and Misr Bank.Chinese embassy officials said last year that Chinese textile firms have been limited by export quotas to EU countries and the United States.Tingjin was to design and plan the zone, carry out construction and infrastructure development and then sell to investors.Chinese investment in Egypt amounts to only 17 million dollars, according to the General Authority for Investment.In 1956, Cairo became the first Arab capital to have diplomatic relations with China. '

title: China supports African countries seeking development aid
description: 'LIBREVILLE, Feb. 3 (Xinhua) - Visiting Chinese President Hu Jintao and his Gabonese counterpart El Hadj Omar Bongo Ondimba have pledged to push the China-Gabon cooperation to a new high. In a communique signed here on Tuesday, the two leaders expressed satisfaction over the healthy and steady development of China-Gabon ties since the two countries forged diplomatic relations three decades ago. They vowed to maintain the exchange of high-level visits between China and Gabon, step up cooperation in various fields and increase consultations on African and international affairs. Gabon voiced support for China's reunification. It reiterated that there is only one China in the world, with the government of the People's Republic of China being the sole legal government representing China as a whole and Taiwan being an inalienable part of China. Both sides said that they will boost trade and investment, continue to support cooperation between enterprises and make sure the implementation of the signed cooperation agreements. They said cooperation will be focused on agriculture, infrastructure construction, resources exploitation and personnel training. China reaffirmed its willingness to render support within its ability for Gabon's economic and social development. The two countries agreed that in a world undergoing complicated and profound changes, peace and development remain to be the two major themes of the present times and the common aspiration of the peoples of all countries. They called for more international consultations to maintain diversity of the world and promote exchanges among countries of different civilizations and development modes. In regard to the economic globalization, both sides called on the international community to adopt measures to help developing countries overcome difficulties and enhance their ability to achieve an independent, sustainable development and protect the environment. They also urged developed countries to shoulder due responsibilities, expand access to their markets, remove trade barriers, and honor their commitments on financial and technological support and debt reduction and cancellation.     They said maintaining stability and alleviating poverty are twopressing tasks faced by African countries.   China supports the Africa Union and sub-regional organizations  in Africa in playing a greater role in achieving peace and stability in the continent and promoting regional integration process. China also supports African countries in seeking development and prosperity through the implementation of the 'New Partnership Program for African Development.' The two sides stressed the importance of solving conflicts in Africa through dialogue, and called on the international community to care more about the continent's situation. China will continue to participate in the United Nations peace-keeping missions in Africa and provide support to peace-keeping activities of Africa's regional and sub-regional organizations. The two countries highly value the China-Africa friendship and cooperation and regard the 'China-Africa Cooperation Forum' as an important platform for China-Africa consultations and cooperation.     China and Gabon will strengthen cooperation within theframework of this forum and promote the China-Africa partnershipdesigned for full cooperation and common development.'

title: Suez Free Trade Zone (Duplicate)
description: Cairo, 18 April: Egyptian Prime Minister Ubayd said emphatically here recently that Egypt and China share a long-standing history of friendly exchange; and the two countries have achieved notable results in cooperation in various fields in recent years. He expressed the belief that through the joint efforts by the two governments and the two peoples, the two countries will have a still brighter future in the development of their relations. Chinese State Council Premier Zhu Rongji will begin an official visit to Egypt from 19 April at the invitation of Egyptian President Mubarak. In an exclusive interview with the Xinhua News Agency on the eve of Premier Zhu Rongji's visit, Prime Minister Ubayd said that both Egyptian and Chinese Governments have always attached great importance to developing bilateral relations; and that the top leaders of the two countries have exchanged visits frequently. President Mubarak has visited China eight times thus far, while the Chinese leaders have visited Egypt on many occasions. During President Mubarak's visit to China in January this year, the two countries signed a total of five documents, including an agreement on economic and technical cooperation, an agreement on cooperation in peaceful use of atomic energy, a framework agreement on cooperation in the field of petroleum, and a memorandum of understanding on implementing the proposal on Chinese citizens' group tours in Egypt. Thanks to the joint efforts by both sides, bilateral friendly and cooperative relations have become stronger and stronger; and the two countries have achieved fruitful results in economic, trade, military, agricultural, and tourism cooperation. Ubayd said: Remarkable progress has been made in bilateral trade and economic relations in recent years. The volume of two-way trade has increased by a big margin year after year, while Chinese investments in Egypt have also increased considerably. He said: Located in an important geographical position, Egypt enjoys domestic political stability and has a vast market. The Egyptian government has adopted a series of measures designed to improve the investment environment, to build up confidence in the Egyptian market among foreign entrepreneurs, and to attract more foreign capital. Ubayd believed that there exist vast vistas for increasing bilateral trade and improving the structure of trade and economic exchange between the two countries. In addition, the two countries also have great potentials for cooperation in the fields of petroleum, agriculture, banking, insurance, tourism, and ocean shipping. Progress has been made in China's participation in the construction of Egypt's Suez Canal Free Trade Zone. He added that there are broad prospects for cooperation in science and technology; and the two countries can work together in organizing technical seminars, and strengthen contacts and exchanges of scientific research personnel. Source: Xinhua news agency domestic service, Beijing, in Chinese 0731 gmt 18 Apr 02.
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: CMEC iron infrastructure in Belinga- duplicate with 630
description: China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corp. (CMEC) recently inked an agreement in the Republic of Gabon to develop the country's Belinga iron ore deposit, according to a CMEC announcement released on July 7.Under the agreement, a Chinese consortium lead by CMEC, with financial support from the Export-Import Bank of China, will establish a joint venture with Gabonese partners to construct and operate a 30 million-ton per annum iron ore mining facility, as well related infrastructure.Infrastructure will consist of two railway lines stretching approximately 500 kilometers in total, a deep-water port and a hydropower dam, which along with the mining facility, will require total investment of approximately EUR 450 million ($706.63 million).The mining facility is expected to commence production by 2010, and CMEC has pledged to offtake the entire iron ore output from the joint venture, state-run Shanghai Securities News reported July 8.CMEC defeated competitor Vale, the Brazilian iron ore miner, in a June 2006 auction for the mining rights to the Belinga iron ore deposit, which boasts an estimated 1 billion tons of iron ore reserves at a grade of 64 percent.CMEC, a subsidiary of the state-owned China National Machinery Industry Corporation (Sinomach), specializes in overseas engineering contracting as well as in the import and export of machinery. //State-owned China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMEC) has signed an agreement with the government of Gabon to develop a iron ore mine in the African country, the official Shanghai Securities News reported. The parties will set up a joint venture to run the Belinga mine, which is expected to produce 30 mln tons of iron ore annually, the paper said. Total investment on for the development and exploration of the mine is expected to reach more than 790 mln usd. The company will also build a 500 kilometer railway, a water power station and a deepwater port, it added. The Export-Import Bank of China will finance the project, according to the paper. kelly.zang@xfn.com//Ask the Chinese to finance and expand even further the Sishen-Saldanha rail link? In Gabon, the Chinese are building the link between the Belinga iron-ore deposit and the port of Santa Clara, plus the associated power station and port facilities as well.//The government and the Chinese consortium led by the China National Machinery and Equipment Corporation (CMEC) have signed a convention specifying new regulations for the exploitation of the giant Bélinga iron ore deposit in the northeast of the country. Bélinga holds an estimated 1bn tonnes of iron ore with 64% purity. The project has progressed more slowly than was originally expected after the signing of the first memorandum of understanding (MoU) in 2006, in part because of disagreements over shareholdings in the project. After several months of intense discussions, a convention signed in December 2007 granted the Gabonese state a 25% stake in the company responsible for exploiting the deposit, Compagnie Minière de Bélinga (Comibel). Technical specifications have been another apparent source of tension: following the signing of the first MoU, the government believed that the works could be completed by 2012 (that is, before the scheduled presidential election).

title: Construction of training college
description: According to Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia, Ai Ping, China allocated $12 million from its aid resources to Ethiopia to finance the construction of an Ethiopian training college. The status of the project is uncertain.

title: Mubarak-1 Oil Rig/Drill Manufacturing (Duplicate)
description: 'BDUEnglishCopyright 2007 China Daily Information Company. All Rights Reserved.Chinese and Egyptian officials on Wednesday laid a foundation stone for a joint venture project to make oil drills, which is the first land oil rig plant in the Middle East region.Jointly laying the foundation stone with Chinese Ambassador to Egypt Wu Sike, Egyptian Minister of Petroleum Amin Sameh Samir Fahmi told Xinhua that the project in the Suez northwestern industrial zone, about 120 kilometers east of Cairo, is a successful story, expecting more Chinese investments in the oil sectors of Egypt as the bilateral cooperation is practical and mutually beneficial.Fahmi also expressed Egypt's keenness to learn China's technology and development experience to promote Egypt's social and economic progress.For his part, Wu praised the progress the joint venture has made, reviewing that the memorandum of understanding was signed last October, the contract signed last December and the venture could start to produce drills only half a year later.The Chinese party to the joint venture is Sichuan Honghua Petroleum Equipment Co Ltd while the Egyptian side comprises three parties, which included an oil and oil processing firm, an oil consultation company and a petroleum company.Earlier statistics from China's customs showed that the trade volume between the two countries reached US$3.19 billion in 2006, up 48.8 percent year on year.Document BDU0000020070601e36100003'

title: Possible railway construction in Gabon
description: 'China's role in the operation is decisive,' Onouviet said, but he added that a role for the French group Eramet, which mines manganese in Gabon and runs the Transgabonese Railway via a subsidiary, has been provided for in the framework accord signed in China. Apart from the infrastructure and future possibilities opened by the rail link, 'this work is going to create thousands of jobs,' the minister said, but while he was full of enthusiasm, he said 'the labour will only begin once the Chinese side is convinced of the worth of the site'. The full Chinese answer should be known at the end of October, once a team of geologists and logistics experts, due to arrive in Gabon in the next few days, has done its work.

title: Manganese mining in Mbigou, Gabon
description: The government of Gabon signed a contract in 2005 with China’s Sinosteel to prospect for manganese ore in the southern region of Mbigou. However, the mine in Mbigou was situated in a rugged area making exploitation very difficult. In 2011 Sinosteel declared the mine no longer economically viable, and returned its mining license to the Gabonese State.STAFF_NOTES:The included Local Language Source may not reference this project, and may only be related to project #633.

title: Preferential loans, Export credits, and Special Fund
description: 'Although China's trade has been running a deficit against Africa in recent years, China still hopes to further expand its import from African countries,' Wen told 27 presidents and 6 prime ministers from Africa, as well as nearly 1,300 Chinese and African entrepreneurs at the gathering. Earlier Saturday, at the opening ceremony of the Beijing Summit of Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, President Hu Jintao made fresh pledges to facilitate bilateral trade and cooperation. He said China will double its aid to Africa by 2009, increase from 190 to over 440 the number of tariff-free import items from the least developed African countries having diplomatic ties with China. China will also provide 3 billion U.S. dollars in preferential loans and 2 billion U.S. dollars of export credits over the next three years and establish a special fund of 5 billion U.S. dollars to encourage Chinese investment in Africa. Calling these measures 'pragmatic and stimulative', Wen made five proposals to entrepreneurs from both China and Africa. He said both sides should work closer in service sectors, tourism, finance and telecommunications in particular, to cultivate new economic growth points and facilitate trade in a more balanced and healthier manner. He said China will encourage capable and reputed indigenous companies to invest in Africa and spread their technology and management experiences. 'African companies interested in investing in China are welcome, ' Wen said. African leaders attending the conference also called for expanding trade and promoting cooperation in the business circles. Ethiopian Prime Minister Ato Meles Zenawi said business communities could evolve into a crucial force to facilitate cooperation between China and African countries. Without solid support of civil collaboration, Africa-China cooperation may not flourish. Gabonese President El Hadj Omar Bongo Ondimba said Central Africa, a peaceful land with 130 million population, has gradually walked out of various difficulties and created a favorable environment for international trade and foreign investment. He believes China and African countries will find out new measures at the FOCAC Beijing Summit to further cement cooperation so as to upgrade their strategic partnership to a higher level.

title: Construction of railway, dam, and port
description: Chinese companies have vastly increased their investments in Africa over the past six months, and in every type of ore. The latest Chinese foray has been in Gabon. Africa Mining Intelligence understands the China Eximbank is putting the financial touches to a funding package for the Belinga iron ore project (15 million tons a year) that was awarded in late 2004 to the China Metallurgical Equipment Importation   Exportation Co. The project, which is due for commissioning in 2009, will call for the construction of a railway (125 miles), dam and port. But the Chinese are also showing a strong interest in another sector in Gabon: the niobium deposit at Mabounie, for which a partnership is taking form at present with investors from Gabon and France. Also in Gabon, the Xuzhou Huasu Group has involved itself in manganese following last year's acquisition of the Ndjole license by its affiliate Ferroalloy Smelting Co.//新華社利伯維爾９月１０日電（記者任亞秋） 中國機械進出口總公司與加蓬政府日前簽訂了貝蘭加鐵礦及配套工程協議。協議包括開發加蓬東北部的貝蘭加鐵礦山，建設經營礦山和運送礦石所需要的電站、鐵路和港口。　　該工程由中國機械進出口總公司牽頭的一批中國企業融資建設。總造價約３０億美元。全部投資將通過礦石銷售收入抵還。　　貝蘭加鐵礦已探明儲量１０億噸。礦石品質好，含磷量低。兩座水電站將建在礦區附近的河道上。擬建設的鐵路東起貝蘭加礦區西至大西洋畔的桑塔克拉拉鎮，全長５６０公裡，將成為加蓬的第二條經濟大動脈。擬建設的深水港位於桑塔克拉拉鎮附近，距首都利伯維爾僅２５公裡。　　貝蘭加鐵礦及配套工程是２１世紀以來，加蓬打造的最大工程，也是中國公司有史以來在加蓬建設的最大項目。整個工程預計用３年時間完成。工程高峰期可為加蓬提供２．５萬個就業機會。

title: Transportation cooperation strategy (Not a project)
description: 'Minister of Transport Alaa Fahmi, currently visiting China, said on August 3rd 2010 that Egypt and China agreed to form a joint working team to crystallize a long-term strategy on cooperation between the two countries'' transport sectors. The Egyptian government has laid out a comprehensive plan to overhaul and upgrade the country''s transport sector, starting with infrastructure up to the complementary and service sectors, Fahmi further said . The government also seeks to upgrade all means of transportation, roads, bridges, and tunnels, and upgrade administration, operation and maintenance systems, he said, noting that his ministry is aiming to benefit from China''s expertise in this field. China''s transport sector has witnessed a giant leap in the past few years, Fahmi said, citing its first high-speed train designed with a maximum running speed of 350 km/h. Fahmi noted that he held talks with Chinese Transport Minister Li Shenglin and Railways Minister Liu Zhijun as well as representatives from major Chinese transport construction and technology companies. He also conferred with officials of China Development Bank (CDB) and China Construction Bank (CCB) over transport projects they can finance in line with agreements signed by Egypt and China.'
recipient_agencies: China Development Bank (CDB), Government Agency; China Construction Bank Corporation (CCB), State-Owned Company

title: Youth Activity Center (Inactive: same as #23)
description: '3月9日，博茨瓦纳青年、体育与文化部新上任常秘马奥瑞萨在我驻博经商参赞马连星的陪同下，视察了到我援博多功能青年活动中心项目工地。听取青年活动中心项目施工单位负责人关于项目情况的汇报后，马连星参赞陪同马奥瑞萨进入施工现场详细查看了施工情况。马奥瑞萨对项目进度及质量非常满意，认为该项目完成后将在丰富博当地青年的文娱生活之余，为青年人提供了一个学习技能的场所，有助于青年人的就业。最后，马奥瑞萨感谢中国政府为博发展提供的帮助和支持。 '

title: Manganese joint venture- duplicate with 851
description: ABIDJAN, Sept. 30 (Xinhua) -- Although Cote d'Ioire is still experiencing internal strife, the country hopes to deepen economic cooperation with China for the benefit of its people, said Laurent Gbagbo, president of Cote d'Ioire.China can use its advanced technology to invest in mining, construction, infrastructure, environmental protection and other sectors of the western African country, he said.'We need to double our efforts to further develop huge potentials in this field,' Gbagbo said on Friday at his residence in Abidjan, in an interview with Xinhua.The president acknowledged that the political crisis following a brief civil war in 2002, triggered by a failed coup to topple Gbagbo, has severely affected economic construction and development of his country, once an example of prosperity and stability in Africa.'We are seeking for solutions to the internal crisis and I hope it will be solved as soon as possible,' Gbagbo said.The former French colony has long been the world's largest producer of cocoa and the fourth largest producer of coffee. But the country now plans to develop its underground resources including manganese, nickel, gold and diamond.A Chinese mining firm is negotiating with Cote d'Ioire's state mining company on a joint venture project to develop manganese in the country, Gbagbo said.'I hope such a cooperation can be carried out in other fields,' he said.Gbagbo is among some 40 African heads of state who have been invited to attend a summit on China-Africa cooperation in early November in Beijing, in which Chinese and African leaders will discuss how to strengthen Sino-African partnership. //State-owned CGM is affiliated with the China Geo-engineering Corporation under the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission, and engages in geological exploration and resource development.CGM's other mining operations include the Augaro-Damiscioba project in Eritrea, the TKC copper project in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a manganese project in Cote D'ivoire, a lead and zinc mine in China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, a gold mine in Shaanxi Province, a copper mine in Yunnan Province and the Gala gold mine in Sichuan Province.

title: Debt cancellation- duplicate with 708
description: ABIDJAN, May 14, 2007 (AFP) -The government of the Iory Coast said Monday that China has written off 40 percent of the debt it was owed by the west African state, during a visit by the Iorian foreign minister to the Asian economic giant.The cancelled debt amounted to some 18 million euros (24.4 million dollars) and Beijing also extended a new 10-million-euro gift to the country, the Iorian foreign ministry said in a statement.The deals were cut by Iorian Foreign Affairs Minister Youssouf Bakayoko during his five-day visit to Beijing, which wrapped up Monday.China also committed millions of euros to the construction of a hospital and rural schools, and granted one million euros in an interest-free loan. Bakayoko also thanked Beijing for 'the priceless support' the Chinese government has given to the peace process in the divided country which reached a new peace deal in March between the government and New Forces rebels designed to reunify the Iory Coast.He also sought more aid to help organize post-war elections expected this year and for reconstruction programmes.Since the beginning of a political crisis in 2002, when the country was split between government and rebel forces after a failed coup against President Laurent Gbagbo, China has given tens of millions of euros for construction work in the political capital Yamoussoukro.Chinese firms built a large parliamentary complex there and funded 72 percent of the 33-million-euro building, while Beijing is also financing a new presidential palace.China is keen to gain access to Africa's massive raw material reserves to help fuel its economy's breakneck growth.Iory Coast is the world's leading cocoa producer, supplying 40 percent of the international supply.

title: (Not project specific) China is trying to lure the country away from Taiwan with a promise of US$6 billion in aid
description: Text of report in English by Taiwanese Central News Agency website [By Rachel Chan] Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) - Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang admitted Thursday that there are some 'unusual signs' in diplomatic relations with Malawi and that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is on 'high alert' following reports that China is trying to lure the country away from Taiwan with a promise of US$6 billion in aid. Speaking to reporters after a swearing-in ceremony for newly appointed Representative to Hungary Stanley Kao and Representative to Jordan Lin Jinn-jong, Huang said that although the US$6 billion is a 'fictional, even astronomical figure, ' the MOFA 'cannot guarantee 100 per cent' that relations between Taiwan and Malawi will not waver. Very few countries can resist such temptation, therefore it is now crucial for Taiwan to keep communicating with the Malawian authorities, he said. Nevertheless, he went on, the government will not raise the stakes for Malawi, as doing so would be 'meaningless.' Noting that the 41 years of diplomatic relationship between Taiwan and Malawi is built up on bilateral cooperation and partnership, the MOFA hopes there will not be any changes and is striving to cement diplomatic ties, Huang added. Source: Central News Agency website, Taipei, in English 1034 gmt 27 Dec 07  (Adds Chinese Foreign Ministry confirmation, paragraphs 5-6) LILONGWE, Jan 14 (Reuters) - Malawi has cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan after 41 years and established links with China, which has become a major economic power in Africa. 'We have decided to switch from Taiwan to mainland China after careful consideration on the benefits that we will be getting from mainland China,' Foreign Affairs Minister Joyce Banda told a press conference in the capital Lilongwe on Monday. She said Lilongwe and Beijing had formalised diplomatic ties effective Dec. 27, 2007. Taiwan's Foreign Ministry said the island would break off ties with Malawi immediately and expressed regret China was continuing to lure its allies with financial incentives. 'It is with regret that the government and leaders of Malawi are unwilling to honour their promises to our government and have succumbed to China's evil forces,' Taiwan's Foreign Ministry said in a statement. China's government and its state-controlled companies have invested billions of dollars in Africa in a bid to tap natural resources for the Asian giant's growing economy and build Beijing's political influence in the developing world. China's Foreign Ministry confirmed on their Web site that they have established ties with Malawi. The deal was signed in Beijing on Dec. 28 The Chinese Foreign Ministry statement was accompanied by a large picture of a beaming Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi shaking hands with a Malawian official. Malawian and Taiwanese media earlier this month said the southern African nation's government cancelled a meeting with Taiwanese officials, raising speculation Lilongwe might end diplomatic relations with the island nation in favour of China. Malawi has been Taiwan's diplomatic ally since 1966. China, which regards the self-ruled democratic island as its own, has tried to isolate Taiwan diplomatically offering financial incentives to its allies. Taiwan's hopes of maintaining relations with the southern Africa nation were dealt a blow recently when the government in Taipei said it could not match a Chinese offer to provide some $6 billion in aid to Malawi, one of Africa's poorest countries. Banda said she did not know how much money China would ultimately donate to Malawi. She said projects funded by Taiwan, including a highway that extends to the border with Zambia, were discussed with China and would not be affected by the change in diplomatic relations. The number of countries that recognise Taiwan has dwindled sharply since the United States, once Taiwan's biggest backer, formally recognised China in the wake of former U.S. President Richard Nixon's 1972 trip to China. The vast majority of the world -- some 170 countries -- recognise China in step with Beijing's 'One China' diplomatic stance. (Additional Reporting by Ben Blanchard in Beijing and Lee Chyen Yee and Richard Dobson in Taipei) (Editing by Phumza Macanda, Paul Simao and Mary Gabriel) MALAWI-TAIWAN/ (UPDATE 3)|LANGEN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|G|RBN|ABN|C|D|E|M|O|U|MTL|GRO|SOF|OIL|AFN|Z|SF|RNA|RNP|DNP|SXNA

title: Infrastructure development- duplicate of 819 and 942
description: China has extended to Kenya a credit of Sh3.2 billion for infrastructure development.Finance minister David Mwiraria said the credit consists of a soft loan for power distribution system and rural telecommunications network modernisation.He said the energy project, which would get Sh1.4 billion, and would cover the entire national grid in the country, with selected lines and sub-stations being modified, and some new lines and sub-stations constructed.The Sh1.8 billion loan for the rural telecommunications development would go towards providing each of the country's district headquarters with a minimum of 2,000 lines.Mwiraria was speaking during the signing of the Kenya Rural Telecommunications Development Project and Kenya Power Distribution System Modernisation and Strengthening Project agreements with China Exim Bank in Nairobi on Monday.Zhao Wenzhang, the Vice-President of China Exim Bank, signed the agreement for China. Also present was Kenya's Information and Communications minister, Mutahi Kagwe.Mwiraria noted that modernisation and strengthening of Kenya's power distribution system, which currently is characterised by a weak network, would be beneficial to the economy.//1月23日，中国进出口银行副行长赵文章与肯尼亚财政部长戴维·姆维拉里亚在内罗毕签署了肯尼亚输变电网改造项目和农村电信网改造项目的优惠贷款协议，协议金额共4亿元人民币，主要用于肯尼亚电力和电信等基础设施建设。该项目标志着中肯两国间的经贸合作关系又上了一个新的台阶。

title: 100-kilometre road (Duplicate)
description: LILONGWE, Apr. 20, 2011 (IPS/GIN) - Driving through MalawiÆs capital, Lilongwe, it is difficult to miss the imposing building under construction in the city centre. It's the countryÆs first five-star hotel, 90 million dollars worth of well-appointed rooms, a state-of-the-art conference centre and 14 opulent presidential suites.The hotel is being built by the Shanghai Construction Company, a Chinese firm, and is one of numerous projects funded in line with a pledge of 260 million dollars of concessionary loans, grant and aid from China to Malawi to support development, including infrastructure.At a ceremony marking the completion of the main building and conference centre, China's ambassador to Malawi, Pan Hejun, said he expects the whole project will be completed by the end of the year.'This will attract more and more foreign tourists to Malawi and enable Malawi to host international conferences such as the AU Summit,' said Hejun.Chinese construction companies have been busy in Malawi. Parliament now operates from a grand new building which was opened in June 2010. That project cost around 41 million dollars.And this month Ambassador Hejun announced China will assist the Malawi government to construct a university of science and technology in the southern district of Thyolo, which, he said, will be ready in just under two years.'The university, which will accommodate more than 3,000 students with advanced facilities, will be one of the best universities in southeastern Africa, and will make great contributions to the national development of Malawi,' said Hejun.Relations growing steadilyChinese construction companies are also building a secondary school in Thyolo, and a 100-kilometre road between the northern districts of Karonga and Chitipa. The Asian nation has also promised to build a China-Africa Friendship School in Lilongwe, establish solar and biogas pilot projects and set up an agricultural technology demonstration centre.ChinaÆs presence in Malawi has been growing steadily since the two countries established diplomatic ties in December 2007, Malawi abandoning its links to Taiwan after 41 years. A memorandum of understanding covering industry, trade and investment was signed between the two countries in May 2008, committing China to help in increasing the productive capacity of Malawi in tobacco, cotton, mining, forestry, fertiliser production and in processing hides and skins.A 2010 report from MalawiÆs Ministry of Trade indicates that the value of trade between Malawi and China has doubled since 2007, reaching 100 million dollars in 2010, rapid growth, though still dwarfed by trade with South Africa, which accounts for just over 40 percent of Malawi's total trade volume of 3.2 billion dollars.MalawiÆs president, Bingu wa Mutharika, has declared himself satisfied with his government's relations with China. In an April speech at the laying of foundations for the planned university of science and technology, Mutharika said the Chinese projects come with 'no strings attached'.'The PeopleÆs Republic of China has demonstrated that they are good friends of Malawi,' said Mutharika.Some problemsThis year alone, Chinese nationals working in Malawi in construction or as traders have featured in a number of unwelcome headlines. In January, police at the international airport caught Zhang Xiang Quian trying to smuggle 3.5 kilogrammes of ivory bangles, curios and necklaces out of the country. The same day, Jennifer Li was arrested when she attempted to bribe police to release Zhang. The two - who both held senior positions with the Shanghai Construction Company - were fined and deported.In February, the owner of the China Superscope Media Company, Ning Naixing, was apprehended at the airport with 1.5 kilogrammes of ivory. Police assert the ivory in both cases originates from elephants poached in Malawi. The Ministry of Tourism issued a statement on Feb. 11 warning against trafficking of ivory.Chinese traders - who have established a firm foothold in the wholesale and retail sectors in Malawi - have also run afoul of the law. Businesswoman Yani Huang was arrested and fined for violating foreign exchange controls in November 2010, when she tried to leave the country with an undeclared $18,350. A few months earlier, another Chinese national was arrested trying to take $144,000 out of the country.Malawi is experiencing acute shortages of foreign exchange, leading to strict controls on the export of hard currency. This complicates life for Chinese traders who want to repatriate profits made in Malawi.Local traders are also anxious over competition from the new arrivals. 'Some are setting up small-scale businesses and competing with indigenous traders. They are making life difficult for us,' Maddy Gawani, a trader who runs a clothes shop in Lilongwe, told IPS. She said there are big Chinese-owned wholesale shops in LilongweÆs Old Town, a cheap area of the capital city.'Many items in the Chinese shops are cheap but not very durable. A lot of people now shop from the Chinese who bring in many things in bulk. We are not happy as local traders,' said Gawani.Relations between the new traders and their clients are sometimes tense as well. Last year, trader Chen Bo Wet was arrested in the lake district of Mangochi after he allegedly forced a woman he suspected of stealing from his shop to undress in the presence of other customers. Nothing was found on the woman, and he was arrested following complaints.Worst fears unrealisedWhen the memorandum of understanding on trade and investment was signed, local groups feared it would have a negative impact on the country.At the time, Mavuto Bamusi, the network coordinator of the Human Rights Consultative Committee (HRCC), which promotes human rights, including economic rights, in Malawi, said the evidence was that Chinese investment had harmed the interest of poor nationals in some countries.'We know that the Chinese usually bring in their own workers when they invest in poor countries and that they have been accused of dumping cheap goods on such countriesÆ markets. Civil society will be quick to raise an alarm if such malpractices happen here,' Bamusi told IPS.But the Malawi Congress of Trade Unions has been keeping a close eye on the situation. MCTU Secretary General Robert Mkwezalamba told IPS that when they first arrived in the country, Chinese construction companies either paid their Malawian workers below the minimum wage or paid them in kind - in the form of clothing, bicycles, maize flour and sugar. In some cases, workers were not provided with protective gear.'They were paying the Malawi workers just about $13 per month when the countryÆs acceptable minimum wage is $20. Some Chinese factories were locking up the workers [in their workplace] overnight,' said Mkwezalamba.But, he said, companies have responded to the MCTU's objections.'We have been asking them to change and they are accepting our demands,' he told IPS. 'We are also happy that the construction companies are transferring advanced skills to local staff.' Document IPRS000020110420e74k0002t

title: Titanium Deal (Not a project)
description: 'A Chinese company has expressed interest in buying titanium from Kenya. Jianchuan Group is interested in buying large quantities of the mineral deposits in the Coast to be mined by Tiomin Resources of Toronto, Canada. The Canadian firm was early this year granted a licence to exploit the mineral in a deal billed as one of the largest single foreign direct investments in Kenya. Representatives of the Chinese firm are in the country to assess the extent to which the company can rely on the Kenyan titanium - a mineral used as a vital component in the manufacture of a variety of products including paints, plastics and electronics. The Chinese company recently signed a memorandum of understanding with Tiomin, declaring its intention to buy the mineral that is found in large quantities in Kwale District. Yesterday, the Chinese company and Tiomin's representatives paid a courtesy call on the minister for Environment and Natural Resources, Mr Kalonzo Musyoka, in his Nairobi office. The minister said the Kenyan Government was keen to assist foreign companies willing to invest in the country. 'There are other minerals in this county. You will find it beneficial if you also take interest in them,' Mr Musyoka told the delegation that is scheduled to visit the mining sites today. Among those in the delegation is vice-director and senior engineer of Jianchuan Group, Qiao Fu-guin, and Tiomin Kenya vice-president and acting chief executive Ben Sassoon.Jianchun Group is a large firm with investments in paints manufacture, electronics, batteries, adhesives and detergents.It is among the many Chinese companies that have expressed keen interest in the Kenyan economy at a time when it is showing solid signs of growth.Others are Aucma Technologies, which recently launched an electronic assembling plant in Nairobi and ZTE Communications, with interest in information technology products and which has strengthened its presence in the country and plans to expand in the region.President Kibaki is currently visiting China, a trip which is widely expected to enhance business relations between the two countries.The Government gave the go-ahead to Tiomin Resources to begin mining after signing an agreement early this year. The signing took place eight years after the Canadian firm declared interest in the mineral.The company has been licensed to mine the mineral for 21 years, in a deal which prompted wide protests from villagers being moved to create room for the venture as well as environmental campaigners.Once the mining starts, the firm is expected to give 2,000 jobs to Kenyans and inject into the economy Sh400 million every year. However, the figures are largely seen as speculative.Indeed, there are disputes about the real value of the mineral deposits with the mining firm being accused of undervaluing it.The Canadian company puts the gross value of the entire Kwale titanium deposits at $1 billion (Sh76 billion) before upgrading it.However, a study by Alternative Approaches to the Mining of Heavy Minerals says that upgrading one of the constituent minerals, rutile, would raise this value to about $1.5 billion (Sh114 billion), besides generating between $2 billion (Sh142 billion) and $3 billion (Sh228 billion) in multiplier benefits.The study, which was commissioned by the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW) in 2001, applied Tiomin's findings in its analysis.An earth scientist, Dr Carey Francis Onyango says that the ore is worth at least Sh200 billion.Some opinion leaders think the venture is a veritable environment disaster in the making while its economic benefits to Kenya are not so clear.However, Kenya is expected to gain in taxes, new job opportunities and royalties.Tiomin Resources Inc, a Toronto-based mining company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange, is expecting to strip-mine for titanium starting in 2008.Scientists from Kenyatta University, in conjunction with non-governmental organisation ActionAid Kenya, produced an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) that raised a number of concerns that a study done for Tiomin itself seemed to have ignored.The land around Kwale is to be strip-mined, exposing mineral deposits up to 30 metres in depth. It is argued that damage will be caused by timbering, construction of roads, a mill, a power-generating plant, power-lines, and waste piles.Hundreds of agricultural families will be displaced and plants, trees, soil, houses, schools, and markets will be destroyed.The mineral deposits are associated with radioactive elements that could harm human health and the environment once exposed to the air.Kenyan scientists are concerned about sulphur dioxide emissions from the combustion of diesel fuels in the mining plants.There is concern over the pressure that the mining will exert on water resources in the area.In a past report, a Tiomin Kenya representative had categorically ruled out engaging in any upgrading of the titanium ores beyond cleaning them for export. To the company, putting up the (smelting and roasting) plants would be uneconomical when the quantity of titanium in Kwale was too small to allow for the realisation of costs. ' 'The controversial titanium mining project in Kwale [Coast Province] has been hit by a new wave of confusion after a Chinese company opted out of an agreement to take control of the project from a Canadian company.Jinchuan Group of China announced it was terminating an agreement to acquire 70 per cent of the project from Canada's Tiomin Resources, just a day before the deal was to be closed.Jinchuan said it was 'not satisfied with the disclosure schedule' presented by Tiomin as it opted out of the deal only two months after agreeing to acquire a controlling stake in Tiomin Kenya Ltd (TKL) and invest 1.8bn [24.9m US dollars] to develop the project.Ironically, the decision came only a day after Tiomin obtained authority from the Kenya government, something that was the last condition before closing of the deal.'We find this decision astonishing, given that the Government of Kenya finally delivered on its material commitments to getting this deal done,' said Tiomin chief executive Robert Jackson in a statement.He accused Jinchuan of using Tiomin to negotiate for supply contracts elsewhere, and said the company would proceed with a shareholders meeting to approve the transaction, regardless of the development.Just two months ago, the companies signed an investment agreement that would have seen Jinchuan assume control of the project, dogged by twists and turns since Tiomin discovered huge deposits of titanium in Kwale.The Chinese company, which is the biggest nickel producer, had committed to finance, develop and operate the venture that has failed to kick off due to controversies and Tiomin's lack of capacity.Soil relationshipConsummation of the deal would have seen Tiomin retain a 30 per cent stake, and cease to inject any further capital to the project. The net cash flow generated would initially have been used to repay project debt, and thereafter net free cash flow was to be re-distributed pro-rata, 70 per cent to Jinchuan and 30 per cent to Tiomin.The decision by Jinchuan to pull out of the agreement now throws the project into a spin and fuels fears that the project will never take off.It could also end a relationship between the two companies, which has existed since 2005, when Jinchuan first got involved with the project after it bought 20 per cent of the mining rights at a cost of 750m shillings [10.4m US dollars].The Kwale project is estimated to hold 14 per cent of the world's titanium deposits, amounting to 3.2 billion tones, which can be extracted in a span of 20 years.'

title: Low Interest Loan for Economic Houses (Duplicate)
description: BDU English Copyright 2003 China Daily Information Company. All rights reserved. China and Angola, despite the long distance between the two countries, have been enjoying good relations especially in the field of economy and trade. The economic cooperation between the Asian and African nations could date back to 1983 when the bilateral diplomatic relationship was established. However, due to the 27-year civil war in Angola, the economic ties have not been fully developed although there were some Chinese companies doing business in Angola before the end of the war in April last year. Since early 1990s, the trade between the two countries began to develop gradually. In 2000, the trade volume reached US$1.876 billion compared with US$150 million in 1995. According to some estimation, the trade volume could stand at US$2 billion this year as the first nine months have seen it reaching US$1.7 billion. In order to accelerate the reconstruction of country after the civil war, the government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos has put forward an 'economic diplomacy' policy to attract foreign investment and technology and further develop trade with other countries. Two projects funded by the Chinese government on rebuilding the telecommunication network in three Angolan provinces and repairing some parts of Angolan railways have been carried out in October and November this year respectively. Besides, the Chinese government also provided Angola with economic aid in terms of grants and interest-free loans to the African country to help the displaced. The 15,000-sq. meter economic houses in Luanda, capital of Angola, built by a Chinese company with US$11 million of interest-free loan from the Chinese government have been deeply welcomed by the Angolan people. After seeing what the Chinese government companies have done in Angola, President dos Santos more than once expressed his hope that more Chinese businessmen would come to Angola to invest, trade and participate in the reconstruction of the country. Angola, a country with rich natural resources such as oil and diamond, needs assistance from other countries including China for rebuilding, dos Santos said. As the trade between China and Angola is complementary, the bilateral economic cooperation will surely come to a new high in the process of reconstructing Angola. Document BDU0000020031124dzbo0000p  align=right>© 2012 Factiva, Inc. All rights reserved.

title: PPIAF - ICT Broadband infrastructure backbone network project (duplicate #23150)
description: On April 16, 2010 Tanzania and the Exim Bank of China signed a concessional loan of 700 million yuan to finance Phase 2 of the Tanzanian National Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Broadband infrastructure Backbone Network Project. The project seeks to support the government's effort to improve Tanzanian communication technology. Tanzanian Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs Mustapha Mkulo and Zhu Hongjie, vice-chairman of the Exim Bank of China, attended the signing ceremony ceremony.     The Tanzanian Minister of Communication, Science and Technology of Tanzania Prof. Makame Mbarawa stated during  meeting in early 2012 that the project was effectively launched on February 1, 2009 and by June,  2010 Phase I was completed with 4,300km of fiber backbone operational. Phase II became effective from August 1, 2010 and to date the construction of 3,000km of fiber backbone and installation of transmission equipment is complete, awaiting Provisional Acceptance Tests (PAT) planned to commence on 1 April, 2012. PPIAF-ID:282

title: Rehabilitation of Antananarivo's streets (Duplicate)
description: Excerpt from report by Malagasy newspaper Madagascar Tribune web site on 26 FebruaryA letter confirming a project partnership between China and Madagascar was signed at the Ministry of Budget, Economy and Finance yesterday. The project, which was designed in November 2002, involves the partial rehabilitation of streets in the [Antananarivo] suburb known as 67 ha. Six sections of road have already been identified for rehabilitation.No information has been made available yet on the financial amount of the project and on when the actual work is due to begin. Studies are currently being conducted.The letter says the studies will be conducted by the Chinese. The equipment and materials needed to implement the project will be provided by the Chinese who will also send engineers and technicians to Madagascar to carry out the rehabilitation work...Source: Madagascar Tribune web site, Antananarivo, in French 26 Feb 03.

title: PPIAF - Electricity portion of the first phase of 2004 two bln loan from Exim Bank of China
description: (PPIAF) Previous description: Oil-backed loan  to repair damaged infrastructure, mainly railway tracks bombed in the country's civil war.  The money will also lay roads and electrify slum areas of the capital, Luanda, and also fund rehabilitation of the water supply systems                                                                                        Updated description: On March 2, 2004 the first Credit Accord with the Eximbank of China was signed for a financial package of two billion US Dollars and meant for the financing of projects of Angola's public investment. The first package was implemented in two different phases, with each taking one billion US Dollars. The first phase involved 27 contracts, corresponding to 50 projects, of which 21 have  been completed. These projects focused on areas of electricity, water, health, education, public works, each of which taking about 20 percent of the total amount released.The second phase included 13 contracts and 52 projects that are underway. These contracts are in the areas of telecommunications, fisheries, health, education and public works.A contract is near approval to complete the second phase. The contract is called EDEL III, plus another two in final stage of negotiation, also in the sector of electricity and waters.The balance at the end of September 2007, according to the Finance Ministry, is of Usd 7.1 million, of which Usd 1.6 million are for the first phase of the financing and Usd 5.4 million for the second phase.The total amount disbursed until the end of September is Usd 932.9 million, being 733.1 million for the first phase and 199.8 for the second phase.As a result of the positive evaluation made by the two parties concerning the first package of two billion US Dollars, a memorandum of understanding was signed on June 20, 2006, between the Angolan Finance Ministry and China's Eximbank, for the granting of a new financing of the same amount.; Contractor Comment: Tied to the loan, is the agreement that the public tenders for the construction and civil engineering contracts will be awarded primarily to Chinese state-owned enterprises approved by the Chinese government. Exim Bank has compiled a list of 3; Political/Resource Considerations: Oil (China was to receive 10,000 barrels of oil per day. Sinopec wins a license for a large oil-production block previously held by Total of France. Sinopec then formed a joint venture to bid on other oilfields in Angola.); Chinese Commitment: USD 200 Million; PPIAF-ID:9
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Kenya seeking oil exploration technical assistance
description: 'Kenya is seeking technical assistance from the Chinese government for oil exploration. The government has also invited Chinese companies to explore possible oil reserves in the country.Chinese companies are known for their success in oil exploration in Sudan. Energy minister Raila Odinga said Kenya has lagged behind its neighbouring countries in exploiting possible oil reserves due to high costs of exploration and drilling of wells. Exploration and development of an oil well is estimated to cost about 240m shillings.Raila was speaking when he met the Chinese ambassador to Kenya, Du Qiwen.[Odinga] We are now also able to share data with the Sudan about our basin and (?this other side). We intend to send some of our experts to go to the Sudan to look at the facilities because there are very modern facilities in Khartoum, which have been set up with the Chinese assistance.'

title: Professional Technical Training (Duplicate of 968)
description: '　应刚果共和国总统萨苏的邀请，国务院总理温家宝于6月19-20日访问了刚果共和国。　　19日下午当地时间15时，温家宝总理的专机抵达布拉柴维尔国际机场，温总理一行在机场受到刚总统萨苏、总理姆武巴和政府各部部长的热烈欢迎。在机场举行了隆重的欢迎仪式，我驻刚果共和国大使馆工作人员、在刚中资机构、援刚医疗队、华人华侨代表也到机场欢迎温总理一行。温总理在萨苏总统的陪同下驱车前往人民宫与萨苏总统会谈。沿途刚果民众手舞鲜花和中刚两国国旗，欢迎温总理到访，表达刚果人民对中国人民的友好情谊。　　温总理在机场发表的书面讲话说：中刚建交42年来，两国关系经受住了时间和国际风云变幻的考验，一直稳步发展。两国人民始终真诚友好，平等相待，互相支持，结下了深厚友谊。近年来，在两国领导人的共同关心和推动下，中刚友好关系焕发出新的活力，各领域的合作成果显著，我们对此感到高兴。我希望这次访问将进一步增进相互了解，扩大经贸合作，推动中刚友好合作关系迈上新的台阶。　　温总理在与萨苏总统会谈时说：我一踏上贵国的土地，就深深感受到刚果人民对中国人民的友好情谊。沿街夹道欢迎的情景十分感人。这种质朴的热情再次表明中刚关系有着坚实的基础。这种基础来源于两国42年来始终真诚相待，在维护国家主权和振兴民族经济的事业中相互支持、相互帮助，结下了浓厚的友谊。正是由于中刚关系日益密切，去年总统阁下提出两国建立战略伙伴关系的建议，中方对此表示赞同。中方从战略高度重视中刚关系的持续发展，愿与刚方共同努力，推动两国在各领域的务实合作。为此，中方希望加强双边政治磋商，探讨政府援助与企业合作并行的合作模式，开展人文交流。为帮助刚果经济、社会发展，中国政府决定再向刚方提供3000万元人民币无偿援助，赠送抗疟药品，援建农业示范中心和乡村学校，提供专业技术人员培训等。　　萨苏总统说：中刚建交42年来，中国一直真诚地帮助刚果，对此，刚果人民永远不会忘记。中国是刚果的伟大朋友。同中国建立战略伙伴关系，是刚果的必然选择，因为两国不仅有传统的友谊，而且在许多重大国际问题上有完全一致的立场。刚方愿继续深化与中国的政治、经济合作，加强双方在联合国等多边机构以及在重大国际和地区问题上协调与配合。　　双方还就非洲形势交换了意见。温总理对萨苏总统担任非盟轮值主席以来，为维护非洲团结和解决地区热点问题所作的积极努力表示赞赏。他说，中方重视加强与非盟的合作。为支持非盟在苏丹达尔富尔的维和行动，中国政府决定向非盟提供１００万美元现汇援助，还将通过双边渠道向达尔富尔地区紧急提供２０００万元人民币人道援助。中方将一如既往地支持非盟加强自身建设，希望非盟在促进地区和平与发展问题上发挥更大的作用。萨苏表示，非洲国家和人民有能力解决自己的问题。非洲感谢中国在解决苏丹达尔富尔等该地区热点问题上发挥的积极作用，希望中国继续关心非洲和平与发展问题。　　会谈后，温总理与萨苏总统共同出席了两国经济技术合作协定等双边经贸合作文件的签字仪式并共同会见了记者。双方还发表了联合公报。　　中国商务部部长薄熙来与刚果负责计划、国土整治、经济一体化和非洲新伙伴计划的国务部长皮埃尔·穆萨签署了《中华人民共和国商务部和刚果共和国计划、国土整治、经济一体化和非洲新伙伴计划部关于两国经贸合作特殊安排的框架协议》，薄熙来部长还与刚外交与法语国家事务国务部长鲁道夫·阿达达签署了《中华人民共和国政府和刚果共和国政府经济技术合作协定》等共7个经贸协议。中国进出口银行行长李若谷与刚经财部长伊索伊卡贝签署了刚果共和国政府和中国进出口银行关于购买新舟60飞机的优惠贷款协议。　　签字仪式后，国务院总理温家宝在布拉柴维尔议会大厦草坪与刚总理姆武巴共同种植了一棵中刚友谊树，然后会见了刚果总理姆武巴。　　温总理说，友谊产生力量，正是由于两国人民有着牢固的友谊，中刚关系才得以不断深入发展。　　温总理指出，经贸关系是两国关系的重要组成部分。中刚经贸合作建立在平等互利基础之上，因而是可持续的，有利于两国经济的发展。中刚在经济上有较强的互补性，合作潜力巨大。中刚在多年的合作中摸索出一些经验，极大地提高了两国经贸合作的水平。中方将鼓励中资公司到刚果投资兴业，要求它们不断提高合作的质量和效益，多从事公益事业，保护好当地的环境，实现互利共赢。　　姆武巴总理说，中国在刚果最困难的时候伸出了援助之手，患难见真情，刚果人民永远将中国人民视为自己最值得信赖的亲兄弟。今天，刚中两国对和平与发展的共同追求使两国关系日益紧密。在刚果，刚中友好已深入人心，两国合作的结晶随处可见。刚方重视刚中关系，将积极采取措施落实双方已签署的各项协议，并欢迎中国企业来刚投资，开展多种形式的合作。　　温总理说，中方赞赏刚果政府坚定奉行一个中国政策，支持中国和平统一大业。目前非洲仍有６个国家同台湾保持所谓“外交关系”，中国与这些国家既无历史纠葛，亦无遗留问题，更未做过任何损害其利益的事情。我们愿意在和平共处五项原则基础上同这些国家建立正常的关系，希望它们尽早认识到发展同中国关系的重要性，回到一个中国的立场上来。　　姆武巴总理重申刚果政府恪守一个中国的原则，反对任何形式的“台独”。希望尚未与中国建交的非洲国家顺应时代潮流，尽快承认一个中国的原则。　　当晚，温总理在下榻的饭店亲切会见了中国驻刚果（布）使馆工作人员、中资机构、医疗队和华侨代表。　　20日上午温总理来到位于布拉柴维尔市区的达朗盖医院。该医院自创立以来，中国医疗队就在这里工作。温总理到达医院时受到刚中两国医务工作者的热烈欢迎。温总理走进病房看望了患者，并会见了中国医疗队员代表和刚果医务人员代表。　　温总理对中国医疗队队员表示慰问。他说，中国医疗队队员远离家乡和亲人，不远万里来到非洲大陆，不畏艰难困苦，忘我奉献，发扬救死扶伤的人道主义精神。你们精湛的医术和高尚的医德，受到了当地人民的赞扬，搭建了中刚人民友谊的桥梁，为中刚友好合作关系做出了积极贡献，为祖国赢得了荣誉。你们不仅是救死扶伤的白衣天使，而且是传播中非友谊、促进中非合作的友好使者。　　温总理强调指出，中国政府高度重视中刚卫生合作。为表示对刚果（布）人民防治疟疾工作的支持，中国政府此次向刚果（布）政府赠送价值２００万元人民币的抗疟药，并将继续向刚果（布）派遣医疗队。最后，温总理在赠送仪式上，向刚果政府赠送了药品，向中国医疗队工作的两个医院赠送了药品和电脑。　　随后，温总理来到布拉柴维尔中学参观，受到该校全体师生的热烈欢迎，学生们用汉语向温总理问候。温家宝总理走进教室与在该校学习汉语的学生进行了亲切交谈，并走上讲台，在黑板上写下了“海内存知己，天涯若比邻”这句中国名言，向同学们认真地进行了讲解。　　温总理表示，中刚教育合作十分活跃，每年都有３０多名刚果（布）留学生在中国学习。在布拉柴学校也曾有中国教师工作过。中国政府愿继续加强两国的教育交流与合作。为支持刚果（布）教育事业的发展，中方将为刚果（布）建设一所乡村学校。　　温总理说，语言是连接友谊的纽带。他希望同学们学好汉语，成为服务于刚果（布）国家和人民的有用之材，成为增进中刚人民了解和友谊的桥梁。　　参观时，温总理还向学校赠送了电脑、书籍和学习用品。　　在圆满结束对刚果共和国的访问之后，温总理于20日上午10时30分乘坐专机离开布拉柴维尔国际机场前往安哥拉。刚果总统萨苏、总理姆武巴以及各部部长等到机场欢送温总理一行。机场上举行了隆重的欢送仪式。中国驻刚果大使馆工作人员、中资机构代表等也到机场欢送温总理一行。'
