title: Kenya to sign oil search deal with China's CNOOC
description: 'NAIROBI, Oct 13 (Reuters) - Kenya said on Thursday it will sign an agreement with China's CNOOC Ltd next month to prospect for oil and gas in six blocks in the north and south of the country.'We hope by mid next month we will be signing a production sharing contract for six blocks with CNOOC of China,' Patrick Nyoike, the permanent secretary in the energy ministry, told Reuters. He said negotiations for the agreement, which began last month, ended positively on Wednesday.Nyoike said the talks with CNOOC Ltd was part of the government's strategy to turn to the Far East for investment. The entry of CNOOC, China's top offshore oil producer, will be the latest of a growing list of foreign firms tapping Kenya's market.Already active is Australia's Woodside Petroleum Ltd. which hopes to drill Kenya's first offshore deepwater well in L-5 block by the second quarter of next year.'They wanted to do it this year but they couldn't get a drilling ship. It has become very difficult to get a ship because of high (oil) prices,' Nyoike told Reuters.He said of the six blocks CNOOC Ltd is considering, one of the offshore blocks, block L-4, near Lamu, had potential gas reserves.'In the 1980s, a well was sunk, about 4,000 meters below ground and they came across gas, in those days nobody was interested in gas,' Nyoike said.'In block 9 which is onshore, the chances are promising geologically, but we don't know what is underground,' Nyoike said, adding that block 9 is also very close to Lamu.He had earlier addressed a meeting of experts preparing the privatisation of state-owned Kenya Electricity Generating Company (KenGen).Nyoike said that power generation through natural gas turbines was the answer to lowering the cost of electricity in Kenya which local businesses say are 4 to 5 times higher than competitors in Egypt and South Africa pay.Kenya depends on hydropower dams for about 70 percent of its power supply. But the government has said it plans to diversify its sources of energy because of the unpredictability of weather.Kenya is a net importer of oil which accounted for 22.5 percent of total imports in the year to June 2005, according to central bank statistics.' 'Chinese giant and Kenyans look to form joint ventureChina National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) is negotiating with the Kenyan government to establish a joint-enture company to explore the Anza basin on the Sudan border.CNOOC is currently studying data following discussions with Nairobi's Ministry of Energy. Two weeks ago, it completed initial talks with the National Oil Company of Kenya (Nock).The Chinese strategy evidently does not fit neatly into Kenya's exploration and production procedure and it is taking time to finalise the proposed special arrangement.However, it is understood joint-enture operations on open acreage may be permitted under a non-exclusive exploration regime agreed between the parties.At stake is primarily the Anza basin, located in the Tertiary rift section where prolific plays have been identified in the Muglad basin farther north in Sudan.Previous exploration there focused on the Lotikipi permit at Elia Springs in the Lochikar sub-basin where the last well was sunk by Shell back in 1993.Nairobi's geologists believe the Kenyan extension of the Muglad basin is underlain by Cretaceous strata and that could spell prospectivity on a par with southern Sudan.Meanwhile, Nairobi's Ministry of Energy has finalised the reduction by half of all its open offshore and onshore blocks, and plans to gazette the new licensing cartography by the end of this month.An Inter-Ministerial Petroleum Advisory Committee (IPAC), chaired by Nock managing director Mary M'Mukindia and stewarded by the Energy Ministry's permanent secretary Patrick Nyoike, is steering the review process in which both the Energy and Finance ministries participate along with the Attorney General's Office and the National Environmental Management Authority.Ministry officials revealed a new licensing round will kick off before the end of this year offering all the new open plays such as Lamu basin blocks L-4 and L-12, some of Kenya's deepest blocks reaching out to the 3000-metre isobar.Also revealed last week was an intention to announce 'ery soon' a comprehensive review of profit oil splits and cost recovery terms before the next licensing round.IPAC has already determined for this fiscal purpose that new depth ranges should stretch from the shallow waters, defined up to 500 metres, then running into the deeper waters until the 1000-metre isobar with incentives for the ultra deep defined beyond that.IPAC has reviewed the existing Petroleum Act and despatched the new code to the Attorney General's Office, which will shortly submit the new Bill to parliament.Kenya's attractive 'no royalties' provision will be retained under the new regime and the government will continue to pay corporation tax on the explorer's behalf out of the company's allocated oil profits.' 'Only late last month, the Kenya government and the visiting Chinese delegation led by Premier Hu Jintao signed an agreement to grant China Offshore Corporation, a Chinese company, the rights to prospect for oil in the country.This presents a major challenge for Kenya, to get the capacity building done in good time. The country needs an enabling legal framework, community goodwill and supporting infrastructure.The existing law, the Mining Act (Cap 306), which commenced application in October 1940, does not reflect the liberal philosophy developed after studying the experiences of the mining nations of Africa after the 1980s. It may need a total review to rid it from the philosophy of state control that prevailed in the 1940s.Specifically, we need to stretch the land-use band to accommodate the increasing mining interests in Kenya.POLICY PLANNERS across a number of sectors need to focus on reforming the current framework governing land use and tenure, the environment, trade, security, infrastructure and services, taxation, importation of skilled labour, repatriation of profits and issues of equitable distribution of benefits between central and local governments.Luckily for Kenya, it can learn from the experiences of the mining industry in other African countries such as Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Zambia and the Democratic Republic of Congo, experiences that have redefined the role of the state.In the 1960s and 1970s, the state had significant, if not full ownership of shares in mining companies in an effort to ensure that earnings from these national assets benefited the nation as a whole. Unfortunately, by the late 1980s, much of the mining industry in Africa was under-performing.This led to a fundamental shift in policy and attitudes, with state ownership declining from 100 per cent to almost complete withdrawal. The previous state enterprises were privatised and nations adopted strategies and legislation favourable to private investors.This is the prospecting climate that attracted Tiomin Inc of Canada, which is mining titanium in Kwale in Kenya's Coast province, as well as a number of other private investors who have shown interest in prospecting for oil along the Coast and the arid and semi-arid north.The Tiomin experience in Kwale should forewarn us of the difficulties ahead in securing land under individual ownership for the purposes of mining. In the case of Tiomin, displaced local communities were to be given alternative land and compensated. But the compensation figures arrived at after the valuation of the land became contentious. Environmental concerns had to be addressed and the necessary impact assessments undertaken.Government licenses had to be issued by the respective ministries. The scenario was optimal for populist local politics. The totality of all these and other requirements and associated protocol resulted in such major delays that the investor had to repeatedly postponed the commencement of the project. This is not healthy for such investments.IT WOULD help if we understood the immense benefits that we stand to reap from a robust mining industry. Our economy can certainly do with the improved revenues, foreign exchange earnings, direct and indirect employment and the transfer and development of technical skills.Host local communities will gain from improved property value employment, support in the development of schools, dams and hospitals and access to physical infrastructure supporting mining activity such as roads, communications, water and power. Mining areas also support the sprouting of urban centres that bring commerce and attract other services.The government must nonetheless take measures to cushion local communities from adverse environmental impacts such as water and atmospheric pollution as well as the adverse social impacts associated with the adulteration of local culture. The sudden increase in population also exerts pressure on the existing infrastructure which may require higher maintenance or rehabilitation.Kenya also needs to learn the lessons of the mining states of Africa in regard to conflicts associated with mineral resources. Nigeria, Liberia and Congo offer good case studies.We must do all we can to promote a climate where our expected mineral wealth will be a boon to our economy and national cohesion, not a source of territorial conflicts.Northern Kenya, for example, has remained underdeveloped for far too long. One hopes that the oil prospecting being done in this region will eventually bear fruits that will be directed towards its development and help bring it into the 21 century.The development of northern Kenya will certainly promote trade with Somalia, Ethiopia and Sudan. Trade and access to trading centres and schools will offer a major boost to our policing efforts in the area. Let any proceeds from oil be dedicated to this broad national cause.BUT ABOVE all, what is needed is good planning and political commitment.It is not in doubt is that there are positive prospects for minerals and mineral oil in Kenya. A major world economy like China does not casually sign agreements for oil prospecting. It is time to mobilise and provide an enabling business environment, a favourable legal framework, prepare forecasts for electricity and other infrastructure needs and prepare our national and local leaders to 'think Kenya' in the event of mineral wealth discoveries our country.Ibrahim N. Mwathane is a consulting surveyor in private practice and a member of the Physical Infrastructure Board of the Kenya Private Sector Alliance.' 'China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC) has returned four out of six exploration blocks in Kenya to the government, according to local press reports. The Chinese state major will only retain onshore Blocks L-2 and 9, according to a report in the Daily Nation newspaper.Quoting the permanent secretary for energy, Patrick Nyoike, the newspaper said CNOOC would return Blocks L-4, 1, 10A and L-3. The official was quoted as saying that the blocks would be awarded soon to other companies and that Kenya had received expressions of interest in exploration back in March from South Korea's SK Corp. -- recently renamed SK Energy -- and CPC of Taiwan.Earlier this year Australia's Woodside Petroleum shelved a planned second offshore exploration well just a few days after revealing that Pomboo-1, its first well in the offshore Lamu Basin, had been unsuccessful. The Pomboo wildcat was the first exploration well in the country for over 20 years (IOD Jan.26,p7). Woodside has a 30% stake in the two blocks together with Spain's Repsol YPF (20%), Global Petroleum (20%) and UK independent Dana Petroleum (30%). '／／中油网消息：中国海洋石油公司与肯尼亚政府就勘探6个印度洋近海石油区块的谈判日前结束，肯尼亚能源部称双方将于11月中旬签署正式的合作勘探与开采合同。　　商业勘探表明，东部非洲沿海的印度洋近海区域有潜在的石油开发价值。肯尼亚邻国坦桑尼亚近年已经在地理构造类似的近海地区发现了天然气田，并投入商业化生产。据了解，中国海洋石油公司此次选定的6个区块中，靠近拉木岛的L-4区块在上世纪80年代初期就 发现过天然气。　　由于资金短缺，肯尼亚和坦桑尼亚都采用合作勘探的形式来吸引外资协助其探明石油储量。一旦探明储量，确定其商业开采价值，勘探公司将优先享有开采权。先期在肯进行勘探的澳大利亚伍德塞德石油公司明年第二季度就将在肯尼亚打第一口深海钻井。

title: Loan to finance various projects duplicate with 725
description: On September 25, 2007, China and Ethiopia signed a $208 million loan agreement to finance new power generation and expand a cement factory. The loan was financed by China's Import Bank and the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia, and was used to expand a cement factory and for power generation, according to Sufian Ahmed, Ethiopia's finance minister. The status of the project is uncertain.

title: Exploration for oil in Mali desert NEEDS CONFIRMATION (Duplicate of 970)
description: BAMAKO, Oct 27 (Reuters) - Chinese state-run oil and gas firm Sinopec Corp (0386.HK) (SNP.N) will start searching for crude in Mali's northern desert under an exploration deal struck with the government, the company said on Wednesday. Encouraged by discoveries in neighbouring countries such as Mauritania and Niger, Sinopec is hoping impoverished Mali will eventually join West Africa's growing club of oil exporters. 'We have good indications in Mali, that's encouraging us to contribute to the development of the sector here,' Sinopec Senior Vice-President Mou Shuling told national radio. Malian officials say that under an agreement signed with Sinopec on Tuesday, the company will take up options to investigate four or five exploration blocs in an area north of the towns of Timbuktu and Gao. Malian President Amadou Toure visited Beijing last year for talks on oil exploration, reflecting growing optimism among Malian officials that a crude discovery will boost the economy of a country rated as one of the poorest in the world.
donor_agency_count: China Petroleum & Chemical Corporation (Sinopec Ltd.), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: China Petroleum & Chemical Corporation (Sinopec Ltd.), State-Owned Company

title: Resettlement of refugees (Duplicate)
description: 'Kenya's coalition cabinet met Thursday for the first time since it was formed a month ago and vowed to address problems left behind by recent nationwide violence. The creation of the 42-member cabinet was key to ending nationwide unrest after President Mwai Kibaki was accused of stealing victory in December polls. A power-sharing arrangement saw opposition chief Raila Odinga appointed as prime minister. The cabinet, in its first collective decision, made food security and restoring security its top priority. 'We must have the drive to succeed in serving our country and Kenyans at large, there is much expectation from the Kenyan people and we must deliver on the promises we made,' Kibaki sad. The cabinet is the largest and mostly costly since the country gained independence from Britain in 1963.The cabinet formed five committees, namely: national security; finance, administration and planning; infrastructure; as well as services and production to help boost stability and growth in the east Africa's most vibrant economy.Kenya is threatened by an acute food shortages which follow months of post-election violence that killed 1,500 people and displaced hundreds of thousands. The cabinet agreed to urgently increase its strategic maize reserves increased from the current four million bags to eight million bags over the next two years. The state-run National Cereals and Produce Board was ordered to three million bags of maize in the next few weeks as a precautionary measure while the government seeks measures of improving agriculture. In addition to shattering Kenya's reputation as a bastion of stability in a region beset by conflicts, the political crisis choked the mainstay tourism and agricultural sectors. The treasury slashed the 2008 growth forecast from 7.0 percent to between 4.5 and 6.0 percent, with independent economists putting it at an average of four percent. The April inflation rate stood at 26.7 percent owing to soaring food and fuel costs. Meanwhile, the Chinese government gave Kenya 200 million shillings (3.2 million dollars) to help resettle hundreds of thousands of villagers who were uprooted from their villages by the political turmoil. This dwarfed a government appeal for 30 billion shillings (492 million dollars, 319 million euros) made by the government. In addition, China gave Kenya an interest-free loan of 500 million shillings (eight million dollars). 'This demonstrates the value your government attaches to the enduring friendship and genuine relations between our two countries and peoples, based on mutual respect,' Kibaki said in a statement. 'Our prayers go to the families of those who lost their lives and those who have suffered injuries or lost their properties and means of livelihood.' The government said 70 percent of about 300,000 displaced people have been settled in or close to their homes.'//中国驻肯尼亚大使馆15日代表中国政府向肯尼亚政府提供总额2000万元人民币的援助，以帮助肯尼亚安置因选举骚乱而无家可归的民众以及重建国家。　　肯尼亚总统姆瓦伊·齐贝吉对中国提供的援助表示感谢。他说，这一善举表明中国十分重视中肯两国政府和人民之间友好、真诚的合作关系。　　齐贝吉说，尤其令他感动的是，中国在自身遭遇特大地震灾害、造成大量人员伤亡的情况下，仍然向肯尼亚伸出援手。他再次代表肯尼亚政府和人民向在四川省汶川县地震中遇难的中国人表示哀悼，向遇难者家属和中国人民表示慰问。　　肯尼亚去年12月底举行大选，选举委员会宣布总统齐贝吉成功连任，但主要反对党“橙色民主运动”指责其舞弊，拒绝接受选举结果。随后，肯尼亚各地爆发大规模骚乱，造成上千人死亡，30多万人无家可归。今年2月底，在安南的调停下，肯政府与“橙色民主运动”签署分权协议。4月，联合政府正式成立。(Note: If you add the grant and loan amounts mentioned in the Factiva articles of Project ID: 1132 an 1133, and convert the amount to CNY, it comes to be close to the 20,000,000 CNY total assistance amount mentioned in the Chinese article.  I was unable to find Chinese articles that differentiated the total amount into grant and loan components.)
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Copper and Cobalt Mining Project (Duplicate of 450 and 441)
description: '〔中港个股〕中国中铁合资开发刚果铜钴矿,项目总投资约29亿美元2008年 4月 23日 星期三 09:01 BJT: 路透上海4月23日电---中国中铁股份有限公司(601390.SS: 行情)(0390.HK: 行情)周三刊登公告称,拟与中国水利水电建设集团公司及刚果国家矿业公司等合资开发刚果铜钴矿,矿业项目投资约需29亿美元.另外,中国中铁和中国水利还将为刚果若干个基础设施项目提供项目融资,首期不超过30亿美元,其中中国中铁需提供融资额的63.2%,年利率为6个月伦敦同业拆借利率(LIBOR)+100个基点,刚果方将以铜钴矿利润来偿还.刚果政府并同意该等建设工程由中国中铁和中国水利承建,有关承建合同另行签署.公司称,公司将成立合资公司,以项目换资源模式投资开发铜钴矿资源.合作各方将成立华刚矿业股份有限公司,注册资本1亿美元.其中中铁透过其子公司共持股43%,中国水利建设透过子公司持股25%,刚果方持股32%.在刚果矿业将铜钴矿采矿权转让予合资公司,并且该项目获得中国政府批准後,中国企业集团将向刚果政府和刚果矿业支付3亿美元入门费,其中中国中铁承担2.21亿美元.中国企业集团将还将向刚果矿业及合资公司提供贷款及融资,其中中国中铁将负责其中的63%,约18.33亿美元.根据合作协议,刚果政府将保证给予中国企业集团不少于1,000万吨的铜及其伴生的钴.根据初步的可行性研究分析,该铜钴矿区的铜储量约680万吨,钴储量约42万吨.根据相关评估报告,相关矿权的评估价值约为19亿美元.中国中铁A股周二收报7.04元人民币;H股收报7.53港元.(完)--发稿 林琦'  '中国中铁(601390)刚果项目出资额减至26.37亿美元: 中国中铁与中国水利水电建设集团公司在刚果民主共和国合资项目所需承担的资本总额，由原来的40.45亿美元急减至26.37亿美元。这次变动，是合资各方重新签署了补充协议的结果。    今年4月22日，中国中铁与中水电及刚果政府签署了《关于刚果民主共和国矿业开发和基础设施建设的合作协议》。根据合作协议，中国中铁的全资附属公司中国中铁（香港）有限公司、 中国中铁华刚矿业股份有限公司及中国中铁资源开发股份有限公司与中水电的全资、控股子公司中国水电建设集团国际工程有限公司、中国水电建设集团港航建设有限公司以及La Sino-Congolaise des Mines（刚果国家矿业总公司）和GILBERT KALAMBA BANIKA先生就成立合资公司华刚矿业股份有限公司一事签订了《设立合资公司协议》。    6月28日，中国中铁与中水电、中国冶金科工集团公司及刚果政府签署了《关于刚果民主共和国矿业开发和基础设施建设的合作协议的补充协议一》。根据合作协议及补充合作协议，中国中铁的全资附属公司中铁香港、中铁华刚及中铁资源与中水国际、中水港航、中冶集团、刚果矿业、GILBERT KALAMBA BANIKA先生及La Societe Immobiliere du Congo（刚果不动产有限责任公司）签署了《设立合资公司协议的补充协议一》。    根据补充合资协议，合资公司的注册资本保持不变，仍为1亿美元，股权结构变更为：中铁香港、中铁资源、中水国际、中水港航、中冶集团、刚果矿业及刚果不动产分别持有合资公司22%，6%， 16%，4%，20%， 20%及12%的股权。    根据补充合资协议，合资公司股份认购价款的出资调整为中铁投资方应以美元现金支付认购价款共计2800万美元，此认购价款占合资公司注册资本的28%。中水投资方应以美元现金支付认购价款共计2000万美元，此认购价款占合资公司注册资本的20%。中冶集团应以美元现金支付认购价款共计2000万美元，此认购价款占合资公司注册资本的20%。刚果投资方应以美元现金支付认购价款共计3200万美元，此认购价款占合资公司注册资本的32%。'    '中国中铁刚果项目投资增至31亿美元:      中国中铁（601390.SH、00390.HK）牵头在刚果设立的合资企业华刚公司股东出现变动，根据今日公告，中冶集团退出，由浙江华友钴业股份有限公司接盘。同时，中国中铁的投资主体将负担的资本由需承担的资本负担总额263，678万美元变更为310，427万美元，增加了17%。中冶集团退出　　根据公告，在由中铁集团牵头成立的华刚矿业股份有限公司注册资本仍为1亿美元，中冶集团退出投资行列，由浙江华友以总计500万美元的对价认购5,000股股份。投资结构更改后，中冶集团原先的20%股权分别由三家中方企业分摊，其中中铁投资方以合共3,300万美元的对价认购33,000股股份，占合资公司股权从28%上升到33%，仍为大股东；中水投资方以合共3,000万美元的对价认购30,000股股份，比例从20%上升至30%；而刚果投资方投资数目不变，仍以3,200万美元的对价认购32,000股股份，占比32%；浙江华友占比5%。　　资料显示，浙江华友为位于浙江省桐乡经济开发区的股份有限公司，经营范围包括生产、销售钴、镍、铜金属及制品，以及金属矿产品进口。　　中铁在解释更换合资伙伴时表示，浙江华友具有铜钴合金产品处理和深加工方面的专业经验和能力，它成为本公司在拟议交易的合作伙伴之后，将在很大程度上有利于拟议交易的顺利进行及合资公司经营活动的开展。　　今年4月，中国中铁首次与刚果签订《关于刚果民主共和国矿业开发和基础设施建设的合作协议》，当时只有中水集团一家中方合资伙伴；在6月再次签订补充协议，中冶集团宣布加入。　　值得注意的是，在这次投资设立合资公司的计划中，各家中国企业还要向刚果公司提供包括贷款、入门费以及向刚果矿业提供贷款等项目在内的其他资本支持。　　其中，中国企业集团要向刚果投资方提供3,200万美元的无担保贷款用于缴纳其对合资公司的出资；如果刚果矿业要将相关矿权转让予合资公司，中国企业集团还要向刚果投资方支付3.5亿美元作为入门费；为了帮助刚果矿业购买设备，中国企业集团应向刚果矿业提供5,000万美元的无担保贷款；此外，中国企业集团应向合资公司提供无担保股东贷款及协助安排融资以进行矿业设施设备建设，而根据专业机构的初步调研，中国企业集团需负责的前述贷款及融资的总额约为29亿美元。　　正是上述各项资本支出的比例都出现变化，中国中铁需承担的资本负担总额由263,678万美元变更为310,427万美元。　　中标两项大单　　中国中铁今日还公布中标沪汉蓉铁路和上海辅助快速路两项大单，共计225,341万元。　　其中，子公司中铁七局集团有限公司中标新建武汉至宜昌铁路HYZQ-2标段施工总承包工程，中标价约为人民币163,030万元，总工期41个月；公司还中标上海辅助快速路（联明路～徐泾中路）道路新建工程JM-3标段，中标价约为人民币62,311万元，计划工期432日历天。　　公告表示，这两项工程中标价合计为人民币225,341万元，约占本公司2007年主营业务收入的1.26%。'

title: New Agreement Facilitates Movement of Chinese Tourists to Mozambique
description: On Thursday, September 6 of 2007, the Chinese Ambassador Tian Guangfend and the Mozambican Tourism Minister Fernando Sumbana signed an agreement declaring Mozambique an official tourist destination for Chinese citizens. Every year, China picks certain countries to officially endorse for its citizens to travel to. This agreement hopes to boost the Mozambican economy and tourism in future years.

title: China to Finance Dam-duplicate with 1164
description: The China Eximbank has agreed to finance construction of the 1,350 MW Mepanda Nkuwa dam on the Zambezi river some 60 km downstream from the Cahora Bassa dam. The project’s cost has been estimated at USD 2 billion.Beijing will also lend around USD 300 million to Mozambique to build a transmission line between the future dam and Maputo. Most of the energy produced by the new facility will be exported to the rest of southern Africa, and particularly South Africa. The funding contracts still remain to be finalized. For that to happen, negotiations between the China Eximbank, Electricidade de Mocambique (EDM) and other would-be customers of the dam that the energy ministry hasn’t identified need to be completed in June.Energy minister Salvador Namburete hopes that all the agreements will be concluded by the end of the year to allow actual construction to begin next April or May after the cyclone season. Mozambique is gambling that the dam will attract industries that require a lot of energy. China’s decision came despite strong protests from defenders of the environment belonging to the NGO Justica Ambiental who travelled to Shanghai in 2007 in the hope of dissuading Chinese promoters of the scheme from proceeding with it. At the time, the ecologists voiced doubts over the physical soundness of the future dam in a region subject to major earth tremors. An initial draft of the scheme was produced by Brazil’s Camargo Correia and its Mozambican partner, Insitec.There is also question of China’s Eximbank financing the construction of the Moamba Major dam on the Nkomati river some 80 km south of Maputo, whose cost has been assessed at USD 300 million, so as to supply water to the capital.62942524|XMLExtract_AEM_605.xmlDocument AEIN000020090613e55r0000o
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Further Chinese Funds for National Stadium Inactive
description: Further Chinese Funds for National Stadium800 words3 March 200903:37 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2009 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMaputo, Mar 03, 2009 (Agencia de Informacao de Mocambique/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Chinese government has pledged a further 2.5 million US dollars to finance work to remove soil from the site where the new Mozambican national stadium is being built.The schedule remains unchanged, that is, that the stadium will be complete before the football World Cup to be held in South Africa, in 2010.To this end, Mozambique and China signed a memorandum of understanding in Maputo on Monday, according to which the money, that had not been initially budgeted, but was shown to be necessary because of the nature of the soil, is to be disbursed in time to complete the work on schedule.The document was signed between Mozambique's Minister of Tourism, Youth and Sports, Fernando Sumbana, and the Chinese Ambassador Tiang Guang Feng.This means that the national stadium, the biggest and most modern sports infrastructure in the country, with a capacity for 42,000 seats, will now cost 60 million US dollars.Paying a visit to the site, in the outer Maputo suburb of Zimpeto, for the first time as Youth and Sports Minister, Sumbana expressed satisfaction with the progress of the work, and with the transfer of know how by the Chinese technical staff.'Here, at the national stadium, we had the opportunity to see that the work is progressing at a satisfactory pace, with the involvement of the knowledge that our Chinese partners are dispensing and also the involvement of the Mozambican multi-sector team, that is fully dedicated to this work', said Sumbana.The technical team on the site said that the construction of the foundations will be completed before the end of this month, and that, of the 850 planned pillars, only 100 are still to be installed.Speaking of his other visits to sports facilities, Sumbana said that the stadium in Pemba, capital of the northern province of Cabo Delgado, is also making good progress, and should be ready for use by 2010As for the 'Mario Esteves Coluna' stadium, in the town of Namaacha, on the border with Swaziland, Sumbana said that only a few details are left to turn it into a true training ground for new Mozambican athletes.Le/bm/pf (372) 10309 GUEBUZA CONDEMNS ASSASSINATION OF GUINEA-BISSAU PRESIDENTMaputo, 3 Mar (AIM) - Mozambican President Armando Guebuza said on Monday that it is 'incomprehensible' that today there are still people who want to change the political order by using illegal and unconstitutional means.He was reacting to the assassination earlier in the day of the President of Guinea-Bissau, Joao Bernardo 'Nino' Vieira, killed at his home by a group of soldiers, in apparent retaliation for the bomb blast that took the life of the Chief of Staff of the armed forces, Gen Tagme Na Waie.Guebuza told reporters that he found both murders repugnant, and completely unacceptable.He called for calm in Guinea-Bissau, and guaranteed that Mozambique, along with the other members of the Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries (CPLP), is following developments there closely.Former President Joaquim Chissano, interviewed by the independent daily 'O Pais', said that he had learnt with deep sorrow of the deaths of Tagme Na Waie and Nino Vieira.'This is very sad for the Guinean people', he said. 'We are in an epoch where conflicts should be solved through dialogue. Guinea-Bissau is a backward country that needs international support so that it can get back onto its feet, and this support will only be possible with stability'.Chissano knows Guinea-Bissau well. He was special envoy to the country of then UN General Secretary Kofi Annan in the run-up to the elections of 2005 which returned Vieira (who had been deposed in a 1998 coup) to power. He recalled that in that period he had worked with both Tagme Na Waie and Vieira to re-establish peace.Chissano said that Tagme Na Waie 'played a fundamental role in the pacification of the country, and in Nino Vieira's return from exile, since he appealed to the armed forces to abstain from politics. It is sad that they have had such a tragic end'.Nonetheless, Chissano did not believe that the murders mean that Guinea-Bissau can be written off as a failed state. 'Work is needed, in this moment of instability, so that Guinea-Bissau becomes viable', he said. 'But we should remember that the country has been stable for the past four and a half years. Now it's up to the people of Guinea-Bissau, to ECOWAS, and to the CPLP to work to restore stability. The prime responsibility lies with the Guinean people. You can't just throw a country away'.

UPDATE 1-INTERVIEW-World Bank upbeat on Mozambique's economyBy Charles Mangwiro572 words25 April 200803:05 AMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2008 Reuters LimitedMAPUTO, April 25 (Reuters) - Mozambique's target of eight percent economic growth this year is realistic despite floods and cyclones which hit the country this year, a World Bank official said.The World Bank's Mozambique director Michael Baxter also said inflation, which stood at 8.4 percent in 2007, could be kept in single digits in 2008.'We believe, and everybody else agrees, the 8 percent growth rate is realistic and achievable despite all the traditional shocks of natural calamities,' he told Reuters in an interview conducted on Thursday.The World Bank is the largest donor to Mozambique, where the economy grew 7.5 percent in 2007. Its role has focused on budget support and reconstruction projects.Huge interest from foreign companies in the country's natural and mineral wealth has put pressure on the government to develop infrastructure and power sources, which could boost regional trade.Growth is largely driven by foreign aid, while the local economy has been slow to develop, especially small- and medium-sized firms that struggle to secure financing.Mozambique was one of the world's poorest nations at the end of a 17-year civil war in 1992, but has had one of the fastest growing economies in southern Africa over the past decade.The former Portuguese colony's government has embarked on reforms to stabilise the economy, which, coupled with Western donor aid and political stability, have boosted economic growth.But most of the country's population of 20 million live in poverty, and depend heavily on subsistence agriculture.RESTRAINING EXPENDITUREBaxter said investment would boost the economy, but fiscal discipline and prudent financial management were essential.'It is possible because the strong growth continues in the large projects and construction while investments are increasing tourism,' said Baxter, who also oversees World Bank operations in Angola, Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe.'Although the challenge is to restrain expenditure and manage the budget.'Mozambique is hungry for foreign investment.The government is eager to upgrade the Cahora Bassa hydro-electric plant, which was built under Portuguese colonial rule in 1960 and then badly neglected during a civil war after independence in 1975.Cahora Bassa has the potential to generate 14,000 megawatts of power, about seven times current capacity, according to the government in Maputo. But getting it to that level will require major investment.China became the sixth largest foreign investor in Mozambique last year while the United States topped the list with $5 billion worth of investment, officials say.Mozambique's Investment Promotion centre (CPI) said China invested $60 million in 11 projects in agriculture, aquaculture, public works and forestry.Turning to the election crisis in Zimbabwe, Baxter said the bank planned to help after results of the disputed March 29 poll were announced.'We are more than ready to assist when those conditions are in place on a larger scale although there is some backlog of issues to clear up,' he said.'For example, how are we going to assure the payment of arrears and guarantees of future payments.'Zimbabweans are suffering from chronic food, fuel and foreign currency shortages, high unemployment and the world's highest inflation rate of 165,000 percent. (Editing by Michael Georgy)MOZAMBIQUE-ECONOMY/WORLDBANK (INTERVIEW, UPDATE 1)|LANGEN|ABN|M|D|SF|AFN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|SXNA

title: Afife Irrigation project [commitment year too early]
description: In 2002 Jun 19, 2002 (Ghanaian Chronicle/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) - THE CHINESE government has donated an amount of $8million (about o56million) to the Dangbe East constituency to build a hospital. They are also going to help in the construction of some portions of the Accra-Kumasi road.This was disclosed in Accra when China's vice Minister for Foreign Affairs in charge of Africa, H.E Yang Wenchang, held bilateral talks with Ghana's deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs, Hon. Alhaji Mustapha Ali Idris.Hon. Ali Idris expressed satisfaction on the excellent bilateral relations between Ghana and China which was established four decades ago and which has been characterised in recent times by the visits of the vice president, Mr Jinn Jintao, in January 1999.He stated that the minister's visit is an illustration of the continued desire of both countries to strengthen their bonds of friendship.He expressed Ghana's appreciation for China's continued financial and technical assistance in the health, agriculture, education and, more recently, the construction sectors.The Afife Irrigation project, the National Theatre in Accra, construction of new housing units at police and military barracks and Dangbe East district hospital and vocational training school at Dansoman are all examples of Chinese projects from which Ghana has benefited.The deputy minister further expressed gratitude to the Chinese government on the cancellation of debts owed to China arising from loans given to Ghana from 1972 to 1998 and also the agreement in principle to provide financial support for the construction of 17.6 kilometre two-way lane and 40.5 kilometre dual carriage portions of the Accra-Kumasi road within three years.Explaining the NEPAD initiative to the vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, the minister said it is about Ghana's efforts to strengthen peace and security with good governance through NEPAD and efforts by the leaders of the sub-region to achieve a meaningful and sustainable development.He commended China for her contribution to Africa's development and hoped that the establishment of the Sino-Africa conference will offer more opportunities for Africa and China to continue to consult in the interest of concerted action aimed at addressing the wide range of issues of mutual concern and deepening the solidarity which is essential for addressing the common challenges presented by globalisation.The Chinese foreign minister on his part said Ghana is one of the sub-saharan countries to welcome China, with the leaders having a very profound relationship between them.He continued that despite the leadership changes, their relationship is still very cordial in the sense that their assistance to Ghana will not change because it is not directed to a particular government but to the people of Ghana.The foreign minister re-assured that the Chinese government is ready to work with the Kufuor administration since Ghana and China are all developing countries.He supported the NEPAD initiative and the preparedness of his government to join in its implementation. He hinted that a certain amount of money has been given to the Ghana government but the amount was however not known.by Linda AkrasiCopyright Ghanaian Chronicle. Distributed by All Africa GlobalMedia(AllAfrica.com)KEYWORD:          Ghana.Document afnws00020020620dy6k000xd

title: Food Aid
description: On December 16, 2002, the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe, Hou Qingru, revealed that 4500 tons of yellow maize was in shipment to help Zimbabwe in a time of drought.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: China Hands over Agrarian Technology Transfer Center to Mozambique
description: MAPUTO, July 9 (Xinhua) -- China on Saturday handed over an agrarian center to Mozambique as part of steps to boost bilateral cooperation.Chinese Ambassador to Mozambique Huangu Songfu delivered to the Mozambican government the Agrarian Technology Transfer Center, Mozambique-China, which is located in Umbeluzi in the district of Boane in the capital Maputo.Mozambican Minister of Science and Technology Venancio Massingue received the center and signed a document to formalize the act.The 6 million U.S dollars project is funded by the Chinese government in cooperation with the Mozambican Ministry of Science and Technology.
verified: Mozambique Ministry of Science and Technology, Government Agency

title: Financing for northern rail extension project
description: >Namibia's network of over 5,000 km of tarred and 27,000 km of gravel roads is generally well maintained, and its rail, harbour and air services are efficiently operated. The economy is therefore largely free from transport bottlenecks. Two agencies hived off from the Ministry of Works, Transport and Communications are responsible for construction and maintenance of the highway network. Road links to Namibia's eastern neighbours have been improved by the construction, mainly funded by donors, of the trans-Kalahari and trans-Caprivi highways. The trans-Kalahari highway, completed in 1998, has greatly reduced the road distance between South Africa's Gauteng region and Walvis Bay, but use of the route has been below expectations owing to logistical problems. The trans-Caprivi road from Rundu to the Botswanan border at Ngoma was completed in 2001, and the construction of a permanent bridge across the Zambezi River to Zambia at Kazungula, due for completion in 2004, will improve the route for trucks, which are presently ferried across. Two shipping lines provide weekly and biweekly direct connections between Walvis Bay and Europe. A regional service sails between Maputo in Mozambique and Luanda in Angola>> >>The TransNamib multimodal transport parastatal, established before independence, was restructured in 1997 into autonomous subsidiaries covering the railways, the country's largest road-haulage fleet, and the national airline, Air Namibia. However, the parastatal has become unprofitable owing to growing competition from private road hauliers, and poor mismanagement, which has led to the need for increasing government subsidies. In 2001 the entire board was sacked and replaced by the members of a presidential commission of inquiry that had completed a critical report earlier that year. The 2,400-km metre-gauge railway network once carried more than 1m tonnes of freight a year. Recent figures have not been published, but traffic is likely to have declined owing to the improved road network. Efforts to revie passenger traffic by upgrading the service have had some success, and in 1998 a Luxury Desert Express between Windhoek and Swakopmund for tourists was launched. In 2001 work began on the northern rail extension project, the first new line for more than 50 years, which aims to improve economic links for Namibia's most populated region. The 260-km line to link Tsumeb to Ondangwa, Oshakati, and Oshikango on the Angolan border will cost N$580m over four years. It is being part-financed by concessional loans from China and Kuwait. >

title: Funding Gas/Oil Exploration On Mauritania's Coast (duplicate)
description: 215 words30 June 2005AFX AsiaAFXASIEnglish(c) 2005, AFX Asia. All rights reserved.BEIJING (XFN-ASIA) - China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC), the country's biggest oil company, has signed an agreement with Australia's Baraka Petroleum Ltd to invest up to 8.6 mln usd in an oil and gas exploration block near the coast of Mauritania, the China Daily reported.CNPC International, an overseas unit of CNPC, will acquire a 65 pct stake in the onshore Block 20 in Mauritania by funding all the exploration costs.Baraka Petroleum is the sole owner of the block. Under the contract, it will have the remaining 35 pct shareholding in the venture.The block, which covers more than 10,000 square kilometers, is considered the most promising onshore part of the Mauritanian Coastal Basin, the paper said, citing a statement from Baraka.Under the terms of the contract, CNPC International will fund a seismic survey of the Herron prospect and will 'substantially' fund the drilling of the planned Herron-1 exploration well.Baraka expects the joint venture to drill an exploration well in the second quarter of next year, the paper said.The agreement is still subject to the approval of the Mauritanian authorities.(1 usd = 8.3 yuan)bjburo@xinhuafinance.comamj/dkMMMMDocument AFXASI0020050630e16u00233

title: N$30,000 to Ongwediva (Duplicate)
description: >ONGWEDIVA, May 14, 2004 (New Era/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -->> >>The Ongwediva Town Council inaugurated its N$ 7-million dollar double storey administration and council chambers building on Monday.>> >>Speaking at the inauguration, the Mayor of Ongwediva, Erastus Uutoni, said the multi-million dollar public asset is a clear testimony of the combined efforts of his council and all stakeholders towards economic emancipation, since 'capital investment in infrastructure development is a key ingredient for economic growth'.>> >>Uutoni said the building serves, partly, to attract major capital investments in the housing, service and industrial sectors of the town's economy, as investors look at infrastructure before investing.>> >>The town's council building is part of Ongwediva's 'clear and decisive' strategic plan for 2002 to 2007, which acts as a guide for development at the town, and to work out strategies in creating sustainable urban development that is in line with Namibia's Vision 2030, the mayor said.>> >>Uutoni however emphasised that the multi-million dollar building was built with the money of Ongwediva residents and not with borrowed money, as some critics claim.>> >>The guest speaker at the inauguration, Minister of Regional, Local Government and Housing, Joel Kaapanda, congratulated the council for being efficient in the management of its resources, and not falling into financial crises like some town councils around the country.>> >>Kaapanda also praised Ongwediva Town Council for showing interest and having a vision in bringing about development for its residents.>> >>The minister hopes that those elected will continue to work as hard and keep up the spirit of Ongwediva as one of the best towns in the country.>> >>The managing director of China Jiangsu International Namibia, Wang Yun, whose company constructed the building, donated N$ 30 000 to the town council, which is to be used for development activities at the town.>> >>Speaking through a translator, Yun said his company had trained many Namibians in the construction industry and had also created a lot of jobs for many Namibians.>> >>Without the good relationship between China and Namibia, this would not have been possible, Yun said, thanking the presidents of both countries for their good leadership. >

title: Port in Lamu- duplicate with 1286
description: 'Excerpt from report by state-owned KBC (Kenya Broadcasting Corporation) Radio on 1 MayKenya and China have today agreed to prioritize the construction of the Lamu Port as a key pillar project and Kenya's Vision 2030.In this regard it was agreed that appropriate modalities on financing arrangements be met to avoid any financial gaps due to the huge financial resources that would be required.During bilateral talks between President Mwai Kibaki and China's President Hu Jintao, the two leaders were in agreement that the port had a potential to open up vast parts of northern Kenya and benefit regional economies of Southern Sudan and Ethiopia.Today's announcement means that Kenya has edged closer to the development of the second port at Lamu.The Kenya government has already commissioned viability studies on the port's accompanying infrastructure which include a railway line from Lamu.The bilateral talks were a climax to President Kibaki's state visit to China that includes attending of the Shanghai World Expo that opened its doors yesterday.At the talks, President Hu Jintao announced the extension of 1.2bn-shilling grant towards Kenya's development projects. The Chinese president termed President Kibaki a true and old friend of China and had really defined relations between the two countries giving impetus to overall China/Africa relations.President Jintao said President Kibaki's leadership had set Kenya on the growth path to drive the economies of countries of east and central Africa region.President Kibaki said China had proved to be a genuine development partner and critical ally in Kenya's economic revial that has led to major infrastructural development in the country.During the talks, President Kibaki noted with appreciation that China remained one of the leading bilateral donors to Kenya with an accumulative official development assistance totalling 42bn shillings.'
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: China Begins Prospecting [not a project]
description: China's foreign minister embarked yesterday on his first tour of a year in which he will rack up tens of thousands of air miles in pursuit of increasingly scarce natural resources to fuel the world's fastest growing large economy. Oer the next 10 days, Li Zhaoxing will regale leaders of six African nations with his wit and even perhaps his poetry as he seeks to consolidate relations on a continent where China's interests have become crucial to its economic might. Beijing has also quietly revied the notion of Third-World solidarity that dictated its support in the 1960s and 1970s for newly independent states and liberation movements across the continent. But rather than competing for influence against old Cold War foes, China is now competing with western businessmen for supply contracts, mineral sources and energy ventures to feed the voracious appetite of an economy growing at 10 per cent a year. Only last week, China's top offshore oil producer, CNOOC, agreed to pay $2.3 billion U.S. for a stake in a Nigerian oil and gas field -- its largest overseas acquisition. In Nigeria, Mr. Li will sign a memorandum of understanding on further economic co-operation. He will also visit Cape Verde, Senegal, Mali, Liberia and Libya. Western rivals accuse China of doing deals with some thoroughly unsavoury regimes in its quest for natural resources. Chinese officials counter that Beijing's long-held policy is not to interfere in the affairs of others. It is a policy that has allowed China go to places such as Sudan, Myanmar and North Korea that are off-limits to many western powers. Beijing notably rolled out the red carpet for President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe last year. Kong Quan, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said: 'China has always been opposed to some countries, people and organizations labelling other countries in this or that way.' China now obtains about 28 per cent of its oil imports from Africa -- mainly Angola, Sudan and Congo. Chinese companies have snapped up offshore blocks in Angola, built pipelines in Sudan and have begun prospecting in Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Chad. Chinese interests are not limited to energy. One of the biggest Chinese mining operations on the continent is the Chambishi copper mine in Zambia. In South Africa, China-controlled ASA Metals Ltd. said last week that it wanted to triple output of ferrochrome -- an alloy used in stainless steel to deter corrosion -- by 2008. And Chinese investors are seeking nickel deposits in such fragile nations as Burundi. Chinese-funded enterprises in Africa increased by 77 in 2004 to 715. The new companies invested $135 million with plans for investment of $432 million, a Chinese official said. Trade has soared. Two-way trade leapt 39 per cent in the first 10 months of last year. Exports totalled $15.2 billion, while imports reached $16.9 billion. Between 2002 and 2003, trade soared by 50 per cent to $18.5 billion -- the fastest growth China has seen with any region. Some African businessmen complain that China is flooding the continent with cheap goods and putting domestic manufacturers out of business. To counter such criticisms, China ensures that its investments are accompanied by medical and other humanitarian aid, scholarships and generous construction projects. Third-World Solidarity. Tripling the Gap: China's trade surplus soars, page D1Colour Photo: Reuters / The Palace of Culture in the Iory Coast capital of Abidjan was built by the Chinese, who blazed a diplomatic trail across Africa in the 1960s and 1970s, offering support to newly independent states and throwing their weight behind liberation movements and the fight against apartheid. Today, with its expanding economy ever more thirsty for oil and raw materials, Beijing is working to turn that history of diplomatic goodwill into concrete energy and investment deals. Document OTCT000020060112e21c0000z

title: economic and technological cooperation (No project)
description: Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency) ['Chinese, Ethiopian FMs Hold Talks on Bilateral Cooperation' - Xinhua headline] ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 11 (Xinhua) - Chinese Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi and his Ethiopian counterpart Seyoum Mesfin held talks Friday and vowed to boost bilateral cooperation. During their talks, both Yang and Seyoum spoke highly of bilateral friendly cooperation. The two sides agreed to make joint efforts to push forward the all-round cooperative partnership between China and Africa in the following areas: First, to maintain the momentum for high-level contacts, enhance mutual political trust and continue mutual support and coordination on key issues. Ethiopia reaffirms its stance to firmly stick to the one-China policy. Second, to explore and expand economic and trade cooperation. The project of China's Oriental Industrial Park, set up in Ethiopia, shall be completed as soon as possible. Ethiopia welcomes Chinese firms to invest in the country and take part in its telecommunications and infrastructure construction projects. Ethiopia will guarantee the safety of Chinese firms and their staff members. Third, to increase personnel and cultural exchanges and cooperation. China encourages personnel exchanges and will help Ethiopia train more professionals. China will send the third batch of youth volunteers to work in Ethiopia. China will fully implement the aid projects involving a hospital, three rural schools and an agricultural technology demonstration centre. Fourth, to strengthen political consultation between the two foreign ministries so as to keep close coordination and cooperation in both regional and international affairs. The two sides also exchanged views on Sudan's Darfur and Somalia issues. Chinese Foreign Minister Yang stressed China follows closely African hotspots, upholding the policy of solving African armed conflicts through peaceful means as dialogue and consultation. Yang said China would continue to work together with the United Nations, the African Union (AU) and African countries concerned to play a constructive role in solving the above issues at an early date and promoting lasting peace, stability and development of African countries concerned and African continent as a whole. Yang and Seyoum signed an agreement on economic and technological cooperation following the talks. They also answered questions from media. Before his talks with Seyoum, Yang also met with Sufian Ahmed, Ethiopia's minister of finance and economic development, and exchanged views on some cooperative projects. Yang and his entourage arrived here Thursday on the last leg of his four-nation African tour, which also took him to South Africa, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Burundi. Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1752 gmt 11 Jan 08

title: Writing off Zanzibar debt (Duplicate of 1361)
description: China writes off 18 million dollars owed by Zanzibar290 words18 July 2001Agence France-PresseAFPREnglish(Copyright 2001)ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, July 18 (AFP) - China is to write off 18.6 million dollars owed by Zanzibar in an effort to help boost the economy of Tanzania's semi-autonomous off-shore state.The decision was announced during a meeting at State House here between a Chinese delegation and Zanzibar President Amani Karume.Karume said 'the writing-off of this debt is a great relief to our country,' and appealed to other countries to follow the example.Karume said the debt burden was crippling the developing world and had become unbearable.'Our war against poverty is hampered by the debt burden, as the debt has existed since late in the 1960s, when China constructed Zanzibar's sugar and cigarette factories,' Karume said.During the State House discussions, the Chinese delegation also promised to continue support for social projects in the Indian Ocean islands of Zanzibar and Pemba.Meanwhile, Zanzibar Chief Minister Shamsi Vuai Nahodha appealed to donors for financial assistance and pledged that every cent of donor aid would be accounted for by the isles' government.'I know that there are reports of misusing money from donor countries, but the Zanzibar government promises that each single cent from donors will be accounted for,' Nahodha told a Zanzibar House of Representatives' closing debate on this year's budget, which was attended by MPs from the ruling Chama cha Mapinduzi (CCM - Revolutionary Party).Members of parliament from the opposition Civic United Front (CUF) were expelled from the House in April after they refused to take up their seats to protest last October's general elections, which they said were rigged.The House then adjourned and will resume work in October.str/lto/gdDocument afpr000020010718dx7i00bvt

title: Tractors (Duplicate of 1444)
description: 10 October 2001From 2000 to this year, Tanzania has received 230 tractors from various donors, namely Japan, Korea and China. Thirty tractors arrived last year, and 200 were shipped in early this year. Out of these, the government of Japan, 25 by the Korean government has donated 170 tractors and the Chinese have up to this year donated 15 tractors.However, only 24 tractors, slightly less than 10 percent of those imported, have actually been sold to farmers, most of whom think the prices being charged by the Ministry of Agriculture are exorbitant. The Ministry has, however, refused to reveal the actual prices of the various models of tractors received from the three donor nations.It only said that the government had incurred a total cost of Tshs87, 773,000 being transport charges, port fees, unloading, and demonstrations-related costs.However, an assessment by this agency has established that the Ministry was selling a tractor at up to Tshs15, 000,000. Clients complain that this price is too high, and possibly even higher than the price of a similar tractor being sold by a trader dealing in agricultural equipment.The tractors Sold at Tshs15, 000,000, are heavy-duty tractors, which are reported to be very popular with farmers, especially in the southern highlands of Tanzania. This paper also established that the price for the Chines tractors was around Tshs2, 548,000. These tractors are, however, light duty tractors, and many potential purchasers believe they are not powerful enough for their needs.Both individual farmers, and representatives of community-based organizations, have been coming to Dar Es Salaam to check out the tractors contributed by donors, but complain that the prices are prohibitive.They told this paper in Dar Es Salaam that, the price did not reflect the fact that this equipment was provided on a donor basis, and that most farmers would not be able to afford them.On the Korean tractors, The ministry said that the Korean tractors were specifically for the Modern Farm Project in Morogoro Region eastern Tanzania and they had already been sold to the stakeholders in this project.When this paper wanted to know the actual allocation of the 24 tractors sold so far, the ministry said these are the Japanese models and have been sold to buyers in eight regions. According to the ministry, no Chinese tractors have yet been sold, as they are still being assembled.The ministry further said that training and demonstrations have been held in 12 regions at a cost of Tshs21, 000,000. As to why the ministry was selling tractors at an exorbitant price, the ministry said the problem was not the high prices, but the low purchasing power of the farmers.'Farmers are not capable of purchasing the tractors. They do not have enough money to buy them on a cash basis,' the ministry said in its response.Asked whether donors had issued any conditions as to how the tractors should be sold, the ministry said that for the Japanese tractors, Tanzania has been directed to sell them at a price equivalent to two thirds of the total acquisition cost of the tractors. It did not, however, specify the exact purchasing price of these Japanese tractors.On the tractors from China and Korea, it said the agreed rate comprises import price, port charges, transport and loading and unloading-related costs. As to allocation, the ministry said it was according to the demand and orders from the respective regions.The ministry also said that the money from the tractor sales would be put into a special fund to finance agricultural-related training and demonstrations, sponsorship of farming projects and social service programs. It did not elaborate.Despite that agriculture accounts for about half of the national income, is the main source of the country's food, and employs about 80 percent of the population, Tanzania has not yet produced polices designed to develop, and modernize the sector.The sectors is still dominated by small-holder farmers cultivating, on average, farms ranging in size from 0.9 to 3.0 hectares each.About 70 percent of Tanzania's crop area is cultivated by hoe, 20 percent by ox plough, and 10 percent by tractor. It is all rainfed agriculture, and no major irrigation schemes are in operation.Labor and land productivity is currently falling due to poor technology, and dependence on unreliable and irregular weather conditions. Considering that the overall GDP growth target for halving abject poverty by 2010 is in the range of 6-7 percent, experts say that this performance falls short of the needed growth as the agricultural sector is growing too slowly.Tanzania is well endowed with a variety of farming systems with climatic variations and agro-ecological conditions permitting the cultivation of an extremely large variety of crops.by Tomric CorrespondentCopyright TOMRIC News Agency. Distributed by All Africa Global Media(AllAfrica.com)KEYWORD:     Tanzania.Document afnws00020021107dxaa02bu1

title: Water project in Coast Region (Duplicate of 115)
description: China funds massive water project in Coast Region.298 words26 August 200104:19 AMBBC Monitoring Africa - PoliticalBBCAPEnglish(c) 2001 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report by Tanzanian newspaper Sunday Observer web site on 26 AugustAbout 100,000 residents in 21 villages in Chalinze, Coast Region will be supplied with clean water after the completion of a giant water project financed by the Chinese government.The acting Chinese ambassador to Tanzania, Dr Liu Youfa, said yesterday that the project to be completed in 2003, will cost 10bn shillings.He was inspecting the project, accompanied by the minister for foreign affairs and international cooperation, who is also the Chalinze member of parliament, Jakaya Kikwete.Dr Liu said the project was the biggest project to be carried out by his government in Tanzania, after the Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority (TAZARA), which was constructed in 1976.He said the Chalinze project is a further step to solve the critical water problem in the area. The ambassador commended Kikwete, for being aggressive in persuading the Chinese government to implement the project.Dr Liu also appreciated efforts being taken by the government in allocating more money to priority sectors like water, education and agriculture. So far the Chinese government has extended 2.9bn shillings to the project.On his part, Kikwete, commended the Chinese government for what he called `making a dream come true'. 'There was a time I thought this big project was a miracle, but it has happened and now I can retire comfortably,' said the joyful Kikwete.Chalinze constituency does not have tap water and residents cover long distances looking for water. Kikwete said digging of trenches and laying down of pipes in the project, started in May this year. The Tanzania government will donate 400m to the project, he said.Source: Sunday Observer web site, Dar es Salaam in English 26 Aug 01.Document bbcap00020010826dx8q0018h

title: Loan for road construction (duplicate #980)
description: On June 27, 2009, the Director-General of Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA) Zaid Woldegebriel and the Chinese Communication and Construction Company (CCCC) manager signed a deal to construct a new eight-lane asphalt expressway stretching 80 km from Addis Ababa to Adama, Ethiopia's first expressway. It will reduce the transportation time on Ethiopia's main import-export route from three hours to one hour. The project, an estimated total cost of $612 million, will be financed by a $350 million Export-Import Bank of China loan, and the Ethiopian government covering the balance.Construction began in April 2010. According to Samson Wondimu, Communication Director of ERA, construction was more than 30% complete in April 2012. This project has provided the groundwork for the use of innovative technology via tolls and creates local employment opportunities. It is also expected to contribute to the development of roadways between capital and regional locations, such as Hawassa and Bale. Construction is expected to be completed in early 2014. Terms of the loan are uncertain.

title: Chinese firm buys stake in Niger's state telecom company (Duplicate of 122)
description: 'CHINA WINS BID FOR NIGER'S SONITELWith a $16.1m offer, Chinese telecoms firm ZTEhas won the bidding war for a majority stake in Niger's state telecoms company, Sonitel, outbidding its rival bid from the France Telecom and Senegal's Sonatel who offered just $8.86m. Previously, in August, ZTE also won a contract to convert Sonitel's mobile arm to the GSM standard, making it the third mobile operator with a GSM licence along with Telecel and Celtel.The Shenzen-based and state owned ZTE is China'slargest listed telecoms manufacturer and has embarked on an aggressive programme of expansion in developing markets by exporting networking products, establishing joint-entures and investing in local communication operations.'The African market will be our next business hub,' Li Taifong, ZTE chairman said in October last year, highlighting the opportunities as African countries are upgrading their basic telecoms infrastructure. ZTE has established a presence in more than half a dozen African countries including Kenya, Libya, Sudan and Congo. '

title: Establish Chinese language centers
description: On November 8, 2011, The Addis Ababa Confucius Institute (AACI) signed agreement with the Addis Ababa and Hawassa Universities to establish Chinese Language Learning Centers in the two universities in Ethiopia. The signing ceremony has taken place on the premises of the AACI in the presence of members of the visiting Chinese High Level Delegation to Ethiopia from Tianjin Municipal Government, which is led by Xing Yuanmin, the chairperson of Tianjin Municipal Committee of Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), and also officials from the Ethiopian side.The status of the project is uncertain. STAFF_NOTES: This Confucius Institute does not appear to be directly sponsored by the Chinese government. No funding was exchanged between the universities, the Institute, or the government in this project.
donor_agency_count: Confucius Institute, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Confucius Institute, Government Agency

title: Not a project: Nigeria, China discuss planned cooperation in arms manufacturing
description: 'A delegation from the Chinese College of Technology is in Nigeria to explore areas of bilateral cooperation in the manufacturing of military equipment. During talks with Defence Minister Rabiu Musa Kwakwanso, the need for collaboration between the two countries was highlighted towards reviing the activities of the Defence Industry Corporation of Nigeria [DICON].The minister disclosed that the current visit was initiated during an earlier visit to China when he met with and held discussion with Chinese government officials.[Kwakwanso] We discussed quite a number of issues and at the end of the day, it was agreed that the leadership of this company should equally visit us, see DICON visit other areas of interest so that at the end of the day we can come to some form of agreement.The Chinese team, led by the vice-president of Poly Technology, Mr Jan Lyegh, is expected to hold talks with Nigerian service chiefs and other relevant functionaries before visiting the Defence Industry Corporation of Nigeria. DICON was set up in 1964 as a non-autonomous small calibre factory to produce small arms and ammunition to meet the basic requirements of the Nigerian Armed Forces. '

title: e-Government network (Inactive: Duplicate project ID#19626)
description: 12 November 2010 08:21 AMBBC Monitoring Africa BBCAP English (c) 2010 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation. Text of unattributed report entitled 'It has been signed' published on republicoftogo.com web site on 11 NovemberThe minister of economic affairs and finance, Adji Otteh Ayassor, on Thursday [11 November] signed a loan agreement of 25m US dollars with the China Exim Bank. The purpose of the loan is to finance the setting up of an e-Government network in Togo.Fibre optics, equipments and training will be provided by the world telecom giant, Huawei.E-government or electronic administration is characterized by the use of information and communication technologies to improve communication and efficiency between users and administrators or administrators among themselves.This technology allows for better outputs on the part of public services in terms of time limits, quality and productivity.The loan agreement payable over 20 years, has a grace period of five years with a concessional interest of two per cent.In September 2009, the China Exim Bank offered the country a preferential loan of 165m dollars for the renovation of the road network and the modernization of telephone infrastructures.Source: republicoftogo.com website, Lome, in French 11 No 10
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: financing some developmental projects (Duplicate of 1573)
description: 16 February 2011 06:01 AMBBC Monitoring Africa BBCAP English (c) 2011 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation. Text of unattributed report entitled «End of Yang Jiechi's visit' published by Togolese government website republicoftogo.com on 15 FebruaryThe Chinese foreign minister, Yang Jiechi ended his short visit to Togo on Tuesday afternoon [15 February]. Welcomed in the morning by his Togolese counterpart, Elliot Ohin at the Niamtougou [northern Togo] airport, Mr Jiechi then visited Pya [northern Togo] to hold discussions with the head of state, Faure Gnassingbe.He sympathetically laid a wreath on the tomb where Gen Gnassingbe Eyadema is resting. The Chinese foreign minister visited the Kara Teaching Hospital [northern Togo] constructed by China about 20 years ago before signing at the Conference Centre a grant agreement of 50m yuans [approximately 7m dollars] aimed at financing some developmental projects which would be halted by common agreements between the Togolese and Chinese authorities.After a second meeting with the head of state at Kara, an official lunch took place at the Conference Centre. Before leaving Niamtougou, Yang Jiechi commended the quality of cooperation between Togo and China.Source: republicoftogo.com website, Lome, in French 15 Feb 11

title: China pledges aid for Liberian army 'capacity-building' (Inactive: see #1621)
description: On April 14, 2005 the Chinese government pledged 5m yuan to assist with capacity-building of the Liberian army. He Meng, the second secretary at the embassy, said that the money would be given in the form of material and logistics. Technical details, according to the diplomat, would be worked out at a later date.

title: China 'willing' to provide Liberia loan to rebuild infrastructure
description: On August 22, 2006 Chinese Ambassador Lin Songtian the Chinese government was willing to provide a loan to Liberia at an interest rate of two or zero per cent to enable it rebuild its damaged infrastructure. Lin Songtian added that if Liberia wanted to be truly developed it would desire a loan rather than grant. The Chinese ambassador spoke at the start of a ten-day seminar on posts and telecommunications in Monrovia.

title: Poubara Hydropower plant (duplicate #85)
description: The Belinga Iron Ore project in Gabon involves the construction of an iron ore facility, but it also requires power derived from hydropower plants. With China gaining the minerals produced from the iron ore facility, the Chinese have invested in the hydropower plants as well; the plant is named the Poubara Plant. The loan provided to Gabon is a concessional loan, and the hydropower plants will add approximately 6,000 jobs. The entire construction process will be completed in 54 months from the day the construction officially began on November 15, 2008. Duplicate project of #85

title: not a project: $23m loan for telecom project
description: 'Nigeria's mobile industry presents an attractive investment opportunity for many foreign investors given its low penetration rates, which according to BMI forecasts, are expected to reach 13.5% by end 2005.Given such an attractive environment, the China Export Import Bank is to loan US$23mn to Nigeria's leading private telecoms operator Starcomms. Under the terms of the agreement, Zenith Bank will act as partner to China Export Import Bank and serve as an on-lender, while China-based telecoms equipment vendor Huawei Technologies, which is also Starcomms main equipment provider will act as facilitator.The operator, which has over 200,000 users and is currently operational in the capital Lagos and cities of Kano and Maiduguri, will utilise the loan to expand its network to several other urban cities across the country. '

title: China to Construct Hospital (duplicate with ID: 1673)
description: Oct 01, 2007 (The Analyst/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Chinese government through her embassy near Monrovia is expected to construct a 150 bed-room hospital in the southeastern region. Speaking at the signing ceremony of Memorandum of Understanding between the both government at the Foreign Affairs Ministry on Friday, the new Chinese Ambassador to Liberia, Zhou Yuxiao said the hospital will be constructed in the south eastern region but added that the main area of the construction has not yet be identified. Ambassador Yuxiao further said the county of the construction will identify by the technical team that is expected in the shortly from China, adding that the there are some bench mark that will be used to determine the locality of the hospital but he was quick to say that the all will be done by then technical team and through the assistance of the Liberian government. Amb. Yuxiao maintained that the hospital is to provide assistance to the people of that region, noting after the 15 years of brutal civil unrest, every sector of the country is left ruined, including the health sector of the country. 'Liberia needs the assistance of every country in the world that had the financial power to help her get on her feet', he said. He said the construction will be done by a Liberian construction firm while the technical aspect will be carried out by the Chinese experts who will soon be in the country following the final approval of the budget by the Chinese government. 'This construction will is been done several African countries including Liberia.' According to him, China will not allow Liberia to carry her burden alone but expressed willingness to work along with the country to achieve her developmental goals. 'We are one people so we should be in the position to help in every way'. He said Liberia had help China in so many ways but especially at the United Nations, 'so we should in return be able to help in return', he told the ceremony. He stressed that what has been in Liberia by the Chinese government is not enough but is the sign of the good bilateral relations between the two countries. Responding, on behalf on Liberia, Acting Foreign Affairs Minister, William V. S. Bull thanked the Chinese envoy for his country's continuous support to Liberia. Mr. Bull said that one of the main objectives of the Unity Party led government is improving the health sector of the state; the gesture of the Chinese government is highly welcoming. He also stated that building of the hospital in the southeastern region will help reduce the health hazard in that part of the country. He maintained that the construction will also create jobs opportunity for many Liberians, noting that the decision by the envoy to give the construction of the hospital to a Liberian firm is a clear indication of patronizing the Liberalization policy. He however, said that the continuous support of Chinese government to Liberia will ever be remembered by the people of the state. Document AFNWS00020071001e3a1001mt//周大使在采访中表示，中利关系近年来发展顺利，两国政治、经济、文化等领域的交流与合作不断深化，中利关系处于历史最好时期。新的一年里，中方将继续一如既往地推动和深化双方各个领域的互利合作，取长补短，相互支持，积极推动互利互惠的中利友好合作继续向前发展。在谈及一个中国政策时，周大使强调，一个中国原则是中利两国互利合作的基础。事实证明，一个中国政策既有益于中利关系发展，也有利于利战后和平，中方对利坚定奉行一个中国政策表示赞赏。　　关于对利援助，周大使说，作为利真诚朋友，中国积极为利提供力所能及的经济援助。援建SKD体育场、利比里亚大学芬德尔新校区、塔佩塔医院、农业技术示范中心、杜伯曼军营等大型基建项目就是中方诚意的具体体现。中方还积极鼓励援建项目承建商尽可能多地雇佣当地人员，以配合利政府“减贫战略”，促进当地就业。为帮助利实施争取外援和吸引外资“两条腿”走路发展战略，中方鼓励有实力的中国企业来利投资，参与利战后重建，在基础设施、公共工程、通讯等领域发挥中国企业的独特优势，为利战后经济恢复与发展贡献力量。(Note: The hospital that Chinese Media mentions is the Tappita Hospital.  Therefore, I think this planned hospital materialized in the form of Tappita Hospital, Project ID: 1673)

title: Building a Military Barracks (duplicate with ID: 1617)
description: MONROVIA, Feb 6 (Reuters) - Too much Western aid can become an addictive drug for poor African countries and Chinese investment offers an alternative, mutually-beneficial relationship, China's ambassador to Liberia said on Wednesday. Zhou Yuxiao urged other countries to follow China's lead in cancelling debt to Liberia, a once-prosperous West African country struggling to recover from a 1989-2003 civil war. China cancelled its $12 million bilateral debt a year ago. China was also interested in investing in a tax-exempt economic zone being planned by President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf's government to kick-start economic activity. 'Too much aid is not good for a country. It's like drugs ... If you are addicted to it, it becomes bad,' Yuxiao told Reuters in an interview. 'China is calling for win-win cooperation, or mutual beneficial cooperation.' China has pumped billions of dollars into Africa in recent years in search of natural resources for its booming economy. That has unnerved Western donors, who worry that it is ignoring human rights abuses. Since they opened relations in 1977, China has twice broken off diplomatic ties with Liberia -- when President Samuel Doe and his successor, warlord Charles Taylor, recognised Taiwan in return for generous aid and investment. In 2004, China deployed 500 peacekeepers to Liberia, its biggest-ever contribution to a U.N. peacekeeping mission, after an interim government reopened diplomatic ties in 2003, shortly after the end of the war which killed some 200,000 Liberians. DEBT RELIEF President Johnson-Sirleaf, who took office two years ago, has been keen to court China. Chinese President Hu Jintao visited Liberia a year ago and announced the cancellation of Liberia's bilateral debt. 'We are calling on other counties to cancel Liberia's debt. If the debt issue can not be resolved, it will affect Liberia's economic development,' Yuxiao said. Years of political strife, economic mismanagement and corruption have left Liberia with foreign debts of $4.5 billion, most of that to multi-lateral lending institutions. The World Bank said in December Liberia cleared its $400 million debt to the organisation, thanks largely to a loan from the United States. At present, China is helping Liberia build a $3 million military barracks in the centre of country and opening a Chinese teaching centre at the University of Liberia. As in many African countries, the football stadium in the Liberian capital Monrovia was Chinese-built. Liberia, Africa's oldest Republic, was founded by freed American slaves in 1847, and has long been a staunch ally of the United States. U.S. President George W. Bush is due to visit Liberia this month. Yuxiao, a 54-year-old diplomat who had previously worked in Nigeria and South Africa, said China was not hoping to step into America's shoes. 'There is no scramble for Liberia. As you know, Liberia has special relations with America and we have normal relations,' he said. 'We do not compete with America.' (Editing by Daniel Flynn) LIBERIA-CHINA/ (INTERVIEW)|LANGEN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|G|RBN|Z|ABN|D|E|M|AFNDocument LBA0000020080206e426001j4//

title: Fund Food production in Liberia
description: >Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)>>['China Pledges To Fund Food Production in Africa' - Xinhua headline]>>Monrovia, April 23 (Xinhua) - China has earmarked a project to fund the production of food and cash crops in Liberia and other African countries over a 50-year period, a vvisiting Chinese delegation was quoted as saying by local media Wednesday.>>The delegation, headed by Chi Jianxin, CEO of China-Africa Development Fund (CADF), is in the country to explore investment opportunities in the agricultural sector.>>Chi said the fund has the financial capacity and expertise to develop and stabilize the food situation in Liberia 'particularly in rice production and other cash crops.'>>While meeting with Liberia's Agriculture Minister Chris Toe, the Chinese delegation said an increased investment in the agricultural sector would provide more food and jobs for hundreds of Liberians.>>Toe thanked the Chinese delegation for their commitment to revitalize Liberia's agricultural sector.>>He said that rice and cassava production are priorities in Liberia's efforts to reduce poverty.>>'Commercial rice, Cassava, and other cash crops would greatly reduce poverty and enhance the economy,' said Toe.>>The minister listed several investment opportunities in the country that could steadily be looked into for partnership, including food and tree crops, agricultural processing technology and the training of farmers in commercial farming activities.>>Toe praised Chinese government and people for their continued assistance in the agricultural sector, such as the China-Liberia Agricultural Demonstration Centre and bamboo weaving training programme.>>Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 0947 gmt 23 Apr 08>>a813c307>>Document BBCAPP0020080423e44n001xh>

title: Ghanaian teachers being hired to teach in China
description: In 2004, hundreds of Ghanaian teachers left for China for teaching positions. The low literacy rates in the African country, low salaries, and little medical allowance provided an incentive for teachers to leave and move to the highly populated China. It does not appear that this is an aid project, and flows are going from Ghana to China.
