title: China to Finance the National Fibre Optic Backbone Project (duplicate, see 1736)
description: China to Finance the National Fibre Optic Backbone Projectby Joseph Coomson601 words17 May 200608:06 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2006 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedMay 17, 2006 (Ghanaian Chronicle/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --The government of Ghana is sourcing a soft loan from the government of China to ensure adequate fibre optics connectivity throughout the country through the National Fibre Optic Backbone project and contract to that effect would be signed in June, this year.Fibre Optics already exist in the southern portion of the country through Volta River Authority's Voltacom infrastructure, which stretches from Kumasi, Nkawkaw, Accra, Winneba, Cape Coast and to Obuasi.With the agreement in place, the fibre optics will be linked with Kumasi and further to the north. This will then be connected to the SAT 3 in Accra for connectivity into the information world.This was revealed by the deputy minister of communications, Dr. Benjamin Aggrey Ntim, during the start of the tenth information and communication technology exhibition and conference in Accra organized by AITEC West Africa yesterday.He said to facilitate the judicious use of ICT in the country, the ministry of communications has facilitated the drafting of an e-Government Interoperability Framework Policy (e-GIF).'Areas such as interconnectivity, data integration, e-services access and content management will be covered, thus articulating a set of agreed policies and standards to allow electronic information and transactions to operate seamlessly across agencies and jurisdictions,' he added.Speaking on the topic 'e-Government and Knowledge Management', the Director of the Ghana Information and Communications Technology Directorate (GICTeD), the operational arm of the Ministry of Communications, said the e-government project has reached the stage where laws are being formulated to monitor the sector called e-legislation.E-government is a form of e-business in governance and refers to the processes and structures pertinent to the delivery of electronic services to the public (citizens and businesses), collaborating with business partners and conducting electronic transactions within an organizational entity.The Director, Mr. Kojo Anyane-Yeboa, said the strategic objective of e-governance is to support and simplify governance for all parties; government (G2G), citizens (G2C), and businesses (G2B). The use of ICTs can connect all three parties and support processes and activities.In other words, in e-governance electronic means to support and stimulate good governance, therefore the objectives of e-governance are similar to the objectives of good governance.Good governance can be seen as an exercise of economic, political, and administrative authority to better manage affairs of a country at all levels.A distinction can be made between the objectives for internally focused processes (operations) and objectives for externally focused services of an e-government environment. He said the external objective of e-government is to fulfill the public's needs and expectations satisfactory on the front-office side, by simplifying the interaction with various online services. The use of ICT in government operations facilitates speedy, transparent, accountable, efficient and effective interaction with the public, citizens, business and other agencies.He said the internal objective of e-government in government operations is to facilitate a speedy, transparent, accountable, efficient and effective process for performing government administration activities.Significant cost savings (per transaction) in government operations can be the result.Ghana has embarked on an e-government journey that is expected to go on endlessly. Initiatives currently being undertaken by the Ministry of Communications include the creation of: an interoperability framework, e-legislation, community information centres, a national fibre optic backbone, a government network, a government portal, and a data centre.He said Ghana expects a 25% tele-density rate by 2010 from 15% in 2005.Document AFNWS00020060517e25h000sk

title: Chinese write-off of Ghanaian debt
description: In 2006, the Chinese government agreed to write off The relationship between China and Ghana isn't new; the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1960. Oer this time, China has assisted Ghana in the construction of the National theater, the Afefi irrigation project, the Dangme East District Hospital and the Ofankor-Nsawam stretch of the Accra-Kumasi Road. Other projects are in the pipeline. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>The Chinese government has also written off most of Ghana's debt to it, to the tune of over CNY100 million ($12.8 million). …5008Document AER0000020061208e2c8000j中国政府免除加纳国家剧院债务2007-05-22 01:26  文章来源：加纳使馆经商参处文章类型：编译  内容分类：新闻  加纳时报5月20日报道， 中国政府免除加纳国家剧院上世纪90年代早期的建设费用，同时还免除了加纳其它一些建设项目的债务。  中国驻加纳使馆周三声明，中国政府向加纳政府提供了200万美元的无偿援助对加纳国家剧院进行了维修。维修工作采用了新材料和新设备，在加纳独立50周年大庆前完成。  声明说，加纳国家剧院是中加友谊的象征，是中国政府给加纳人民的礼物。中国全国政协主席贾庆林主席上个月访问了加纳并会见了加纳总统库福尔，签订了6个双边协议。协议之一是中国政府免除了加纳政府于2005年底到期的部分债务，包括加纳国家剧院上世纪90年代早期的建设费用以及其它一些建设项目的费用。  加纳国家剧院在加强中加两国人民友谊方面发挥了很大作用。随着时间的流逝，加纳国家剧院的一些设施和功能已经不能满足时代的需要，中国政府出资对加纳国家剧院进行了维修改造。加纳国家剧院维修工程恰好在加纳独立50周年大庆前夕完成，维修工程大量使用了新材料、新技术，同时安装了许多新的设备。  随着国家剧院维修工程的完成，中加两国人民的友谊得到了进一步的加强。

title: Ghanaian-Chinese joint venture company to produce power
description: In 2007, China agreed to partner with Ghana to produce, in two phases, up to 600 megawatts of power by the end of 2008. It is unclear what the status of the project is because there is little information to go on. It appears that the China-Africa Development Fund funded the construction of a project in Ghana, a 560 megawatt power plant. That project is currently under construction, but it may not be the same project.

title: Trade Partnership (Not a Project)
description: Country and China to Have 'Special' Trade Partnershipby Joseph Mwamunyange336 words6 June 200703:01 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2007 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedNairobi, Jun 06, 2007 (East African/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --Tanzania and China will form a preferential economic partnership to promote trade between the two countries.Recently, China allowed 442 commodities from Africa to be sold in the country.Tanzania's Minister for Industry, Trade and Marketing, Basil Mramba, said Tanzania will fully exploit the fact that it had signed business contracts with China to sell agricultural produce, minerals and livestock products.Mr Mramba was speaking in Dar es Salaam when he received an eight-member Chinese delegation led by country's deputy minister for Commerce, Huang Hai, who called on him.The Chinese delegation is in Tanzania following an invitation by the government during the last Sino-Africa meeting in China.Mr Huang said that his government was working towards enhancing its long-term bilateral relationship with Tanzania and that the investment opportunities in the latter are a big boost to the growth of trade between the two countries.He said both China and Tanzania had much to benefit from one another, and the wide coverage of Tanzania's wildlife sector by the Chinese mass media had highlighted the country's various national parks leading to an increase in Chinese tourists visiting the country.The current Tanzania-China economic co-operation is a spin-off of what existed in the 1970s under Mao Tse Tung, when China helped to finance and build the 1,806km joint Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority railway line, which runs from the port of Dar es Salaam to New Kapiri Mposhi in Zambia. China also built the Friendship Textile Mills (Urafiki Textile Mills) which produces fabrics for local consumption as well as export. The only colliery in the country, the Kiwira Coal Mine - now partly privatised - was also borne of this friendship. Later the coal mine started producing electricity, which was connected to the national grid.Electricity from the mine has also benefited the neighbouring districts of Malawi.Document AFNWS00020070606e3660002u
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: Preferential tariff treatment
description: In 2006, Rwanda was admitted to preferential tariff treatment program, which allows certain goods from the country to enter China at zero tariff and in unlimited quantities. According to a 2010 source, the zero-tariff treatment is for over 440 export items, many of which are primary raw materials. It appears that the zero-tariff program is still in effect. The amount is unknown.  STAFF_NOTES: Preferential tariff agreements are not counted as official or unofficial development finance, and so this record has been deactivated.
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: Inactive: before 2000, Wheat Donation
description: 'Ag Export: Morocco to import 5,100 tns Chinese soft wheat soon London, Aug. 16 (BridgeNews) - Morocco will import 5,100 tonnes of soft wheat from China soon as the result of a 1999 agreement between the two countries which calls for the Chinese government to provide the wheat as a donation, the Moroccan state grains board, ONICL, said Thursday. It gave no specifics about shipment dates but has launched a tender to select an importer. ONICL said it will sell the wheat to millers at market prices. ( Story .15656 ) (C) Copyright 2001 FWN The bridge.com ID for this story is BVGHTRW The Bridge ID for this story is 02740 '摩洛哥将很快进口5，100吨中国软麦伦敦8月16日电：周四，摩洛哥的国家谷物委员会ONICL称，摩洛哥将很快从中国进口5，100吨软麦，以作为两国在1999年达成一些的结果，该协议要求中国政府提供小麦作为捐赠。ONICL没有提供船期的具体细节，但是已经发起招标，来选择一家进口商。ONICL称将以市场价格把这批小麦出售给加工厂。

title: Concessionary loan for the implementation of a communication system
description: China and Ghana have signed six agreements, among them is the cancellation of 126m dollars out of the total debt owed her by Ghana. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>Others are a framework on the provision of a concessionary loan of 30m dollars for the implementation of a communication system for the security agencies in Ghana and a 3.8m-dollar agreement on economic and technical cooperation. Deputy minister of finance Prof Djan Baffour and his Chinese counterpart for commerce initialled the agreements as President [John] Kufuor and the chairman of the National Standing Committee of the Chinese People's Political, Consultative Conference, (CPPCC), Jia Qinglin, witnessed. The two countries also exchanged notes on the construction of three basic level schools in some rural communities as well as for the construction of a new office building for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Other projects to be given topmost priority include the national communication backbone network, the construction of the Kumasi Youth Centre and Preliminary Studies in the railway sector. Mr Jia noted that the Bui dam is a project the Chinese government takes seriously. The relevant departments of the two governments have made progress with the signing of a commercial arrangement spelling out modalities for funding of the project. Mr Jia stressed the need for both countries to work harder to implement all other cooperation arrangements for their mutual benefit. To this end a Memorandum of Understanding has been signed between the National Tourism Administration of China and Ghana's Ministry of Tourism and Diasporan relations. Source: Radio Ghana, Accra, in English 0600 gmt 20 Apr 07 a62d7038 Document BBCAP00020070420e34k001p5

title: Railway Agreement
description: On October 30, 2006, the China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation signed a $8.3 billion (was downsized to $8 billion in 2009) deal with Nigeria's Ministry of Transport to build the first phase of a 1,315 km railway from Lagos to Kano. The project was originally proposed in 2002, and was to be financed by a $1 billion soft loans from the Export-Import Bank of China. In 2007, the Chinese loan fell through. The status of the project is uncertain-- the contract may have cancelled.

title: 3 of 4 'Agreements and documents' (INACTIVE)
description: 'Chinese president, Moroccan king discuss Middle East situation.1119 words6 February 200202:40 AMBBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - PoliticalBBCAPPEnglish(c) 2002 The British Broadcasting Corporation [date of publication]. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.The Moroccan king has urged China to play an active role in encouraging all sides in the Middle East conflict to restart peace talks. At a meeting with Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing, the king described the situation in the Middle East as 'sinking into a deadlock'. Jiang said that the key to the problem was the 're-establishment of the legal rights of the Palestinian nation' and that China was willing to work with the Arab nations to help maintain dialogue to resolve the situation. The following is the text of report by Liu Dongkai, entitled: 'Jiang Zemin meets with Morocco's King Mohammed VI' by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Beijing, 5 February: Chairman Jiang Zemin met with Moroccan King Mohammed VI in the Great Hall of the People this afternoon. The leaders exchanged sincere opinions on bilateral relations and major international and regional topics of interest, and reached a broad consensus in a cordial and friendly atmosphere.Jiang Zemin warmly welcomed King Mohammed to China, and expressed his pleasure at once again seeing the King in Beijing. He said: Your excellency is the first Moroccan sovereign to visit China in the 44 years since China and Morocco established diplomatic relations, and I believe that your excellency's visit will become a milestone in Sino-Moroccan relations.Jiang Zemin gave high marks to relations between China and Morocco. He said: The friendship between China and Morocco is deep and long. In their long-term struggle to obtain their independence and be liberated, to protect their national sovereignty and dignity, and to promote world peace and development, the people of both nations have always shown each other sympathy and support. There has been sincere, friendly and mutually beneficial cooperation based on equality on matters involving economic development and construction of the nation. Today, we once more take a look backwards at history, standing here at a strategic height, and take long-term interests as our point of departure. We set the direction for the relations between our two nations in the new century. Jiang Zemin suggested that China and Morocco should continue their joint efforts on the following points:1. Establishing a long-term, stable friendly relationship of cooperation between the two nations for the future.2. Promoting mutually beneficial cooperation.3. Enhancing coordination and discussion to jointly protect the rights and interests of developing nations and protect world peace.Jiang Zemin praised Morocco's long-standing adherence to the viewpoint that there is but one China, and thanked Morocco for its support of China in the area of human rights. Jiang gave an excellent assessment of the Moroccan government and the king's hard work and successes in maintaining political stability, bringing about sustained economic growth and securing the welfare and happiness of the people, and expressed his heartfelt congratulations to Morocco on its continued progress down the road of national construction.When discussing bilateral trade relations, Jiang Zemin stressed that the Chinese government has always placed great emphasis on friendly cooperation with Morocco. He said: In recent years, both sides have enlarged the channels for cooperation on a daily basis, and diversified the forms of cooperation. This has been done to bring about positive social and economic benefits to both sides. China will work hard with Morocco on the basis of equality and mutual benefit to strongly enhance trade cooperation between the two nations, and to bring about common development.King Mohammed expressed his thanks to Jiang Zemin for the invitation to visit China and for the warm welcome he had received after arriving in Beijing. He gave fulsome praise to China's success in reform and opening, and said that in the 10 years since he had last visited China, earthshaking changes have taken place in China.King Mohammed gave a very positive assessment to the relationship between China and Morocco. He said: Relations between China and Morocco have been long and friendly, and the two nations have common viewpoints on many international issues. We have close discussions and interchanges at many international venues, and each has many experiences in economic construction which we can share and exchange. Morocco is willing to work hard with China to enhance bilateral cooperation in all areas, and to promote further development of relations between our nations.King Mohammed gave Jiang Zemin a brief introduction to his views on the Middle East problem. He said: Currently, the Middle East is sinking into a deadlock. I hope that China will play an active role in stimulating all the parties involved to quickly find a resolution, and to break through the deadlock and resume the process of negotiation.Jiang Zemin thanked the king for his summary. He emphasized that the key to the Middle East problem is a reasonable resolution of the Palestinian problem, and re-establishment of the legal rights of the Palestinian nation. Israel must return the occupied Arab territory. The principle of 'land for peace' cannot be dropped. He said that China has always firmly supported and has worked hard for the Arab nations in recovering their lost lands, and has supported the Palestinian people in recovering their legal rights as a nation, and is willing to work with the Arab nations, including Morocco, to maintain normal communications and discussions to continue to play a positive role in promoting an early resolution to the Middle East problem.Jiang Zemin expressed his approval of Morocco's constructive role and unique function as chair of the Jerusalem committee in maintaining the stability of the Middle East for the long term, and promoting the peace process.The two leaders also exchanged opinions on the fight against terrorism, Sino-African relations, the Chinese-African Cooperation Forum, and other international and regional issues.After the talks concluded, Jiang Zemin and King Mohammed VI appeared together at the signing ceremony for the 'Economic and technical cooperation agreement between the People's Republic of China and the Kingdom of Morocco,' and four other agreements and documents.Before the talks, Jiang Zemin formally welcomed King Mohammed VI to China. Attending the welcome ceremony were State Council Vice-Premier Qian Qichen, NPC [National People's Congress] Standing Committee Vice-Chairman Cheng Siwei, CPPCC [Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference] Vice-Chairman Bai Lichen, Jiusan Society 10th Central Committee Vice-Chairman Zhao Weizhi, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tang Jiaxuan, Minister of Health Zhang Wenkang, Chinese Ambassador to Morocco Xiong Zhanqi, Vice Foreign Trade Minister Sun Guangxiang, Assistant Minister of Foreign Affairs Zhou Wenzhong, and a number of related officials from Morocco.Source: Xinhua news agency domestic service, Beijing, in Chinese 1446 gmt 5 Feb 02. '

title: Duplicate: Medical Supplies
description: 'Shanghai. November 12. INTERFAX-CHINA - The Chinese government announced today that it recently shipped anti-bird flu supplies valued at RMB 5 million ($674,399) to Nigeria's agriculture and water resource departments.According to the announcement, China made the donation to the western African country without any political requests attached.The gesture marks the second instance China has offered medical assistance to Nigeria this month. At the beginning of November, the Chinese government donated 529,000 doses of anti-malaria drugs in various forms to the Nigerian health administration.In February this year, Nigeria reported its first human fatality from H5N1 type bird flu infection. By March, outbreaks were reported in more than 130 farms across 11 of the country's 37 states.China has provided Nigeria with medical aid since 2002, which includes insecticide-treated nets and anti-malaria and anti-avian flu medicines. '
donor_agency_count: Agriculture and Water Resources Department of Nigeria, Government Agency
verified: Agriculture and Water Resources Department of Nigeria, Government Agency

title: Yearly Food Aid (Multilateral, not a project)
description: Tanzanian home affairs minister hails bilateral cooperation with Chinaguochunju302 words4 September 200910:53 AMXinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) 2009 Xinhua News AgencyTanzanian home affairs minister hails bilateral cooperation with ChinaDAR ES SALAAM, Sept. 4 (Xinhua) -- Tanzanian Minister of Home Affairs Lawrence Masha on Friday hailed the bilateral cooperation between Tanzania and China and expressed his thankfulness for the donation of hi-tech equipment from China.Masha made the remarks at the Handover Certificate signing ceremony held here with the presence of Chinese Ambassador to Tanzania Liu Xinsheng.The minister noted that the bilateral relation between the two counties will be enhanced and that his ministry will make good use of the donated equipment to improve the service for the society and the people.He added that he expects to find new things when he pays a visit to China's northeastern city of Dalian next week and attends the World Economic Forum annual meeting there, as he had done each time in the past while he was in China.For his part, the Chinese ambassador noted that China and Tanzania hold long-lasting friendship and the donation of the equipment aims to promote the friendship and cooperation between the two countries and their people.The donated equipment from China's Ministry of Public Security include 150 personal computers, 50 notebook computers, 30 scanners and 40 digital cameras, which have total worth of 1.5 million RMB (about 220,000 U.S. dollars).Moreover, China on Wednesday donated food aid to Tanzania through the World Food Program (WFP) in the northeastern region of Arusha, which will assist Tanzania's low-income and food-insecure communities in several regions in the north.China has donated a total of 470,000 dollar-worth food aid to Tanzania in 2009 through the WFP, according to the agreement between the Chinese government and the organization.
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: Improve government IT system
description: In January of 2009, China agreed to grant Senegal 24 million euros to finance improvements to the government's IT system, including creating a national security network designed to facilitate operations between the interior ministry and other agencies. It is unclear exactly how the funds were used, but the project was untied.

title: Niger, China sign agreement worth 5.3 mln dollars (Duplicate of 15226)
description: 'NIAMEY, No. 7 (Xinhua) -- Nigerien and Chinese governments have signed an economic and technical cooperation agreement worth 40 million yuan (around 5.3 million U.S. dollars).The agreement was signed Tuesday by the Nigerien Foreign Affairs and Cooperation Minister Aichatou Mindaoudou and Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Zhai Jun, who is currently visiting Niger.The financial assistance will be used for the construction of two rural schools and the rehabilitation of General Seyni Kountche Stadium, constructed by China in the 1980s.During the signing ceremony, Mindaoudou said 'as in the past, the Chinese government has once again decided to implement part of the measures announced by President Hu Jintao during the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation held in Beijing last year, by undertaking three important projects for the benefits of our country and people.'The Chinese assistant foreign minister said his visit to Niger falls within the framework of strengthening cooperation ties between China and Niger.On Monday, he took part in a foundation laying ceremony for the construction of a second bridge over River Niger in Niamey financed by China. '

title: Construction of railway to Mauritania (Duplicate of 184)
description: In 2007, Sudan's Danfodio Holding and China's Transtech Engineering signed an agreement to construct a 430 km (290 mile) railway connecting Mauritania's capital, Nouakchott, to Bofal, which contains phosphate deposits. The railway will run along Mauritania's southern border with Senegal. The agreement, signed by private Mauritanian investors and Mauritanian Transportation Minister, Ahmed Ould Mohameden, is worth 460 million Euros ($634 million USD). The rail line, according to Mohameden, will allow access to new animal, agricultural, and mineral resources, and it has been proposed to link the railway to an existing network within Senegal, Mali, and Burkina Faso. The project appears to be untied. Eximbank will fund 70% ($686m) of the project, the remaining balance being funded by domestic sources.

title: Financing railway project
description: China Exim Bank to finance railway project in Mauritania 260 words 23 January 2008Xinhua News Agency XNEWS English (c) Copyright 2008 Xinhua News Agency NOUAKCHOTT, Jan. 23 (Xinhua) -- The Export-Import Bank of China (China Exim Bank) has agreed to provide funds for the construction of a major railway line connecting Kaedi in the south to the capital Nouakchott, official sources have said. According to an agreement signed Tuesday by the Mauritanian Transport Minister Mohameden Ould Ahmed and Dai Chun Li, China Exim Bank general manager, the bank will provide 470 million euros (about 686 million U.S. dollars), equivalent to 70 percent of the total cost of the new railroad. The remainder of the cost of the railway line is to be financed by Mauritania's Phosphate Company, which is one the major beneficiaries of the project, according to Mauritanian government sources. Speaking during the signing ceremony, the Mauritanian minister welcomed the signing of the agreement, which according to him underscored the depth of relations between Mauritania and China 'These relations were strengthened recently by the signing of a comprehensive agreement on the planned expansion of the Autonomous Port of Nouakchott,' said the minister. 'This project will facilitate the exploitation of our mineral resources as well as the creation of various development activities in areas crossed by the railway line,' the transport minister said adding that 'this will also ease the movement of people and goods in the country.' According to the minister, the 430 km long railway line, Nouakchott and Kaedi, Mauritania's third city, through Tiguint, Mederdra, R'Kiz, Leguatt, Leeleibatt and Menjem Boffal, is to be constructed in three years time.
donor_agency: Phosphate Company; Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Niger receives $34.8m loan for bridge construction (Duplicate of 135)
description: 'Niger is to receive a 27.3 million euro (US$ 34.8 million) loan from China for the construction of a second bridge over the River Niger, according to Agence France-Presse (AFP). Additionally, in fulfilment of pledges made at last year's Forum on China-Africa Co-operation, Niger and China have signed a US$5.3-million economic and technical co-operation agreement, according to an African Press Agency (APA) report. The money will be used for the construction of two rural schools and rehabilitation of the General Seyni Kountouch stadium. The first, and at present only, Nigerien bridge across the River Niger was built in 1972 with U.S. assistance.Significance: Construction of the new bridge is expected to be completed by mid-2011 and it is hoped that congestion on Niger's first and only bridge across the river will be reduced as a result. The investment is one of China's largest in the sub-region, according to Nigerien Minister for Equipment Lamido Harouna.ChineseNigerien relations have been complicated of late by violence in the north of the country. One Chinese expatriate uranium mining worker was briefly kidnapped by the Tuareg insurgent movement earlier this year. '

title: Oil Block Investment (Duplicate)
description: On June 2, 2008, China National Petroleum Corporation (PetroChina Group) signed an agreement to invest $5 billion in the following three years to develop Niger's Agadem oil block with the Nigerian government. Agadem is the largest oil block in Nigeria. PetroChina Group will also build a plant capable of refining 1 million tons of crude oil/year and 2,000 km of pipeline.

title: $3 billion loan for gas, oil infrastructure- duplicate with 28056
description: In September of 2010, the Ghanaian government signed an agreement with the Chinese Development Bank. The Parliament of Ghana gave its assent to the deal in February of 2012; this necessary legal procedure delayed the initial implementation of the projects. The Bank will provide a loan worth $3 billion USD for oil and gas infrastructure and agricultural development. As repayment, the Ghanaian government will provide 13,000 barrels of crude oil daily for 15 years. Projects to be included under the loan include: the Western Corridor Gas Commercialization project, the establishment of gas-processing plant at Bonyere to use gas discoveries from Jubilee and Sankofa fields for power generation, the construction of gas transmission pipelines from Bonyere to Western region, an industrial minerals processing estate, developing mineral processing industries in the Export Processing Zone in Sekondi, railway line expansions, among others. It is unclear exactly what the current status of each of these projects is, although a recent report indicated the Bonyere processing plant was relocated to Atuabo.

title: Chinese firm said to invest 4bn dollars in projects in Ghana
description: Chinese firm said to invest 4bn dollars in projects in Ghana211 words18 February 201109:48 AMBBC Monitoring AfricaBBCAPEnglish(c) 2011 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of unattributed report by Ghanaian radio station Joy FM owned by the Multimedia Broadcasting Corporation on 18 February[Presenter] A Chinese company in Ghana is to set up factories and all aluminium smelting plants as well as other facilities. The company says it is investing 4bn dollars in the project.Speaking at the launch at the free zones site at Mpintsin near Sekondi [in southwestern Ghana]. Hasan's President, Luke Luang said the project would create jobs for residents.[Luang] There is going to be alumina processing, silicon, magnesium processing, tile processing, factories of ceramic, there is going to be a cement factory as well. So there is going to be a complex of combined industry in there focusing on fully utilizes much resources in Ghana where the end product will be exploited there. We are expecting majority of the job opportunity we are going to open is to be local and part of our responsibility is to train the people locally to be able to carry out the works that needs to be done.[Presenter] Luke Luang is the president of Chinese company, Hassan International Holdings.Source: Joy FM, Accra, in English 0800 gmt 18 Feb 11ad633b5eDocument BBCAP00020110218e72i0025t

title: Construction of the holy town, Touba (duplicate: 1947)
description: Since the resumption of diplomatic ties between China and Senegal in 2005, there has been acceleration of cooperation in all sectors between the two countries.As a friend of China in the 1960s and 1970s, Senegal then benefited a lot from the Chinese support.Senegal's former presidents Leopold Sedar Senghor and Abdou Diouf had facilitated the arrival in Senegal of Chinese investors.The Chinese agricultural and medical missions were highly appreciated in several Senegalese localities because of their expertise.The construction by the Chinese of the 'friendship' stadium in Senegal which later became 'Leopold Sedar Senghor' stadium in 1980s, helped to take this friendship to a higher level.The breaking off of diplomatic relations between the two countries in 1996 created some inconvenience to their people. However, Dakar and Beijing later decided to resume their diplomatic relations in October 2005.In January 2006, the signing of the first agreement after the reopening of the Chinese Embassy in Dakar marked the return of a 'big friend' in Senegal.The two countries have adopted a new model of cooperation which is christened 'the win-win partnership.'REVIVAL OF POLITICAL RELATIONSThe resumption of Sino-Senegalese relations was materialized on the political front through the revial of talks between Beijing and Dakar.The missions, visits and exchanges between the senior authorities in the two countries increased.President Abdoulaye Wade and members of his government made several visits to Beijing. Chinese President Hu Jintao also visited Senegal in February 2009.Several accords were signed between the two governments for the completion of several large scale projects such as the construction of the Grand National Theater, the rehabilitation of the 11 regional stadiums and training of Senegalese farmers.In addition, the Chinese government, through the Import-Export Bank of China, gave Senegal several preferential loans to carry out projects in several sectors such as energy production.CONSTRUCTION OF QUALITY AND MODERN INFRASTRUCTURESituated in the Dakar city center, the Grand National Theater has been an attraction to all passers-by.Constructed by the Chinese through aid from the Chinese government, this cultural building will enable Senegal to have a modern cultural infrastructure.During the official opening of the building in April 2010, Senegalese President Wade said it was a demonstration of the depth of ties between the two countries.China is in the process of revolutionizing Senegalese sports with the construction and rehabilitation of 11 regional stadiums. Two stadiums were already been completed and handed over to Senegal in 2009 while nine others are still under construction.Another example of Sino-Senegalese cooperation is the construction of the holy town of Touba (East) by the Chinese group, Henan China.In the health sector, Senegal's Health Minister Modou Diagne Fada and Chinese Ambassador to Senegal Gong Yuanxing recently laid the foundation stone for the construction of a children's hospital in Diamniadio town, 40 km north of Senegalese capital Dakar.The health minister said that this modern hospital which will have a 130 bed capacity, will cost 70 million yuan.CHINESE SUPPORT FOR SENEGAL'S ENERGY SECTORConfronted by a crisis in the energy sector with frequent power cuts, Senegal has benefited from the Chinese aid to resolve this problem.China will participate in the modernization of Dakar's electricity network. By 2015, the Senegalese capital city will have sufficient energy supply.In 2010, the Senegalese national electricity company (SENELEC) signed two agreements worth 69.1 billion Fcfa with the Chinese electricity company CMEC to improve electricity distribution within Dakar and its environs.DYNAMISM OF BILATERAL COMMERCIAL EXCHANGESA Senegalese newspaper Le Soleil recently reported that China has intensified bilateral commercial exchanges with the country.Chinese products are visible in almost all Senegalese markets and China has now become a destination of choice for Senegalese economic operators.FIGHT AGAINST FOOD INSECURITY AND IMPROVEMENT OF LIVING CONDITIONSOn the agricultural front, Chinese agricultural experts who settled in Senegal in 2006 have helped Senegalese farmers on ways to fight against food insecurity.In the transport sector, China and Senegal signed a cooperation accord on the opening of the Senbus bus park. This accord also envisioned the setting up of a car assembly plant in Senegal.During the same year, theSenegalese authorities announced the arrival of 200 buses assembled in China to help resolve difficulties that were being experienced by the public transport company, 'Dakar dem dikk.'China also helped Senegal in the organization of international meetings. In this regard, China gave Senegal 50 vehicles during the 11th session of the Organization of Islamic Conference (OCI) which was held in Dakar between March 7-14, 2008.The vehicles were handed over to help in the transportation of foreign dignitaries.During the third edition of the Global Negro Festival which was held in Dakar between Dec. 10-31,2010, Senegal received additional 50 vehicles from China.For the past several years,China and Senegal have maintained good momentum in further developing bilateral ties.
donor_agency_count: Henan Guoji, Private Sector
recipient_agencies: Henan Guoji, Private Sector

title: TAZARA - Grant (Duplicate of 1364)

He said the money will also be used to improve the technical department and to improve the status of Tazara.Speaking after the aid was given, the minister of communications and transport, Hon Mark Mwandosya, thanked the Chinese government and added that he believed the assistance would help improve Tazara's operations. The meeting was held today in Dar es Salaam...Source: Radio Tanzania, Dar es Salaam, in Swahili 1300 gmt 19 Jul 01.

title: Preferential Loan for uranium project (Duplicate of 256)
description: 'NIAMEY, April 24 (Reuters) - China has granted Niger a $95 million preferential loan to boost a uranium mining project the two countries have in the West African state, Niger's government said late on Thursday. Niger's government is a 33 percent joint venture partner with the China National Uranium Corporation (SINO-U) in the SOMINA uranium mining operation, due to come on line by 2010, with an annual output of about 700 tonnes. The entry into Niger of Chinese miners and Cameco Corp , the world's top uranium producer that now has a stake in GoviEx, a company with local exploration rights, follows years of dominance by French nuclear group Areva . 'China has agreed to the Export-Import Bank of China granting Niger a preferential loan of 650 million yuan ($95.22 million) with a view to supporting the SOMINA uranium exploration project,' Niger's government said in a statement broadcast on state television late on Thursday. Niger will have to pay 2 percent interest on the loan, which must be paid back within 15 years, a government source said. China has committed to investing some $300 million in the project, which is at Azelik, in the northern Agadez region, where Areva has mining projects but the Niger government has also been battling a two-year uprising by Tuareg rebels. Niger already has two significant uranium mines providing 7.5 percent of global output from Africa's highest-grade uranium ores, according to the World Nuclear Association website. Earlier this year, Areva said it had won a licence to operate the Imouraren mine, which would more than double Niger's uranium output to make it the second largest producer in the world. ($1=6.826 Yuan) (Reporting by Abdoulaye Massalatchi; Writing by David Lewis; Editing by James Jukwey)''

title: Reduction of debt (Not a sepecific project)
description: Beijing, 29 March: Chinese Vice-President Hu Jintao said China and Sudan have maintained good momentum of bilateral relations since the two countries forged diplomatic ties 42 years ago.Hu made the remarks during talks with visiting Sudanese First Vice-President Ali Uthman Muhammad Taha here Thursday [29 March]. He added that Sino-Sudanese relations have withstood the test of time and change, and the two sides have conducted good cooperation in all fields. China appreciates Sudanese government's one-China stance and its support for China's reunification cause, Hu stressed. He also expressed gratitude for the support by Sudanese government towards China on the human rights issue, and said that China is ready to improve the relations with Sudan in the new century. On Sino-Sudanese trade relations, Hu said the trade volume between China and Sudan has increased and the cooperation has expanded in recent years. He particularly mentioned the successful cooperation between the two countries in the petroleum field, and cited it an example of friendly cooperation among the developing countries. Hu said that China is ready to expand areas for bilateral cooperation on the basis of equality, mutual benefit and effectiveness. Taha said the Sudanese government has attached importance to developing relations with China, and thanks China for its support to Sudan's national independence and territorial integrity. He also expressed gratitude for China's economic and technology assistance towards Sudan, and its reduction of debt owned by the African nation. Sudan hopes to further its cooperation with China in all fields especially in the area of petroleum, he added. Taha reaffirmed Sudan's one-China stance, and expressed his appreciation for China's efforts in promoting Sino-African cooperation. Hu Jintao said the international situation tends to ease on the whole, but hegemonism and power politics still exist, thus peace and development face challenges. Globalization is bound to intensify, Hu said, adding that economic globalization promotes the world economy, and will widen the gap between the rich and the poor. The Chinese vice-president urged the developing countries to work together to promote the establishment of a just and reasonable international political and economic order. He said that China is ready to work with Sudan to improve peace and development of mankind. Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1247 gmt 29 Mar 01.

title: (NOT A PROJECT?) China to invest further $3 billion in Nigeria
description: 'The global economic crisis may have forced other nations to put their African investments on hold, but not China.This week, the Nigerian government announced that China would double its current direct investment from a total of $3 billion to $6 billion, most of that in Nigeria's oil sector. Last week, the government of Guinea - where a coup brought a military captain to power last December - announced that a Chinese firm planned to invest $7 billion in oil and mining infrastructure in return for preferential treatment in all mining projects in Guinea.China's increasing investment in Africa has raised concerns among human rights activists and others who warn that Chinese money props up regimes such as those in Zimbabwe, Sudan, and the Democratic Republic of Congo who are either undemocratic, corrupt, or carry out mass-scale human rights crimes, or combinations of the above. Yet many African leaders applaud Chinese investment, saying that they create jobs, infrastructure, and business opportunities in African countries where Western companies fear to tread.'Huge Chinese investment in African companies and infrastructure is helping Africa develop. The Chinese bring what Africa needs: investment and money for governments and companies,' Rwandan President Paul Kagame told reporters for the German business daily Handelsblatt earlier in October. 'European and American involvement has not brought Africa forward,' President Kagame added, complaining of trade barriers erected by the West.China's long-stated policy of non-interference in the domestic affairs of its African partners plays well here in Africa and is a stark contrast to the starchy human-rights focus of many post- colonial European nations and of the United States. While Western nations balk at investing in a country like Zimbabwe, where state security agencies round up, beat, and sometimes kill opposition members and human rights activists, the Chinese are happy to do business. They also sell arms to those regimes.Arms for ZimbabweConsider China's arms deal with Zimbabwe, which went largely unnoticed until June 2008, when South African trade unionists refused to unload a cargo ship carrying the weapons in Durban harbor (Zimbabwe is landlocked). The Chinese ship eventually unloaded the arms in Angola and Zimbabwean planes carried them the rest of the way to Harare.'The Chinese ought to be held accountable for that, whether you'e got an embargo by the UN or not,' says Francis Kornegay, a senior researcher at the Center for Policy Studies in Johannesburg. 'On things like that, the Chinese don't like to be taking the heat, in the limelight, and South Africa ought to be able to get China to agree that nobody should be sending arms to Zimbabwe.'But despite the expected 'tougher stand' of President Jacob Zuma toward Zimbabwe, no African nation has stood up to either the Chinese or the Zimbabwean government. 'There is no leadership on the continent. And China takes advantage of that,' Mr. Kornegay said.China has an advantage over Western countries who keep their government aid and their business interests separate, at least on paper. When a US-based mining company makes an offer to pay for the rights to exploit a mine in, say, the Democratic Republic of Congo, it does so completely on its own. But when a Chinese firm - which is, after all, owned by the Chinese government - bids on the same project, it can also promise significant Chinese government aid for building roads and water systems and electrical projects, a complete package that no Western private company can compete with.The Chinese government is also flush with cash. So while other governments have simply pulled back from development aid projects, China has actually boosted investment, with $552 million in the first half of 2009. In May, Beijing announced that it would increase its China-Africa Development Fund - which has invested $400 million in Africa since 2006 - by an additional $2 billion.Trade between Africa and China is now worth about $100 billion per year, most of it generated by mineral and oil sales. That's about 10 times the level it was in the 1980s. Chinese investment in Sudan - a country accused by the International Criminal Court of war crimes and mass murder in its six-year civil conflict in the Darfur region - allows China to take home more than 60 percent of all the oil that Sudan produces. The arrangement works well for Sudan, or at least for the government in Khartoum. More than 80 percent of Khartoum's revenues come from oil.Faced with no-questions-asked Chinese investment on one hand and the West's penny-pinching aid-with-a-lecture on the other makes competing with China in Africa a tough task, German President Horst Kohler admitted in a June meeting with Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni. 'For this reason, Africans believe that China is better than the West because for us we raise issues regarding democracy, corruption and human rights,' the German president said in Berlin.(c) Copyright 2009. The Christian Science Monitor'

title: Construction of oil transmission pipeline (Duplicate)
description: 16 September 2003China Chemical Reporter CHCR English (c) 2003 China Chemical Reporter. All rights reserved  The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources of Sudan and China National Petroleum Corporation recently signed 3 agreements on joint oil development in Al Khurtum. President of Sudan, attended the signing ceremony.     The first agreement is concerned on the capacity expansion of Al Khurtum Refinery. The project has an investment of US$340 million. After the completion of the project, the oil refining capacity in the plant can increase from 56 000 barrels to 100 000 barrels per day. The second agreement isabout the construction of a 720km-long oil transmission pipeline from oil producing areas to Al Khurtum. The transmitting capacity of the pipeline will reach 200 000 barrels per day. The third agreement is about the joint establishment of an oil geophysical company. Not long ago CNPC Explorationand Development Co. discovered a large oilfield with oil reserves amounting to 2.0 billion barrels in a Basin of Sudan.        Sudan can already produce various oil products including jet fuel oil. Besides meeting the domestic demand, some export can also be made each year.(c)2003. China Chemical Reporter. title: Construction of power stations (Duplicate)
description: The Shandong Electric Power Construction Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chinese Shandong Power Group, has recently signed a letter of intention with the Sudanese authorities for the construction of three electricity power stations. It concerns a coal fired 500 MW power station in Port Sudan and two 300 MW gas fired power station, situated respectively in El Bagair (suburbs of Khartoum) and Al Fula (Kordofan). These projects represent an investment of $483.3 million and could be supported by the Export Import Bank of China. However, the negotiations have not yet been completed and a number of problems remain to be settled (the precise nature of the contract, cost of the project and conditions attached to the credit). There is one important point of disagreement between the government of Sudan and the Chinese company. Khartoum wants Shandong to build these power stations under a BOT (Build, Operate and Transfer) contract over 25 years.The Chinese company for its part considers that running these power stations for 25 years involves taking a risk on the future political stability of the country and on the conditions of their economic viability. It does not want to take such a risk and therefore proposed building them under an EPC (Engineering, Procurement and Construction) arrangement. Discussions will therefore have to continue for some time between the Chinese company and the authorities of Sudan before this project can be materialised.
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
donor_agency_count: Shandong Electric Power Construction Corp. (SEPCO), State-Owned Company

title: Chinese military advisers for use of patrol boats
description: In 2006, Sierra Leone and China signed a military aid deal involving Chinese advisors for the use of patrol boats donated by Beijing. The agreement provides for 15 Chinese advisers to stay for six months and train patrol boat personnel. It is unclear if the team ever arrived.

title: The Chinese government has donated 7,780 metric tons of fertilizer valued at 20 million RMB Yuan (duplicate)
description: China donates fertilizer, maize to Zambia.253 words16 September 2003Xinhua News AgencyXNEWSEnglish(c) Copyright 2003 Xinhua News AgencyLUSAKA, Sept. 16 (Xinhua) - The Chinese government has donated 7,780 metric tons of fertilizer valued at 20 million RMB Yuan ( about 2.5 million US dollars) and 4,500 metric tons of non-GMO yellow maize to Zambia.While officiating at the handover ceremony held here Tuesday, Zambian Agriculture and Cooperatives Minister Mundia Sikatana said he is grateful for the assistance the Chinese government has continued to render to Zambia and in particular in the development of the agricultural sector.Sikatana said the donation has not only come at the right time but that it will assist Zambia in expanding coverage in terms of input support and in assisting the country's vulnerable households access food.'The fertilizer we are receiving today will supplement government efforts in reaching out to many of our small scale farmers,' he said.'The food we are receiving today will add value to the nutritional status of our people particularly, in those areas prone to disasters,' he added.    Sikatana reaffirmed the Zambian government's commitment to thecontinued good relations with China.   Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu said the consignment ofmaterials is provided by the Chinese government to promote theagricultural development of Zambia.   Peng said the donation deeply expresses the friendly feelingsof the Chinese government and people to the Zambian government andpeople.   He hoped the two countries can further strengthen the bilateraleconomic cooperation and make new contribution to the commoninterests of the two peoples.  Document XNEWS00020030916dz9g001e4

title: Chinese government promise to aid Sierra Leone in food security
description: In 2002, the Chinese government promised to aid Sierra Leone in food security. It is unclear exactly how much food aid was given and the value of the project.

title: 10,000 tons of peanut oil purchase
description: In 2009, China signed a contract to buy 10,000 tons of peanut oil. This project does not appear to have any aid component, and its current status is unknown.
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: china donates goods (duplicate)
description: China gives Zambia 1m dollars to purchase relief aid270 words9 February 200610:16 AMBBC Monitoring Asia PacificBBCAPPEnglish(c) 2006 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Lusaka, 9 February: China has given drought-hit Zambia 1m US dollars for it to purchase relief food. At the signing ceremony held here Thursday [9 February] of the notes to acknowledge receipt of the fund, Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Baodong said that this donation is in the conditions that Zambia is suffering the food shortage because of drought.The ambassador said that the Chinese government is doing the job to help the Zambian government to implement the project of maintenance of water supply in Lusaka, Ndola and Kitwe with about 80m RMB [renminbi] yuan (about 10m dollars).The Chinese government has also agreed to provide the government with a batch of goods worth 10m RMB yuan (about 1.2m dollars) to be used in the elections later this year.On occasion Zambian Finance Minister Ng'andu Magande thanked the Chinese government for the assistance. The minister assured the Chinese ambassador the grant will be utilized to purchase relief food to benefit the hunger stricken people and accountability and transparency in the utilization of grant is strictly observed.It is estimated that 1.7 million Zambians are facing food shortage due to the drought that hit most part of the southern African country in the 2004/05 farming season. In November, 2005, Zambian President Levy Mwanawasa declared the hunger situation in the country as a 'national disaster', calling for international food aid.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1154 gmt 9 Feb 06
sector: Humanitarian and Disaster Relief and Preparation

title: $10 million financing arrangement secured (not a project)
description: Unnamed Chinese Investor Found for Tazaraby Mike Mande, the Eastafrican341 words30 October 200604:23 PMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2006 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedNairobi, Oct 30, 2006 (The East African/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) --Tanzania, Zambia and China are working on price assessment for possible concessioning of the Tanzania-Zambia Railways Authority (Tazara) to a Chinese private firm early next year.The three countries have already appointed a team consisting of three parties for the negotiation of the pricing. A private investor from China has been identified.Brigadier General Peter Tembo, Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Communication and Transport in Zambia, told The EastAfrican in Lusaka last week that Zambia and Tanzania had agreed to concession the railway firm to a Chinese investor who will be guaranteed by the Chinese government.'The Tanzania Parastatal Sector Reform Commission (PSRC) is overseeing the privatisation of Tazara, with the committee from the three partner states working on the price assessment,' he said, adding that some members of the privatisation committee had already been drawn from Tanzania, Zambia and China.Among other things, the Commission was expected to come up with an appropriate modality of privatising Tazara, with the two options being selling or leasing it out.Recently, a Chinese delegation visited Tanzania and Zambia for consultations with various stakeholders on the concessioning of Tazara.Maua Daftari, Deputy Minister for Infrastructure Development, said recently that the Tanzania and Zambia governments had identified a Chinese firm with the capacity to run the 1,860 kilometre railway profitably but stopped short of disclosing the firm's name.Ms Daftari said that Tanzania and Zambia had agreed to give priority to the Chinese firm after taking into account China's role in building the railway line and sustaining it over the past three decades.The railway line, constructed in the 1970s, runs from Dar-es-Salaam to Kapiri Mposhi in Zambia. Tazara has been experiencing declining profits through technical and managerial problems.Early this month, Tazara contracted an international firm to rehabilitate 18 main line locomotives under a $10 million financing arrangement secured through Konkola Copper Mines.
verified: Konkola Copper Mines, Private Sector

title: Aid to Gabon Tri-Service Military General Hospital: treatment, training (Duplicate of 11756)
description: 4月28日，由广州军区武汉总医院医护人员组成的中国援助加蓬军医组一行9人，完成为期一年的医疗援助任务返回武汉。援非期间，他们先后救治病患6000多人，为加蓬三军总医院培训医护人员300多人次，指导开展新技术新业务10余项，加蓬总统和国防部长曾分别为军医组成员授勋。图为加蓬国防部秘书总长为军医组成员佩戴勋章的情景。 李玉宝、余 敏摄影报道

title: $500m on Zambian economic development (duplicate-progress report)
description: Chinese firm spends 500m dollars on development of economic zone in Zambia355 words15 December 200808:20 AMBBC Monitoring AfricaBBCAPEnglish(c) 2008 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report by state-owned national newspaper Zambia Daily Mail website on 15 December[Report by Nkole Chitala: 'NFCA Spends US Doller 500m on MFEZ']China's Non-Ferrous Metals Corporation Africa (NFCA) mining Plc has spent US$500 million on the development of Chambishi multi-facility economic zone (MFEZ) on the Copperbelt.And a Chinese delegation, led by that country's minister of Commerce and Trade is expected in Zambia to commission the copper smelter at Chambishi mine next month.Commerce, Trade and Industry minister, Felix Mutati, said in Solwezi that out of the US$900 million investment set for the establishment of the economic zone, US$500 million had been spent.Mr Mutati said that apart from the commissioning of the Chambishi smelter, the delegation would also launch the Lusaka MFEZ.He said work on the Chambishi zone which was on schedule, had progressed well.Power and sewer system, infrastructure and road system were already in place at Chambishi economic zone.He said that currently a pass centre into the zone was being created.The economic zone is an area or premise where manufacturing activities, most for exports, are conducted with tax incentives offered to the firms.To qualify for operating in the zone, a company must invest over US$ 500,000, demonstrate that the investment will transfer technology and utilise local materials, among other criteria.Chambishi mine, being operated by NFCA, was initially an open pit mine and later developed as an underground mine. It was one of the first mines to be privatised in 1999.Since the acquisition of the firm, there has been heavy investment,which has seen the rehabilitation and modernisation of the old copper concentrator.The concentrator will have a capacity of producing 42 per cent copper concentrate grade from 1.8 per cent, making it superior to any other copper produced in Zambia.Currently, average grade for concentrates produced in Zambia is 35 per cent, most of which is exported to China.Source: Zambia Daily Mail website, Lusaka, in English 15 Dec 08a94b0e35
donor_agency_count: China Nonferrous Metal Mining (Group) Co., Ltd. (CNMC), State-Owned Company
recipient_agencies: China Nonferrous Metal Mining (Group) Co., Ltd. (CNMC), State-Owned Company

title: China has given Zambia grant assistance totalling 30 million (duplicate)
description: China gives Zambia 53m dollars for mobile hospitals469 words3 August 201012:31 PMBBC Monitoring AfricaBBCAPEnglish(c) 2010 The British Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved. No material may be reproduced except with the express permission of The British Broadcasting Corporation.Text of report by Zambian privately-owned daily newspaper The Post website on 3 August[Report by Florence Bupe: 'China Gives Govt US$53 Million Loan for Mobile Hospitals']The Government of China has given Zambia a 361 million yuan (approximately US $53 million) concessional loan for the construction of mobile hospitals in the country.And Vice President George Kunda has appealed to the Zambian and Chinese governments to implement the various bilateral agreements that were signed during President Rupiah Banda's state visit to that country in February his year.Speaking when a visiting Chinese delegation met Vice President Kunda at State House yesterday, Chinese State Councillor Dai Bingguo disclosed that his country had given Zambia the loan as part of continued efforts to strengthen bilateral ties.'On his visit, China will again provide assistance to Zambia through a concessional loan worth 361 million yuan for the construction of mobile hospitals. China will also consider providing preferential export bias credit to support the project n the Mongu-Kalabo Road and the housing project for civil servants,' he said.China has also given Zambia grant assistance totalling 30 million (about US $4.4 million) for the completion of already existing projects, including the construction of the Government Complex and stadium.Dai pledged his country's continued support to Zambia's economic growth through the provision of technical and financial resources for various projects. And Vice President Kunda said President Banda's recent visit to China had provided an opportunity for Zambia to be in touch with prevailing economic trends for growth. He said Zambia was one of China's biggest investment destinations with a total investment injection of US $700 million so far.'I would like to appeal to the governments of China and Zambia to quickly implement the various agreements that were signed during our President's state visit t hat country in the areas of technical and economic support,' said Vice-President Kunda.The Chinese delegation and Zambian government officials later held a closed door meeting with President Rupiah Banda, who was not part of the earlier meeting. The closed door meeting was followed by the signing of four bilateral agreements which included economic and technical cooperation, the Framework on the provision of the concessional loan, the agreement on the avoidance of double taxation and the agreement for the establishment of the Confucius Institute at the University of Zambia (UNZA).Meanwhile, First Republican President Dr Kenneth Kaunda appealed to China to continue providing assistance not only to Zambia, but also to Africa as a whole if sustainable development is to be attained.This was when the Chinese delegation visited Dr Kaunda's residence in Lusaka's Kabulonga area.Source: The Post website, Lusaka, in English 3 Aug 10ac5cf9d7Document BBCAP00020100803e683001rx

title: U.S.$400 Million Deal With Zambia [not a project, company is Nigerian]
description: In 2010, the Investment Promotion and Protection Agreement between Dangote Industries Ltd. and the Zambian government was signed, an agreement worth $400 million USD. It is a requirement for all major investors in Zambia which offers them additional incentives and safeguards their investments.  'As Dangote Industries Limited's investment is among the largest investments outside the traditional mining sector and Chinese investments in Zambia, it has understandably attracted a lot of attention,' he said, adding 'The fact that it is an African investment also generates a great deal of interest. Let me assure you that we are equal to the task; we have similar investments in more than 10 other African countries. We spent about nine months negotiating and I am delighted that we are now at a point where all parties are agreeable to the deal.'According to Dangote, the proposed cement plant in Zambia with an installed capacity of 1.5 million metric tonnes per annum, will be up and running 27 months from February/March 2011. He said DIL's choice of Zambia for this multi-million dollar investment is quite strategic, noting that the World Bank had in 2010 named Zambia as one of the world's fastest economically reforming countries. Zambia, he recalled, is also rated as one of the most highly urbanised countries in sub-Saharan Africa with 44 percent of the population concentrated in a few urban areas.Document AFNWS00020101213e6cd0004

title: China Injects assists Tazara Railway
description: In 2011, China granted a soft loan worth $39.9 million USD to Tazara to strengthen the railway. The loan would be spent on 11 areas including purchase of six new locomotive engines, rehabilitation of nine more and purchase of 90 new cargo carriages and rehabilitation of four cranes and two rescue cranes. Other requirements include the purchase of raw materials for rail underlining bars, purchase of spare parts for 1,200 cargo carriages and covering training costs of workers from different departments and professionals.

title: Bauxite development
description: In 2007, four Chinese state-owned firms set up a conglomerate known as the Henan International Mining Co. Ltd. to develop Guinea's bauxite resources. Yongcheng Coal and Co. Ltd. was one of the participants. This particular company holds a 51 percent stake in the overall conglomerate, which has a registered capital of 200 million RMB. In February of 2012, Henan International held a groundbreaking ceremony, with Provincial Minister Guo Gengmao, Chinese Ambassador Zhao Lixing, Deputy Prime Minister Uthman Ba, and Mineral Resources Minister Fu Fana all present. Geological exploration of the region was completed in October of 2009, and in October of 2010, completed the charter of their mining rights. The total investment will reach more than $3 billion USD.

title: Souapiti hydroelectric dam- duplicate with 187
description: Energy   electricity: Guinea246 words16 January 2007Economist Intelligence Unit - Business AfricaEIUBFBusiness Africa15Number xxxEnglish(C) 2007 The Economist Intelligence Unit Ltd.The Chinese government is reported to have pledged funding of US$850m towards the building of the Souapiti hydroelectric dam on the Konkouré River in the north of the country. Lack of funding has stalled the project—whose total cost is put at US$1bn—for many years. Attempts were initially made to link the project to various proposals for building alumina refineries, but the relevant investors could not be persuaded to help finance the construction of the dam. There are chronic electricity shortages in Guinea—the capital experiences frequent power cuts and most businesses that can afford it rely on a diesel generator to supplement their power supply. Outside Conakry electricity supply is minimal and mainly restricted to large towns. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>The proposed Souapiti station would generate 750 mw of electricity and would have the potential to supply not only the capital but also many industrial projects, such as the alumina refineries, as well as areas outside Conakry.However, the distribution of electricity will also require significant investment, especially if the area of distribution is expanded to include some rural areas. The Chinese interest in the project comes at a time when many bauxite-prospecting licences have been awarded to Chinese companies. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>The US$850m financing is being organised through a Chinese commercial bank, Exim Bank of China, and a Chinese construction company, Sinohydro, is to build the dam.SOURCE: Business Africabfbfmain20070116t0000000015; Business Africa 16 Jan 2007, Part 15 of 36Document EIUBF00020070127e31g0000f--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------China to fund $1 bln hydro dam in Guinea -sourceBy Saliou Samb348 words7 July 200702:02 PMReuters NewsLBAEnglish(c) 2007 Reuters LimitedCONAKRY, July 7 (Reuters) - China has agreed to fund the construction of a $1 billion hydroelectric dam in mineral-rich Guinea and renovate a series of state buildings, government officials in the West African country said on Saturday. The Souapiti dam should allow the former French colony to generate some 750 MW of electricity, officials said. Guinea is one of the world's least developed countries and even parts of the capital city have only sporadic mains power.A senior Chinese government delegation visiting Guinea had confirmed that China's government-owned Export-Import Bank (Eximbank), which has invested in projects across the world's poorest continent, would fund the dam.Local media reported that in return, Guinean authorities would guarantee China access to mineral reserves equivalent to some 2 billion tonnes of bauxite, the raw material used in the production of aluminium.'To guarantee Chinese investment, you have to give them guarantees but nothing has yet been formally decided,' said Cece Noramou, a senior official in Guinea's mines ministry.'They are interested in bauxite but we haven't finished determining the tonnage and so on,' he added.China has been offering low interest loans, debt relief and other incentives to countries around Africa as it seeks to increase its influence on the continent and gain access to natural resources to feed its fast developing economy.Guinea is the world's top bauxite exporter but most of the population survie on less than $1 a day.The Chinese delegation also promised debt relief worth around $4 million and an aid package of $5.2 million, according to Aboubacar Cisse, a spokesman for Guinea's foreign ministry.He said China had pledged to renovate the People's Palace cultural centre in Conakry and the state radio and television centre, partially destroyed when a Guinean air force jet crash-landed on it in April.GUINEA-HYDROPOWER/CHINA|LANGEN|G|RBN|Z|AFN|AFA|CSA|LBY|RWSA|RWS|REULB|GNS|RNP|DNP|PGE|SXNADocument LBA0000020070707e377000dj----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Souapiti Dam: Beijing Gets Way With Package273 words18 July 2007Africa Mining IntelligenceAMIN160EnglishCopyright 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedAs they did with the Belinga iron mine in Gabon the Chinese got their way in Guinea’s bauxite sector after several years of lobbying: tstyle='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>hey are to undertake an integrated program worth over USD 1 billion that includes construction of a dam, bauxite mine and an aluminium smelter. On July 2, a delegation from China’s Export Import Bank turned up to present the package to the minister for economic and financial controls, Saidou Diallo. The Chinese are to be awarded deposits containing over two billion tons of bauxite ore in return for financing construction of the Souapiti hydro power dam and building an aluminium facility. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>The Souapiti dam is to generate 94 MW and be linked to the Kaleta and Amaria mines (an application for the hook-up is being examined by Conakry). Some of the 2 billion tons of ore covered by the agreement will come from concessions already awarded to the Chinese in the Fria and Telemele regions.But other licenses of better quality, located at Boke, will also be turned over to the Chinese next year after properties are relinquished in the region by BHP Billiton, RusAl, CGB and IMIDRO. Management of the bauxite resources will be seen to by Chalco while Sino Hydro is to build the hydro dam by 2012. China’s deputy foreign minister, Zhai Jin, was still in Conakry on July 7 to negotiate the bonus for the package: the write-off of USD 45 million in debt, renovation of the Palais du People and the Radio Television Guineenne between now and October.31129145Document AMIN000020070824e37i00002----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Eximbank Floored by Competition ! Bauxite274 words14 November 2007Africa Mining IntelligenceAMIN167EnglishCopyright 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedThe vast Cogon project to build an aluminium smelter linked to the planned Souapiti dam could slip through the fingers of China Eximbank and its partners Chalco and Sino-Hydro (see AMI N°160). According to our information, Eximbank sought to impose too many conditions as guarantees of its investment. Among other things, style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>it demanded some of the revenue that Conakry gets from the Compagnie des Bauxites de Guinée (CBG) as well as 2 billion tonnes of superior quality bauxite (with alumina content of 60% or more) ! These conditions were judged unacceptable by the Prime Minister, Lansana Kouyaté, and the Minister for Mines, Ahmed Kanté, particularly as CBG’s revenues have been used to buy heating oil, rice and sugar for the country via an account with BNP Paribas since Kouyaté became head of the government. The Prime Minister therefore favoured encouraging another company to become involved in the project.The managing director of Cogon, Ahmed Tidjane Diallo, brought a group run by Sinozonto Mining Investment Co. Ltd backed by China Development Bank to Guinea to take the reins of the project. The grouping, run by Sun Jimming, is negotiating, among other things, taking on the bauxite bloc that had been allocated to China Eximbank at Fria. Sinozonto proposes building all the hydroelectric dams on the Konkouré, not only Souapiti, but also Kaléta and Amaria. It expects to commence bauxite production in 2010 and electricity production in 2012. Feasibility studies will begin between 2011 and 2012 for building an alumina refinery and then, depending on the availability of reserves, for construction of an aluminium smelter.34927882Document AMIN000020071130e3be0000k------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------New Chinese Group Formed for Souapiti - Conakry118 words28 November 2007Africa Mining IntelligenceAMIN168EnglishCopyright 2007 Indigo Publications All Rights ReservedIt seems that the removal of China Eximbank and its partners Chalco and Sino-Hydro from the integrated bauxite-alumina-aluminium development project linked with the Souapiti dam (AMI N°167) is confirmed. style='BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00'>On November 16, the government’s “new” Chinese partners, Hongpeng Sinozonto Mining Investment Co Ltd and Shanxi Luneng Jinbei Aluminum Corporation, formed Luneng Sinozonto Aluminium Guinea, a locally registered subsidiary. The same day, both signed a preliminary agreement covering development of the bauxite-alumina-aluminium branch and the integration of that activity with hydro-electric, rail and port infrastructure. Besides the Souapiti dam, the development programme now includes a plan to build a dam at Kaléta.35274948Document AMIN000020071214e3bs00004Energy   electricity: Guinea246 words16 January 2007Economist Intelligence Unit - Business AfricaEIUBFBusiness Africa15Number xxxEnglish(C) 2007 The Economist Intelligence Unit Ltd.The Chinese government is reported to have pledged funding of US$850m towards the building of the Souapiti hydroelectric dam on the Konkouré River in the north of the country. Lack of funding has stalled the project—whose total cost is put at US$1bn—for many years. Attempts were initially made to link the project to various proposals for building alumina refineries, but the relevant investors could not be persuaded to help finance the construction of the dam. There are chronic electricity shortages in Guinea—the capital experiences frequent power cuts and most businesses that can afford it rely on a diesel generator to supplement their power supply. Outside Conakry electricity supply is minimal and mainly restricted to large towns. The proposed Souapiti station would generate 750 mw of electricity and would have the potential to supply not only the capital but also many industrial projects, such as the alumina refineries, as well as areas outside Conakry.However, the distribution of electricity will also require significant investment, especially if the area of distribution is expanded to include some rural areas. The Chinese interest in the project comes at a time when many bauxite-prospecting licences have been awarded to Chinese companies. The US$850m financing is being organised through a Chinese commercial bank, Exim Bank of China, and a Chinese construction company, Sinohydro, is to build the dam.SOURCE: Business Africabfbfmain20070116t0000000015; Business Africa 16 Jan 2007, Part 15 of 36Document EIUBF00020070127e31g0000f

title: Aid to Gabon Tri-Service Military General Hospital: treatment, training (Duplicate of 11756)
description: 4月28日，由广州军区武汉总医院医护人员组成的中国援助加蓬军医组一行9人，完成为期一年的医疗援助任务返回武汉。援非期间，他们先后救治病患6000多人，为加蓬三军总医院培训医护人员300多人次，指导开展新技术新业务10余项，加蓬总统和国防部长曾分别为军医组成员授勋。图为加蓬国防部秘书总长为军医组成员佩戴勋章的情景。 李玉宝、余 敏摄影报道
