title: China to build a primary school at Harare, Zimbabwe
description: President Leaves for China-Africa Summitby Mabasa Sasa1179 words9 November 200903:09 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2009 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedHarare, Nov 09, 2009 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- President Mugabe yesterday left for Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, to join other Heads of State and Government attending the Fourth Ministerial Conference of the Forum on China-Africa Co-operation, where the leaders will review progress made in strengthening Sino-Africa ties since the 2006 Beijing Summit.He was seen off at the Harare International Airport by top Government and Chinese officials as well as service chiefs.President Mugabe, who is the Head of State and Government and Commander-in-Chief of the Zimbabwe Defence Forces, will today address the opening ceremony.Vice President Mujuru will be the Acting President during President Mugabe's absence.Apart from reviewing the implementation of agreements already reached, Africa and China's political leadership will also chart the course of action for the next three years.Sino-Africa ties are premised on the principle of friendly co-operation to jointly meet the challenges of globalisation and promote mutual development.The idea of having a formal forum through which to explore joint initiatives dates back to 2000 when the first Focac was held in Beijing.Focac is a platform established by the two sides for collective consultation and dialogue within the spirit of South-South co-operation.Africa's ties with China date back to the continent's liberation struggle.Relations between the two have grown in leaps and bounds over the past decade, with Africa appreciative of China's deliberate and stated principle of non-interference in domestic political affairs.This is in marked contrast to the manner in which Western countries have historically sought to undermine Africa through unfair trade arrangements and direct meddling in local politics.At the first Ministerial Conference of Focac leaders present adopted the Beijing Declaration and Programme for China-Africa Co-operation in Economic and Social Development.The conference charted the direction for the development of a new, stable and long-term partnership featuring equality and mutual benefit between China and African countries.At the Beijing Summit and Third Ministerial Conference in 2006, 48 African Heads of State and Government and the Chinese leadership discussed further co-operative measures.Leaders then adopted the 2007-2009 Action Plan, which will be reviewed in Sharm el-Sheikh.Zimbabwe, in particular, has benefited immensely from ties with China.Beijing has extended over US$300 million for Zimbabwe's economic turnaround programmes in addition to US$500 000 to fight last year's cholera outbreak.Construction of China-Zimbabwe Friendship Hospital in Mahusekwa, Mashonaland East province, began on October 30 this year.The hospital covers 6 600 square metres and will have 100 beds when complete.The total investment of the project is about US$10 million.The Chinese recently completed the construction of a school in Bindura, while another one in Harare's environs will be done by the end of this year, with both projects costing US$1,5 million.An 80-hectare agricultural demonstration centre is under construction at Gwebi College and 10 senior Chinese agricultural experts -- who arrived in the country on October 25 -- will assist in grain production, dryland farming, aquaculture, animal disease prevention and control, and irrigation.In 2009, the Chinese government donated US$5 million through the World Food Programme.China, along with Russia, South Africa and others, has also been at the forefront of defending Zimbabwe from the political Western onslaught at the United Nations Security Council in recent years.Recently, China's Ambassador in Harare, Mr Xin Shunkang, said: 'The Chinese side highly appreciates Zimbabwe's firm commitment to the One-China Policy and its support of China's great cause of reunification.'The Chinese government and people value its traditional friendship with Zimbabwe, view Zimbabwe as a trustworthy friend and important partner.'China is ready to work with Zimbabwe to further strengthen the existing friendly relations and co-operation to bring more benefits to our two peoples.'Meanwhile, earlier in the day, President Mugabe capped 300 Bindura University of Science Education graduates who successfully completed degree courses in the university's eighth graduation ceremony.Of the 300 students who graduated from the faculties of Agriculture and Environmental Sciences, Faculty of Science Education and Faculty of Commerce, 15 were awarded with master's degrees.In his keynote address, BUSE acting Vice Chancellor Mr Cuthbert Katsvanga said the university was striving to create a conducive environment for student empowerment and learning.'The university is committed to offering quality education and be among the first to be accredited by the Zimbabwe Council for Higher Education,' he said.He said the university had completed three computer laboratories and furnished them with 20 brand new state-of-the- art computers each.'We have accomplished wireless Internet connection to enable students and staff to access the Internet from any point on the campus and bought a printing press which is already running.'The printing press will serve to generate income for the institution,' he said, adding the university would print textbooks.The university, he said, had installed ten 5 000-litre water storage tanks and another 10 000-litre tank, which were donated by Unicef, while a borehole was sunk to complement existing boreholes.Mr Katsvanga added that the university valued private public partnerships.'In this respect the university engaged Mr Hanif Ahmed Allana, a philanthropist, who came up with a scholarship for the financially less privileged students,' he said.Mr Allana yesterday also donated a motor vehicle, a motorcycle and four printers to the university.Mr Katsvanga paid tribute to members of the university council including Dr Solomon Guramatunhu, Dr J. Nyika, Mr K. S. Musanhi, whom he said had assisted the university in various ways and set up important support programmes.He applauded the Mashonaland Central Governor and Resident Minister Advocate Martin Dinha for assisting the university especially in terms of networking.Mr Katsvanga told President Mugabe that the university's second five-year strategic plan was now in place and would guide them towards the institution's ambitious projects.He, however, said the university still faced a critical accommodation problems since only 500 can be accommodated by the university's hostels yet the total enrolment stood at 2 000.Members of the staff have been forced to share rooms, a situation that has hampered the university's recruitment efforts.Turning to tuition fees, Mr Katsvanga said most students were battling to raise the money though parents were trying the best to make payments.He praised Government for its cadetship programme saying it had proved useful to disadvantaged students of whom about 450 were beneficiaries at the institution.Mr Katsvanga expressed concern at the brain drain that had affected its science education programmes that had hard hit secondary schools.Many teachers are leaving the profession for greener pastures in the Diaspora.Mr Katsvanga applauded President Mugabe on his educational expansion programme that had made university education available to all Zimbabweans.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020091109e5b90008v-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Chinese Envoy Hands Over Two Schools495 words29 September 201106:48 AMAll AfricaAFNWSEnglish(c) 2011 AllAfrica, All Rights ReservedSep 29, 2011 (The Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- THE Chinese Embassy yesterday handed over two primary schools to the Zimbabwean Government built at a cost of US$1,5 million as part of the bilateral cooperation between the two countries.The two schools, one in Bindura, Mashonaland Central Province and another in Warren Park, Harare, are part of the eight measures announced by Chinese President Hu Jintao at the Forum of China-AfricanCo-operation Beijing Summit aimed at assisting the continent, where Zimbabwe is one of the beneficiaries.China will also build a high school, another primary school, a mini-hydro power station, solar power project, a methane project and drill boreholes as part of the programmes announced by Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao in 2009.Speaking at the commissioning of Chiwaridzo Primary School in Bindura Vice President Joice Mujuru said there was need to review the school curriculum to incorporate the politics of the country to ensure that pupils appreciated how countries such as China helped Zimbabweduring the liberation struggle.VP Mujuru said China was an all-weather friend, which stood by Zimbabwe in the wake of illegal sanctions imposed by the United States and other Western countries.'Indeed, it was the veto power of China and Russia, that crippled the West's yearning for the sanctions resolution in the United Nations Security Council,' she said.'Our Look East policy, which aims to expand bilateral and trade opportunities, and offer priority toinvestors from the region, is paying dividends.'Government, said VP Mujuru, would want civil servants to get reasonable salaries, but was being hampered by the illegal sanctions.She said Government alone might not be able to meet the demand for education at a pace that is desirable, hence such partnerships as the one that exists with China assist the nation to achieve its aspirations.Chinese ambassador to Zimbabwe, Mr Xin Shunking, said Beijing would soon be sending six agricultural experts and also provide medical equipment.'I believe that all the projects can bring more benefit to Zimbabwean people and give impetus to the development of China-Zimbabwe relationships,' said Mr Shunkang, also known locally as Chakanaka Chakanaka.Co-operation in education, he said, was one of the important parts of the two countries' bilateral relations and made positive contributions to the development of the two countries' overall relationship.'China always pays attention to training programmes of human resources in Zimbabwe,' said Mr Shunkang.'These two schools will become new symbols of China-Zimbabwe friendship. They will witness the further progression of our relations.'The two schools were built by Chinese companies Gansu Hualong and Jiangsu Nantong. Mr Shunkang mesmerised the audience when he mixed Shona and English in his speech.The event was also attended by Transport, Communications and Infrastructural Development Minister Nicholas Goche, Education, Sport, Arts and Culture deputy minister Lazarus Dokora, senior government officials and local political and traditional leadership.All Africa Global MediaDocument AFNWS00020110929e79t000hk---------------------------------------------On April 19, 2007, it was announced that through the China-Africa Cooperation Forum, the Chinese government plans to construct two schools in rural areas of Zimbabwe alongside an agricultural demonstration center. An update from May 12, 2008 Harare, May 12, 2008 Ambassador Nasheng said under the eight measures of assisting Africa proposed by Chinese President Hu Jintao during the China-Africa Beijing Summit in 2006, China would set up an Agricultural Technology Demonstration Centre, a hospital and two schools in Zimbabwe. He said the investment in ATDC had increased from 10 million RMB to 40 million RMB and both Governments had finalised all the preparations and other related work. 'Another team of 10 Chinese Youth volunteers will arrive soon to start from where the previous team has left. Zimbabwe's personnel in the public sector will continue to benefit from short-term training courses offered by China in various fields ranging from computer science to agro-technique,' said Ambassador Yuan. He said the courses were targeted at all African countries while the number of Zimbabweans trained last year was the highest in Africa.

title: 23 vehicles [duplicate of 1449]
description: Accra, Jan 22, 2003 (Accra Mail/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) - The Minister of Defence and Acting Interior Minister Dr. Kwame Addo-Kufuor yesterday cut the sod for the construction of barracks for the Military and received a donation of twenty-three vehicles from the Chinese Government. The barracks comprising three blocks of twenty-eight units and two blocks of twelve units will accommodate 105 families. They have been financed from an interest-free loan of $4.5 million from the Government of the People's Republic of China to the Ghana Armed Forces and the Police Service. Dr. Addo-Kufuor said Ghana and China continue to enjoy excellent economic, political, social and cultural relations and the mutual benefits from these ties are seen in increased trade between the two countries especially in the manufacturing and technological sectors, thus promoting technical and scientific co-operation. He said the donation of vehicles including four tipper trucks, eight troops carrying vehicles, six double cabin pick-ups and five single cabin pick-ups was made possible with a grant of $482,000, and expressed the hope that they would improve the transport situation in the Ghana Armed Forces. The Chinese Ambassador, Mr. Lu Yongshou, said China attaches importance to the friendly relations and cooperation with Ghana. He said the donation is to support the capacity building of the Ghana Armed Forces and a manifestation of the friendship between China's Armed Forces and the Ghana Armed Forces. Mr. Lu Yongshou said since Dr. Addo-Kufuor assumed office he has added significantly to the high reputation enjoyed by the Ghana Armed Forces. He added that China would continue to support Ghana and promote military, economic and technical co-operation between the two countries. In related development, the United Kingdom government is providing the Ghana government with GBP2 million in support of Ghana's participation in the West African peacekeeping operation in Cote d'Ioire. The funding is to be used to provide logistical and other supplies for the Ghanaian Contingent of the Cote d'Ioire peacekeeping force, dubbed ECOFORCE. A memorandum of understanding (MOU) in respect of the British support was signed at the Ministry of Defence, ON Monday by the Minister for Defence, Dr. Kwame Addo-Kufuor, and the Acting British High Commissioner, Mr. Robin Gwynn. Speaking after the signing, Dr. Addo-Kufuor said Ghana was grateful to the UK government for providing her such resources to support the Ghanaian Contingent. He said he hoped this support would go long way to help maintain lasting peace in Cote d'Ioire. The Defence Minister, who also Acting Minister of the Interior, also requested assistance to enhance the training of the civil police and especially for the Police College. The Acting High Commissioner, expressing the British Government's belief that a peaceful political solution to the Iorian crisis was vital for both Cote d'Ioire and the sub-region, said his government valued Ghana's contribution to resolving the difficult problem, hence her consistent support for Ghana's peacekeeping efforts. Mr. Gwynn hoped that the current peace negotiations in France would provide a framework for a lasting resolution to the problem. by Hannah Asomaning Copyright Accra Mail. Distributed by All Africa Global Media(AllAfrica.com)   KEYWORD:          Ghana. Document afnws00020030123dz1n002bd

title: Two hydroelectric dams
description: In 2003, China announced that it would grant Cameroon 30 billion CFA francs to help build three hydoelectric dams. The first of the dams to begin implementation, the Memve'ele Dam in Nyabizan #289, will cost a combined FCFA 420 billion. The implementation of the Memve'ele Dam was officially launched by Cameroonian President Paul Biya on June 15, 2012. At the time of the launch, the Cameroonian President reiterated that two more dams projects are in store. No further information is known about the future location of those dams, progress, implementing agencies or financial amounts.

The loan will be repaid over 20 years and will be accessible in 2011.

title: Zimbabwe-ZUPCO acquires 50 buses from China-FAW (duplicate of 17926)
description: On June 16, 2005, Chinese state-owned auto manufacturer First Automobile Works (FAW) announced that it would sign a memorandum of understanding with Zimbabwe parastatal Zimbabwe United Passenger Company (ZUPCO) to construct a vehicle assembly plant in Zimbabwe to construct buses.ZUPCO chief executive officer Marko Kandengwa announced the MoU. The rebuilding public transporter recently acquired 50 buses from FAW, with more orders expected to follow.'We are going to be signing an MOU with FAW with respect to setting up an assembly plant and then conduct a feasibility study to determine the viability of the project,' said Kandengwa.Kandengwa could not be drawn into giving figures, saying the cost of the project would be determined by the feasibility study.This is however, not the first time that investors have explored possibilities of establishing a vehicle assembly plant in Zimbabwe. Pioneer Motor Company, which acts as an intermediary for Swedish bus-makers Scania, stitched up a supply agreement with ZUPCO a few years ago and was considering setting up an assembly plant.However, payment problems resulted in relations souring between the two and the plans have since been put on hold.ZUPCO, whose fleet has been severely depleted owing to poor maintenance levels and lack of recapitalisation, has announced plans to boost its fleet to about 1200 buses, with the Chinese emerging as preferred suppliers in line with the government's 'Look East' policy that has also seen national airline Air Zimbabwe procuring three aircraft from China.Early this year Vice President Joice Mujuru indicated that a joint venture, with the Chinese to set up an assembly plant was being considered.Document AFNWS00020050617e16g000pm

title: title
Minerals for infrastructure deal
description: In September of 2007, China and the Democratic Republic of the Congo signed a deal providing the Congo with $6 billion US dollars in aid for infrastructure projects in return for rights to minerals. The agreement was signed by state companies representing both sides. The deal helped fund some small infrastructure projects including the construction of roads, railways, hospitals, dams, and mine development. The Congolese government will in turn provide up to 10 million tons of copper and thousands of tons of cobalt. Dates of completion and contact information are yet to be determined.

title: Building Processing Factories and Providing technical and management training
description: BEIJING, Jan. 15 (Xinhua) -- Resources cooperation between China and Africa will help Africa to realize sustainable development, Chinese experts on African studies told Xinhua in recent interviews. In a policy paper aimed at strengthening its ties with Africa, China is working to explore the prospect of Sino-African cooperation in 30 concrete fields. In China's first-ever African Policy Paper released here Thursday, China highlighted its readiness to facilitate information sharing and cooperation with Africa in resources development. 'To translate Africa's advantages in resources to competitive strength, and to realize sustainable development in Africa is our aim in the resources cooperation,' said Wang Yingying, a researcher on African studies with the China Institute of International Studies. Despite their remarkable economic growth in recent years, African countries are still vulnerable in their economy as the majority of their exports are unprocessed raw materials, Wang said. China has helped African countries build processing factories and provided technical and management training courses in a bid to increase the added value of their exported commodities, thus increasing the competitiveness of their products. The Chinese government encourages and supports competent Chinese enterprises to cooperate with African nations in developing and exploiting rationally their resources. 'While the Chinese enterprises are involved in resources exploitation in Africa, they contribute to the continent's development at the same time,' Wang said. Elaborating her viewpoint, she said that China refunds the profits it has earned by reinvesting in infrastructure construction such as building power stations. 'The investment has brought real benefits to people in Africa and the continent as a whole,' the researcher said. 'Unlike some western countries, China's cooperation with African countries is based on boosting sustainable development in Africa,' Wang said. While developing oil, iron ore and mineral resources in Africa, China pays much attention to protection of local environment, she said, adding, 'We also help train personnel in various fields in an effort to guarantee sustainable development in Africa.' An Yongyu, president of the China Society for African Studies, said China sticks to a policy of sustainable development. Consequently, it lays stress on sustainable reproduction of resources in its cooperation with African countries. For example, An said, when exploiting forest resources in Gabon, China adopted a method of planting saplings at the same time to make it renewable. Currently, many African-made products are sold 'cheaply' due to their unfavorable position on the world market, causing huge losses to these countries. In energy cooperation with African countries, China purchased their products at a reasonable price in international market in stead of forcing prices down, said An, who used to serve as former Chinese ambassador to several African countries. 'These examples show that China does attach importance to sustainable development in Africa,' An said.

title: Social Projects Grant
description: In April of 2004, Angola and China signed an economic and technical cooperation agreement. This provided that China would give Angola a loan of $1.8 billion US dollars for the implementation of social projects decided on by the two governments. The money was funded by China's ExIm Bank who pledged the almost $2 billion dollars on March 2, 2004. On March 21, the financing package was finalized. The specific project endorsed by the agreement are not known, but 70% of the work was reserved by Chinese companies. Projects included 31 contracts on energy, water, health, education, and public works projects. The second half of the payment was made in late March of 2007. (extension of loan seen in Project #20055). The loan was repaid in Angolan oil; it could be paid in 12 years with a concessional interest rate.

title: Telecommunications Loan (Not a Project)
description: '　The Export-Import Bank of China (EIBC) has signed a loan contract worth $56.4 million with African Import-Export Bank, sources reported.The loans will be provided to the Republic of Zimbabwe and the Republic of Burundi for the purchase of telecommunications equipment from China's ZTE Corp, a telecommunications equipment producer and network solutions provider.''新华网北京９月２８日专电（记者陶俊洁、赵晓辉）记者２８日从中国进出口银行获悉，在与非洲进出口银行签署的框架协议项下，双方将签署５６４０万美元的电信项目贷款协议。　　进出口银行有关部门负责人介绍，进出口银行承办的非行第８５次董事会会议近日在北京召开，这是非行成立以来首次在非洲大陆以外的董事单位所在国举办董事会会议，旨在与中国进出口银行等中国金融机构和企业加强合作，加快中非战略合作伙伴关系全面发展。　　非行行长让·路易·埃克拉指出，非行将利用双方签署的信贷额度协议项下的资金为毛里求斯客户在津巴布韦和布隆迪的电信项目安排融资，以支持其从中兴公司进口电信设备。　　成立于１９９３年的非行是以促进非洲各国贸易发展为宗旨的区域性多边金融机构，总部设在埃及开罗。该行董事会董事一般由各股东国财政部或央行及非洲大型私营部门或企业主要负责人担任。该行董事会会议每年举办四次，由不同董事单位所在国承办。　　作为非行的股东和董事单位，中国进出口银行与非行逐步建立了稳固的合作关系，并于２００９年签署了贸易融资信贷额度协议。'Document BJEIND0020100929e69t0000c'

title: Debt rescheduling
description: 'YAOUNDE, Cameroon: Visiting Premier Zhu Rongji yesterday highlighted the progress made in exploring new areas of economic co-operation with Cameroon. During the meeting with his Cameroon counterpart Peter Mafany Musonge, Zhu said that China has provided assistance within its capacity to Cameroon for this African country's development. Apart from helping Cameroon in infrastructure construction, China has also reduced and cancelled debts owed to it by Cameroon. Official statistics indicate that China has already cancelled 75 per cent of the debts owed to it by Cameroon that have become due. An agreement signed between the two countries yesterday after the prime ministerial meeting has rescheduled a number of debts Cameroon owes to China and allowed the country to defer their repayment. China promised two years ago during the Forum on China-African Co-operation that it will cancel or reduce 10 billion yuan (US$1.2 billion) of debts owed to China by African countries within two years.Inside sources told China Daily that the work is proceeding smoothly, but declined to say how much of the originally set figure has been settled. According to a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Zhu said that the Chinese Government has all along encouraged and supported Chinese enterprises to conduct mutually beneficial co-operation with their counterparts in Cameroon. Zhu also pushed for the tapping of trade potentials, suggesting that Cameroon can import more Chinese products that are not too expensive but are of good quality for a more balanced trade relationship. The trade volume between China and Cameroon reached US$213 million last year, with Chinese imports taking US$180 million of the total. Musonge thanked China for the help it has given Cameroon, saying that his country wishes to further expand co-operation with China in various fields, according to the Chinese spokeswoman. Zhu arrived in Yaounde on Thursday for an official visit before heading for South Africa to attend the World Summit on Sustainable Development today. He also held separate talks with Cameroon President Paul Biya yesterday afternoon local time. The meeting was still going on at press time. (Copyright 2001 by China Daily). '                                 'Since 2000, Beijing has intensified its development agenda in Cameroon in the areas of politics, economy, social and cultural activities. Biya's visit to China from 21st to 25th of September 2003 marked another turning point in Sino-Cameroon co-operation. Not only did the President hold a tete-a-tete at the Great Peoples' Palace, he also held important talks with Prime Minister Wen Diabao and the National Assembly President, Wu Bangguo. Prior to the visit, China on the 23rd of November 2001 cancelled Cameroon's debt to the tune of CFA 17 billion. '
donor_agency: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency

title: Renovation of the Yaounde Conference Centre - duplicate of 274
description: 'Cameroon and China have signed a total of five cooperation conventions which have to do with the commercial activities of both countries; debt rescheduling; the renovation of the Yaounde Conference Centre; and the construction of a modern sports complex in the nation's capital worth 5.4bn CFA francs [8.8m dollars]. The signing of the five conventions was the high of an enlarged working session in Yaounde today between and Cameroonian and Chinese delegations. Our Star Building correspondent, Benard Ngwa, reports on today's activities at the star building between the Sino-Cameroon delegations.[Reporter] The visiting prime minister of State Council and the People's Republic of China, Zhu Rongji, and his delegation arrived the Star Building at exactly 0927 [local time] for the first working session with their Cameroonian counterparts...In his introductory remarks as he welcomed the Chinese delegation, Prime Minister Peter Mafany Musonge described the visit as significant and expressed the hope that discussions will further strengthen Sino-Cameroon relations. Speaking through an interpreter, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji thanked President Biya for an invitation to visit Cameroon adding that it enabled him to discover first hand the peace and beauty of the country, the warmth of its people as well as enabled them appreciate effort by the Cameroon government to improve the standard of living of its people...Meanwhile the high point of the enlarged working session was the signing of five cooperation accords between Cameroon and China. The five accords included one for commercial, economic and technical cooperation; another on rescheduling Cameroon's debt to China; the third on a Chinese grant to Cameroon worth 72m CFA francs [107,000 dollars]; the fourth to renovate the Yaounde Conference Centre; and the final accord to construct a modern sports complex in Yaounde to the tune of 5.4bn CFA francs… '

title: Grant
description: On January 31, 2007 Chinese President Hu Jintao signed a number of deals including a 40 million yuan grant. It appears that the grant  funded projects of the government of Cameroon's choosing, which according to sources, 'included wireless (CDMA) phone technology for CAMTEL (developed by Huawei Technologies) (#22553), a potable water project for Douala (#315), and several small agricultural projects.' The extent to which this money funded these projects (or whether it did at all) is currently unclear, as well as the specifics of each project. This appears to be an ideal project to follow up on with in-country contacts. Cameroonian President Paul Biya commented on the deals.STAFF_NOTES:The financial amount for this project has been removed since the finance is already counted in the projects mentioned above.

title: Debt Cancellation Plans
description: In 2001, The cooperation between China and the Central African Republic was hailed today during a meeting the prime minister and head of the govenment, Anicet Georges Dologuele, and other government officials held with a Chinese delegation led by the minister of foreign affairs of the Chinese People's Republic, Mr Jiaxuan Tang. The two parties discussed various issues of a economic, social and cultural nature. They expressed readiness to strengthen the cooperation between the peoples of China and the Central African Republic. On behalf of the Chinese delegation, the minister of foreign affairs announced assistance to the Central African Republic and at the same time spoke of plans to cancel debts owed to the Chinese government by the Central African Republic. China also intends to contribute to the consolidation of peace, which is a necessary condition for lasting development. Source: Radio Centrafricaine, Bangui, in French 1300 gmt 12 Jan 01. '

title: $26m Loan  for Chad (DUPLICATE)
description: 'Copyright 2007, Global Insight Limited. All Rights Reserved.China's Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing is currently on a seven-country tour of sub-Saharan Africa, visiting states that his country could profit from by exploiting minerals or securing future energy supplies. Li, having finished his visit to Equatorial Guinea, met Chad's president Idriss Déby Itno, with whom he discussed security issues and the conflict in Sudan’s Darfur region. Li later signed off on a loan of US$26 million and promised to cancel debts that Chad owed to China. The African country is looking for significant investment in its hydrocarbons sector and in August 2006 decided diplomatically to recognise China over Taiwan (see Chad: 9 August 2006:). Significance: China is responsible for building up Sudan's oil industry from a low level and after this first visit by a senior government minister from the East Asian giant, Chad can also expect huge investment in its oil sector.Because of China's special relationship with Sudan, hostilities between Chad and Sudan should cease permanently. Chad's oil is currently exported by pipeline via Cameroon, but with Chinese funds it is possible that a new pipeline will be constructed and Chad's crude could be exported from Sudan's east coat. Meanwhile, Li's visit to Equatorial Guinea saw his host's bilateral debt to China reduced by US$75 million. Global Insight believes China will take significant acreage in Equatorial Guinea's upcoming licensing round due early this year; the country's oil sector is currently dominated by U.S. firms. When Li completes his seven nation tour he will also have visited Guinea Bissau, Botswana, Eritrea, Central African Republic and Benin. ''中国外长李肇星已抵达乍得并与乍得总统伊特诺举行了会晤。双方就乍得邻国苏丹受战乱摧残的达尔富尔地区的人道主义危机等事项进行了磋商。这是李肇星此次非洲七国访问的第四站。李肇星此行的主要目的是加深中国与非洲各国的关系，同时李肇星此行也反映出中国对非洲大陆日益增加的经济兴趣。李肇星还签署了一系列协议，包括中国向乍得提供价值两千六百万美元的优惠贷款及免除乍得欠中国的数十亿美元债务等内容。此前，李肇星刚刚结束对中西非国家几内亚比绍的访问，几内亚比绍获得了中国四百万美元的捐助。中国迫切希望打通渠道获得非洲大陆丰富的石油与矿产资源，用来满足国内经济高速发展的需要。因此中国和苏丹与津巴布韦等因侵犯人权而遭到西方国家摈弃的非洲国家发展关系的做法也饱受西方国家的批评。'

title: Hospital with equipment and kits (Duplicate of 438)
description: 'KINSHASA, Sept. 4 (Xinhua) -- Democratic Republic of Congo ( DRC)'s president Joseph Kabila attended here Tuesday the inauguration of a modern comprehensive hospital built with the assistance of China.The hospital has 150 beds and an array of sophisticated medical equipments and kits.China's ambassador in DRC Wu Zexian described this hospital as a testimony of fruitful friendship between the two countries, adding that 'China will lend its support to efforts deployed by DRC as it embarks fully on its reconstruction process.'Ndjili general hospital with a surface area of 8,000 square meters, is situated to the east of DRC's capital of Kinshasa, where a third of the city's population lives. '

title: Ice City in Egypt (Trilateral)
description: 'Skiing is coming to Cairo. The Egyptian Ice City, an enterprise worth $20 million (LE 78 million), was opened in Cairo in June. The city, a collaboration between China, Sweden, Egypt and financed by businessmen from the UAE, is roughly 6,000 m2 large.'
sector: Trade, Tourism, Banking and Financial Services

title: $75 Loan for Medical, Agricultural Purposes (Duplicate of 458)
description: 'BRAZZAVILLE, Dec. 21 (Xinhua) -- China on Tuesday concluded with the Republic of Congo an interest-free loan agreement of 500 million RMB (75.8 million U. S. dollars) for the development of medical care and agriculture in the Central African country.Chinese Ambassador to Congo Li Shuli and Congolese Minister of Finance Gilbert Ondongo signed the agreement in the Congolese capital Brazzaville.The loan to be repaid by the Congolese government in a 10-year period from July 1, 2020 to June 30, 2030 is part of the framework agreement on economic and technical cooperation between the two governments.According to Ambassador Li, the money is to finance projects selected by both parties. '

title: Debt Relief (duplicate of 472)
description: In 2001,  19 (AFP) - Chinese President Jiang Zemin Monday issued an unspecified amount of no-interest loans to Equatorial Guinea, while the two countries signed agreements on debt exemption and agricultural cooperation, state press reported.'China and Equatorial Guinea have supported and earnestly cooperated with each other since the establishment of bilateral diplomatic relations 31 years ago,' Jiang was quoted by the Xinhua news agency as telling visiting President Obiang Nguema Mbasogo.Jiang said China was 'keen' on helping developing countries during his talks with Mbasogo held in the Great Hall of the People in central Beijing, the report said.No details on the amount of debt relief or loans were immediately available.In the first-ever China African Cooperation Forum, held in Beijing in October 2000, China pledged to cancel 1.2 billion dollars of debt owed by African nations over the following two years and called for increased trade with the continent.The agreement on debt exemption for Equatorial Guinea was signed in light of the October 2000 pledge, Jiang said.China has been a traditional recipient of global financial aid, but with its growing economic clout has recently become a provider of aid to developing countries. '  '新华网北京12月23日电(记者潘林青、刘劼)国务院新闻办公室23日发表的《中国与非洲的经贸合作》白皮书说，从2000年至2009年，中国已免除35个非洲国家的312笔债务，总计189.6亿元人民币。　　白皮书说，中国政府一贯支持非洲国家的减债努力，帮助非洲国家减轻对华债务负担。上述减债举措，体现了中国帮助非洲实现发展的愿望和决心，也推动了国际社会对非减债进程。　　中国还积极援建非洲国家公共福利设施。白皮书说，中国为非洲国家援建了一大批低造价住房、打井供水、污水处理、广播电视和通讯设施等公共福利项目，对提高当地人民生活水平发挥了积极作用。比如，塞舌尔、莫桑比克、安哥拉、埃塞俄比亚的低造价住房项目，改善了当地民众居住条件；尼日利亚、塞内加尔、赤道几内亚的打井项目、坦桑尼亚查林兹供水系统、尼日尔津德尔供水工程等，解决了当地居民生活用水问题；赤道几内亚国家电视中心，满足了当地电视信号传输、覆盖的需求。'

title: Chinese-Gabonese industrial fishing and timber companies
description: The cooperation between Gabon and China, which have had diplomatic relations since 1974, is not limited to the health sector since there is a Chinese-Gabonese industrial fishing company and two timber products manufacturing companies. Furthermore, China funded and built the [Gabonese] National Assembly building and is currently building the senate's building. '新华网利伯维尔２月１日电（记者毛雪良 任亚秋）中国和加蓬建交３０周年之际，中国国家主席胡锦涛应加蓬总统邦戈的邀请，将于２月１日至３日对加蓬进行国事访问。这次访问必将把两国关系推向新的高度，为两国友好合作谱写新的历史篇章。　　中国和加蓬１９７４年４月建交以来，两国关系发展顺利。尤其是进入新世纪以来，两国在政治、经贸、军事、文教、司法、科技和医药卫生等领域的交往与合作不断扩大和深化，双边关系开始形成多层次、全方位发展的格局并呈现出蓬勃发展的势头。　　中加关系的一个显著特点是，双方政治交往频繁，保持高层互访势头，为两国发展长期友好合作打下了坚实的基础。加蓬总统邦戈曾先后８次访华，他称中国是可信赖的朋友。加蓬政府一贯坚持一个中国的立场，支持中国统一大业。新世纪以来，加蓬总检察长、国防部长、文化部长、外交国务部长等相继访华。时任中共中央政治局常委、书记处书记尉健行，时任中国外交部长唐家璇等也分别率团访问了加蓬。　　政治关系的稳定发展为中加两国经贸和技术合作提供了良好契机。加蓬地处非洲中西部，自然资源极其丰富，享有“资源宝库”和“绿金之国”的美誉，是非洲木材、石油和锰矿砂生产大国。长期以来，两国始终在经济和贸易领域等保持着积极合作。　　建交以来，两国经济技术合作方兴未艾，涉及农业、渔业、公共工程、文化教育和医疗卫生等领域。两国已成功实施了多个合资、合作项目，其中包括中加渔业公司、投资贸易促进中心、中加制药厂等。目前双方正就实施加蓬广电大厦项目进行协商。该项目系中国在加蓬的第一个出口信贷项目，将对中加经贸合作多样化和拓宽两国合作领域起到积极推动作用。　　与此同时，两国贸易也取得了长足发展，双边贸易额已从１９９４年的８８００万美元上升到２００３年的约３亿美元。加蓬已成为中国在中西非地区的第二大贸易伙伴。中方主要从加蓬进口木材、原油和锰矿砂等，向加蓬出口纺织品、日用品、小五金、家用电器及机电产品。中加经贸合作互利互补，前景广阔。两国政府均表示，将继续采取措施鼓励两国商界增加往来，加强合作。　　中加建交后，中国向加蓬提供了大量无私援助，为增强两国友好关系发挥了积极作用。１９７４年以来，中国向加蓬提供的各种经援已超过８亿元人民币。中方还在加蓬承担了许多技术合作项目，目前已完成的有１０个，其中包括加蓬国民议会大厦、利伯维尔中加合作医院、弗朗斯维尔中加友谊医院等。包括总统邦戈在内的加蓬许多政要称赞２００１年启用的加蓬国民议会大厦是“加中两国友谊的丰碑，加蓬人民的骄傲”。目前，中国正在加蓬首都实施加蓬参议院大厦项目。　　中非合作论坛部长级会议２０００年１０月召开以来，中国和加蓬两国人员往来不断，中国在外交、经济、军事、教育、科技和医药等领域对加蓬人员的培训力度明显加大。　　当地舆论认为，胡锦涛主席对加蓬的访问，将为两国关系长期稳定和健康发展奠定更加坚实的基础。'

title: Grant of EUR 1.9 million (duplicate of ID#427)
description: 'China's foreign minister continued his whistle-stop African tour on Tuesday in Equatorial Guinea, where he canceled debt, promised aid and opened a new Chinese-built media center.As part of China's increasing interest in the African continent, bilateral cooperation has intensified since small Equatorial Guinea became third largest producer of crude oil in sub-Saharan Africa. Last February, a Chinese company and the government of Equatorial Guinea signed an agreement on sharing oil production.Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing on Tuesday wrote off 56 million euros ($75 million) in debt owed by Equatorial Guinea, and promised a grant of 1.9 million euros.He also presided at the official opening of the new headquarters for Equatorial Guinea's state radio and television, built by a private Chinese company with interest-free credits provided by Beijing.Li had arrived in Malabo Monday on the second leg of a seven-nation tour of Africa that includes Benin, Guinea-Bissau, Chad, the Central African Republic, Eritrea and Botswana.China is keen to gain access to Africa's massive raw material reserves to feed the breakneck growth seen in its own economy. In doing so, it has been criticized for dealing with countries such as Sudan and Zimbabwe spurned by the West for human rights abuses.China's President Hu Jintao and Prime Minister Wen Jiabao each took separate trips to Africa in 2005, returning home with a slew of energy and other business deals.Such deals have punctuated a recent Chinese courtship of Africa that culminated last month in a China-Africa summit in Beijing drawing top leaders from more than 40 African countries to the Chinese capital. During the summit, Wen said China intended to more than dou'

title: Deal to build a mine and dam
description: African nations must stop signing away their natural resources in skewed deals with foreign firms, the African winner of the 2009 'Green Nobel' prize said in an interview.Ona, a wheelchair-bound Gabonese activist, has won the African 2009 Goldman Environmental Prize for a decade of activism to protect the Congo Basin Rainforest, the second largest rainforest in the world. [nLH706097]He exposed a secret $3.5 billion deal between the Gabonese government and a Chinese company to build a mine and dam in and around one of Gabon's national parks. The ensuing outcry forced the government to cut the project concession by 90 percent.'Africa can no longer sign contracts with economic partners to exploit their natural resources like they did in the 1930s,' Ona told Reuters in Gabon's capital Libreville.'Africa doesn't have to be subservient to do business. We have resources and economic partners have money -- it's 50:50. Those who don't want to do business by the terms that we fix should go elsewhere,' he said, before flying to the United States where he will receive his prize on Monday.Gabon is part of the Congo Basin and roughly 75 percent of country is covered in dense tropical rainforest.It is losing over 10,000 hectares of wooded land a year to logging, according to Mongabay, an environmental NGO. The World Wildlife Foundation estimated in 2002 that 70 percent of the forestry activities in Gabon were illegal.In 2002, Gabonese President Omar Bongo designated 10 percent of the country's land as national parks.But in 2006, the government handed a 7,700 square km concession in and around Iindo National Park to the Chinese company CMEC to develop the Belinga Mine. The project included construction of a railway, roads and a dam in the middle of central Africa's most beautiful waterfalls to power the mine.The agreement offered CMEC a 25-year tax break with Gabon receiving 10 percent of the project's profits.HOUSEHOLD NAMEOna, 45, leaked a copy of the agreement, and the strong public reaction drove the government to reduce the mining concession by 90 percent, scrap the tax break, and halt the project until an environmental impact assessment was done.Chinese investment in Africa has burgeoned in recent years, but many of the deals between Chinese companies and African governments are shrouded in secrecy.Ona was denied permission to leave Gabon three times last year and was held by the police in December, charged with possession of anti-government documents -- a charge he denies.Through his campaigning, he has become a household name in Gabon and is one of the most respected civil society leaders.'We appreciate his dedication and his work and especially the ideas that he defends in our country,' said Gaspard Obiang, a pastor in Libreville, speaking in a shopping centre.'Mr Ona can help engage young people to understand that nature is something unique that God has given us,' said Armel El Matcho, a security guard at the shopping centre.The Goldman Prize includes $150,000 in cash, which Ona says he will use to fund projects for forest communities run by his Libreville-based non-governmental organisation Brainforest.'I wasn't born to be rich. I couldn't care less about being rich,' he said. 'You can't imagine the reality of people living around Gabon's national parks. We need to put money into helping these communities regain their dignity.'Ona, wheelchair-bound because of childhood polio, has never shied away from political prosecution for his goals.'Mandela spent decades in jail, but he never stopped the fight to liberate the people of South Africa,' Ona said. 'I'm not Mandela, but I say if you haven't found a cause for which you are ready to die, you haven't found meaning in your life.'

title: Damietta container port joint venture
description: On November 26, 2007, China Shipping Group, parent of China Shipping Container Lines, signed an agreement to acquire 20 per cent of Damietta container port with an investment of 40 million USD. The port is located 8.5km to the west of the Damietta Nile River tributary. The first phase of the sixth planned berths of the container port, with an annual capacity of 2.5 million teu, was expected to be completed by the end of 2008. However, in March 2012 Egyptian Prime Minister Kamal el-Ganzouri created a commission to try to continue the construction of the container port. The current status and start and end dates of the project are unknown.

title: Expertise for food security programme (Duplicate)
description: 'AFPREnglish(Copyright 2000)ROME, Aug 22 (AFP) - China and Ghana signed Tuesday a tripartite agreement with the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) for Chinese agricultural experts and field technicians to assist Ghana, the UN agency said.The accord, signed within the framework of FAO's special programme for food security (SPFS), will put China's technical assistance services at the disposal of Ghana for three years, indicating that Chinese cooperation with developing African countries is being pursued.China also provides expertise for the special programme for food security in Ethiopia, Guinea, Mali and Mauritania.According to the agreement, China will provide Ghana with up to four experts, 47 field technicians and one interpreter over a phased period.China will 'provide the most appropriate technology, material and equipment to maximize technical cooperation in the various fields' such as water and improve living conditions for the poor and vulnerable in rural areas, the FAO said.In Ghana, SPFS activities are aimed at diversifying agricultural production and improving food security.The SPFS is designed to reduce incidences of malnutrition and, in Ghana, it specifically focuses on water control, increasing production and productivity of crops and agricultural diversification.Livestock and aquaculture development will be introduced.The agency launched the cooperation scheme at the beginning of 1997.The special programme for food security is operational in 60 countries -- 36 in Africa, 13 in Asia and the Middle East, seven in Latin America, two in Europe, and two in Oceania.fao/gk/swDocument afpr000020010803dw8m03e56'

title: Grant duplicate with 576
description: a grant of US$1.2m to the Gabonese government, and an interest-free loan of US$6m. The fact that the Chinese government is likely to be less critical of Gabon's failure to liberalise the political system than Western partners and international financial institutions is an added bonus.Outlook and Implications The ramifications of enhanced Chinese engagement in sub-Saharan Africa are likely to be mixed. Whilst the consistency of China's foreign policy should provide most states with a modicum of continuity in terms of external support, its effects will be uneven. Tariff-free access to Chinese markets will not be to the advantage of all parties: the mixed success of the US African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) has demonstrated that foreign legislation is not enough to stimulate genuine economic reform in African countries, and that - when tied to foreign policy - it can have a deleterious effect on the standards of sovereignty and governance in African regimes (see Africa Regional: 26 February 2003: US Lobbies Hard to Win African Votes on Iraq). For Bongo's government, closer Chinese engagement is nothing but good news. China is already involved in a number of developmental projects, centring around infrastructural developments, new technologies and healthcare. Hu's visit and new commercial deals should further strengthen Bongo's position. However, whilst stability is a thing to be welcomed in an otherwise torrid sub-region, Bongo's manipulation of incumbency and authoritarian control of political resources does not bode well for Gabon's political future. If China's only intention in Central Africa is to prop up particular regimes for long enough to withdraw their oil supplies, Chinese 'engagement' is something to be profoundly wary of. //法新社利伯维尔消息 中国国家主席胡锦涛及加蓬总统邦戈2月2日签署三项双边贸易协定，其中一项的内容是双方合作勘探开采加蓬的石油资源。 　　胡锦涛在加蓬的第二天访问行程中，与邦戈进行了45分钟的闭门会谈。两人在会谈后签署了三项协定。 　　中国外交部发言人孔泉说，第一项协定总值120万美元，内容是两国的经济及技术合作。根据协定，加蓬可得到北京的“无偿援助”。中国将提供加蓬“一笔用来落实多宗计划项目的援助金。项目性质尚未定案。” 　　第二项协定是中国向加蓬提供600万美元免息贷款，以推动已开始进行的双方合作项目。 　　第三项协定由国营中国石油化工股份有限公司（中国石化）与加蓬能源部签署，是“一项协议备忘录，旨在证明双方有意发展石油产品的勘探、开采、提炼及出口等方面活动。” 　　中国经济发展近年一日千里，带动全球石油需求去年急速增长三分之一。 　　中国为应付国内与日俱增的石油需求，石油进口量急升30％，当中一半来自中东，其余来自全球其它地区，包括非洲、东南亚、俄罗斯、哈萨克及南美等。 　　一位接近随胡锦涛出访的中国访问团的消息人士说，该项石油合作协定也包括人员培训及两国技术共享等方面。 　　加蓬总统府发表的声明说，邦戈在2月2日的会谈指加蓬“坚定支持中国统一，中华人民共和国是唯一的合法代表”。 　　胡锦涛邀请邦戈今年访问中国。 　　中国外交界消息人士在胡锦涛自埃及抵达加蓬前说，胡锦涛将在2月2日下午在加蓬国会向整个非洲大陆发表演说。他会在演说中公布北京的非洲新政策。 　　胡锦涛将于2月3日到石油资源同样丰富的阿尔及利亚访问，该国是他今次非洲访问行程的最后一站。 　　另据报道称，法国石油公司－－加蓬道达尔公司及中国石化附属机构中国国际石油化工公司（联合石化）签署一项合约，让加蓬石油首次出口中国。 　　加蓬道达尔公司总裁德格罗特说，根据协议，将每年出口大量石油到中国，但他没透露具体数量。

title: Egypt-China drilling company (Duplicate)
description: *check if related to 563'HFTMVolume 3, Number 56English(c) 2008 Hart Energy Publishing, LP. All Rights Reserved. Speaking at the “Prospects of Sino-Egyptian Corporation on Oil,” Abd El Aleem Taha, chairman of the Egyptian General Petroleum Corp, said that Egypt will seek to continue to develop energy projects with China. “The cooperation between Egypt and China is very important,” he said. He placed special emphasis on the importance the relationship held for Egypt’s job market, as well as technology exchanges. Taha expects the countries to work together on exploring and refinery projects, as well as oil rig manufacturing. Egypt’s first oil rig, Mubarak-1, was built earlier this year by an Egyptian-Chinese factor. In July 2005, the Tharwa Petroleum of Egypt and China’s Sinopec created Sinotharwa Drilling Company, an $18 million joint venture providing oil and gas drilling in Egypt and other parts of Africa and the Middle East. Additionally, the two countries have cooperated on Egyptian Petroleum HH Rig Manufacturing Shareholder Company. Earlier last week, Reuters reported that Zhiming Zhao, executive president of Sinopec, said China intends to increase its oil and gas imports from Africa by 10% in the next five to 10 years. Egypt, Equitorial Guinea, the Sudan, and Nigeria were specifically mentioned by Zhao as countries China wanted to continue to work with in importing oil. Currently, China imports roughly 30% of its total oil imports from Africa and has invested approximately $30 billion in the continent’s oil and gas infrastructure. – Frank Nieto Document HFTM000020080417e43o0002w '中萨石油钻井公司举行开工庆典2005-12-27 19:45  文章来源：驻埃及使馆经商处文章类型：原创  内容分类：其它   　　12月26日，中萨石油钻井公司在开罗举行开工庆典仪式。 　　该公司是中国石化新星石油公司（SINOPEC STAR PETROLEUM COMPANY）与埃及石油部下属萨瓦石油公司（THARWA PETROLEUM COMPANY）合资组建的钻井公司，合资公司注册资本1800万美元，双方各投入900万美元，各占50%股份。 　　合资公司的业务范围目前以油气钻井为主，将从钻井向修井、测井、固井、录井等其他领域扩展辐射。公司注册后，由合资公司购买中方公司的两台陆上钻机，并聘请中方技术人员从事钻井作业。 　　目前第一台钻机已经开钻，第二台钻机也即将开钻。 　　埃石油部副部长、中国驻埃及大使吴思科、经商处崔明谟公参等出席了开工庆典仪式。  '

title: Construction of China-Africa Friendship (Duplicate of 829)
description: LILONGWE, Apr. 20, 2011 (IPS/GIN) - Driving through MalawiÆs capital, Lilongwe, it is difficult to miss the imposing building under construction in the city centre. It's the countryÆs first five-star hotel, 90 million dollars worth of well-appointed rooms, a state-of-the-art conference centre and 14 opulent presidential suites.The hotel is being built by the Shanghai Construction Company, a Chinese firm, and is one of numerous projects funded in line with a pledge of 260 million dollars of concessionary loans, grant and aid from China to Malawi to support development, including infrastructure.At a ceremony marking the completion of the main building and conference centre, China's ambassador to Malawi, Pan Hejun, said he expects the whole project will be completed by the end of the year.'This will attract more and more foreign tourists to Malawi and enable Malawi to host international conferences such as the AU Summit,' said Hejun.Chinese construction companies have been busy in Malawi. Parliament now operates from a grand new building which was opened in June 2010. That project cost around 41 million dollars.And this month Ambassador Hejun announced China will assist the Malawi government to construct a university of science and technology in the southern district of Thyolo, which, he said, will be ready in just under two years.'The university, which will accommodate more than 3,000 students with advanced facilities, will be one of the best universities in southeastern Africa, and will make great contributions to the national development of Malawi,' said Hejun.Relations growing steadilyChinese construction companies are also building a secondary school in Thyolo, and a 100-kilometre road between the northern districts of Karonga and Chitipa. The Asian nation has also promised to build a China-Africa Friendship School in Lilongwe, establish solar and biogas pilot projects and set up an agricultural technology demonstration centre.ChinaÆs presence in Malawi has been growing steadily since the two countries established diplomatic ties in December 2007, Malawi abandoning its links to Taiwan after 41 years. A memorandum of understanding covering industry, trade and investment was signed between the two countries in May 2008, committing China to help in increasing the productive capacity of Malawi in tobacco, cotton, mining, forestry, fertiliser production and in processing hides and skins.A 2010 report from MalawiÆs Ministry of Trade indicates that the value of trade between Malawi and China has doubled since 2007, reaching 100 million dollars in 2010, rapid growth, though still dwarfed by trade with South Africa, which accounts for just over 40 percent of Malawi's total trade volume of 3.2 billion dollars.MalawiÆs president, Bingu wa Mutharika, has declared himself satisfied with his government's relations with China. In an April speech at the laying of foundations for the planned university of science and technology, Mutharika said the Chinese projects come with 'no strings attached'.'The PeopleÆs Republic of China has demonstrated that they are good friends of Malawi,' said Mutharika.Some problemsThis year alone, Chinese nationals working in Malawi in construction or as traders have featured in a number of unwelcome headlines. In January, police at the international airport caught Zhang Xiang Quian trying to smuggle 3.5 kilogrammes of ivory bangles, curios and necklaces out of the country. The same day, Jennifer Li was arrested when she attempted to bribe police to release Zhang. The two - who both held senior positions with the Shanghai Construction Company - were fined and deported.In February, the owner of the China Superscope Media Company, Ning Naixing, was apprehended at the airport with 1.5 kilogrammes of ivory. Police assert the ivory in both cases originates from elephants poached in Malawi. The Ministry of Tourism issued a statement on Feb. 11 warning against trafficking of ivory.Chinese traders - who have established a firm foothold in the wholesale and retail sectors in Malawi - have also run afoul of the law. Businesswoman Yani Huang was arrested and fined for violating foreign exchange controls in November 2010, when she tried to leave the country with an undeclared $18,350. A few months earlier, another Chinese national was arrested trying to take $144,000 out of the country.Malawi is experiencing acute shortages of foreign exchange, leading to strict controls on the export of hard currency. This complicates life for Chinese traders who want to repatriate profits made in Malawi.Local traders are also anxious over competition from the new arrivals. 'Some are setting up small-scale businesses and competing with indigenous traders. They are making life difficult for us,' Maddy Gawani, a trader who runs a clothes shop in Lilongwe, told IPS. She said there are big Chinese-owned wholesale shops in LilongweÆs Old Town, a cheap area of the capital city.'Many items in the Chinese shops are cheap but not very durable. A lot of people now shop from the Chinese who bring in many things in bulk. We are not happy as local traders,' said Gawani.Relations between the new traders and their clients are sometimes tense as well. Last year, trader Chen Bo Wet was arrested in the lake district of Mangochi after he allegedly forced a woman he suspected of stealing from his shop to undress in the presence of other customers. Nothing was found on the woman, and he was arrested following complaints.Worst fears unrealisedWhen the memorandum of understanding on trade and investment was signed, local groups feared it would have a negative impact on the country.At the time, Mavuto Bamusi, the network coordinator of the Human Rights Consultative Committee (HRCC), which promotes human rights, including economic rights, in Malawi, said the evidence was that Chinese investment had harmed the interest of poor nationals in some countries.'We know that the Chinese usually bring in their own workers when they invest in poor countries and that they have been accused of dumping cheap goods on such countriesÆ markets. Civil society will be quick to raise an alarm if such malpractices happen here,' Bamusi told IPS.But the Malawi Congress of Trade Unions has been keeping a close eye on the situation. MCTU Secretary General Robert Mkwezalamba told IPS that when they first arrived in the country, Chinese construction companies either paid their Malawian workers below the minimum wage or paid them in kind - in the form of clothing, bicycles, maize flour and sugar. In some cases, workers were not provided with protective gear.'They were paying the Malawi workers just about $13 per month when the countryÆs acceptable minimum wage is $20. Some Chinese factories were locking up the workers [in their workplace] overnight,' said Mkwezalamba.But, he said, companies have responded to the MCTU's objections.'We have been asking them to change and they are accepting our demands,' he told IPS. 'We are also happy that the construction companies are transferring advanced skills to local staff.' Document IPRS000020110420e74k0002t

title: Algerian Mosque
description: On May 22, 2012 the China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) started construction of a mosque expected to be the third largest in the world. The project is projected to cost 1 billion Euros and will sit on land covering 20 hectares. It will fit 120,000 people and contain a library, museum, and research center. It should take approximately three years to finish.

title: CITIC Dameng Chinese-Gabonese mining enterprise (duplicate of Project ID 686)
description: LIBREVILLE, Oct 23 (Reuters) - Gabon and Chinese mining enterprise CITIC Dameng, a unit of CITIC Resources Holdings , should mine over 26 million tonnes of manganese from their M'Bembele mine over the next 25 years, the two sides said.The operation, whose start-up date has not yet been confirmed but was inked this week in Gabon, comes ahead of a planned separate listing for CITIC Dameng on the main board in Hong Kong. [ID:nnTOE69A066]Gabon, the number No. 2 producer of manganese, is seeking to boost its output of the metal, used in steel and aluminium alloys, as part of a drive to diversify its economy away from dependence on oil and French firms.Zhang Longzhu, vice president of CICMHZ, the local company created to run the M'Bembele operation in Gabon's Moyen-Ogooue province, said that reserves were estimated at 'over 26 million tonnes'.Julien Nkoghe Bekale, Gabon's minister of mines, said 40 billion CFA ($84.71 million) would be invested in the project and production would start at around 800,000 tonnes per year and peak at just over 1 million tonnes for about 25 years.Neither official gave a start-up date for the operation.Gabon's manganese output slumped to around 2.2 million tonnes in 2009 due to falling demand after hitting 3.1 million tonneS.Mining accounts for a small percentage of Gabon's economy, but President Ali Bongo is seeking to boost the sector as his country's oil reserves start winding down.Bongo is also actively seeking investment from firms outside France, the former colonial power that has long-enjoyed a strong influence in the Central African nation.Gabon is due to buy a greater stake in Comilog, another manganese operation Gabon has with Eramet , Eramet said earlier this month.//10月21日，在加蓬总理比约盖.姆巴的主持下，华州矿业工贸有限公司总经理农德连与加蓬矿业部长贝加雷、经贸部长恩冈比亚在总理府共同签署了蒙贝利锰矿开采矿权协议。　　中国驻加蓬大使李福顺、经商参赞胡平、中信大锰矿业公司副总经理张龙珠等出席了隆重的签字仪式。加蓬广播电视一台和媒体报道了签字仪式，并采访了投资公司负责人。　　该矿位于中西部恩乔莱附近，锰矿储量三千多万吨，由宁波矿业投资公司获得勘探权和采矿许可权。2007年11月，宁波矿业与中信大锰矿业公司签署合作开发协议，由后者控股开发经营。目前该矿仍在进行矿山、运输等后期建设，预计年底开始出矿。//据消息透露，日前在加蓬总理比约盖.姆巴的主持下，华州矿业工贸有限公司总经理农德连与加蓬矿业部长贝加雷、经贸部长恩冈比亚在总理府共同签署了蒙贝利锰矿开采矿权协议。　　加蓬矿业部长贝加雷称，中国中信大锰矿业旗下一分公司华州矿业日前表示愿意投资6100万欧元开发位于首都东南部200公里的蒙贝利锰矿。公司计划前两年每年从该矿开采800000-900000吨锰矿，接着在以后的30年内每年开采量增长到1040000吨。　　贝加雷在与华州签订收购协议时表示，该矿需雇佣255位本地居民，另外85名可来自中国，开采出的部分锰矿需在本地加工生产。同时他还透露，华州自接受该锰矿后，大约可从中获利7300万欧元，每年的收益可达900-1200万欧元。目前该矿仍在进行矿山、运输等后期建设，预计年底开始出矿。　　目前该矿仍在进行矿山、运输等后期建设，预计年底开始出矿。　　锰矿与石油及木材是加蓬最重要的资源。法国集团Eramet已经对该国其中一矿山进行了垄断，目前为全球第二大锰生产商。近年来非洲也不断迎来中国商人的投资热潮。中国政府在一篇报告中指出，2009年年底中国向非洲累计投资了93亿美元，预计此势头还将有所增长。

title: Grant NEEDS CONFIRMATIOIN (duplicate of 858)
description: Not on the list of countries that Minister Li visited in his tour, the Chinese Foreign Ministry pledged at the start of the New Year to disburse at least 5 million euro to Côte d’Ioire to honour the promises made at the Beijing Summit two months ago. 75% of this total is to be given as a gift to the West African country, while the remainder is on loan. This is not the first time that Côte d’Ioire has been the beneficiary of Chinese grand gestures— in 2002, China showered the country with an excess of 33 million euro at the time of the rebel insurgency. Already, China has been the source of capital for the construction of an impressive parliamentary complex and a presidential palace. Indeed, China’s interest in Côte d’Ioire is plain: it is keen to benefit from the unexploited Iorian oil resources and to gain a foothold in the potentially lucrative cocoa industry: Côte d’Ioire is the world’s number one exporter of cocoa.

title: Upgrade of road (Not a project)
description: Addis Ababa, Jul 28, 2006 (The Ethiopian Herald/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Ethiopian Roads Authority (ERA) yesterday signed road construction and upgrading agreements with Keangnam Enterprise Ethiopia and China Road and Bridges Corporation (CRBC) enabling to upgrade 293 kms of gravel road. The 867 million birr project agreement was signed by ERA Deputy Director General Samson Fiseha, and representatives of the two companies. According to the agreements, Keangnam Enterprise would undertake the construction of the 185 kms Azezo-Metema road, which links Ethiopia with the Sudan, in two phases as of September 2006, and would be completed in the next three years. Keangnam would be paid a total of 496 million birr upon completion of the asphalting of the 87 kms Azezo-Gente as well as the 98 kms Gente-Metema road. Speaking on the occasion, Samson said the road which is part of the Trans-African highway system is important for promoting trade and investment ties between Ethiopia and the Sudan. Similarly, an agreement has been signed between ERA and CRBC for the upgrading of Geshen-Woldiya gravel road. The Authority said foreign and domestic companies would undertake the consultancy and supervision of the road projects. The construction costs of the roads would be covered by the Ethiopian government and international creditors, it was learnt.

title: Economic, technical, political support (too vague-not a project)
description: LIV ZHONGXIN (China) said successful election processes in both Burundi and Guinea-Bissau showed the two countries were on their way back to stability and democracy. However, many challenges stood before each country, and the international community must help them with concrete actions, such as technical assistance. Her country had been involved with the development process in both countries, including by providing economic, technical and political support. It would continue to engage with both countries.

title: PPIAF - A power plant invested by Shenzhen Energy and China-Africa Fund (Phase I)
description: (PPIAF) A joint venture of Shenzhen Energy, based in Shenzhen City, Guangdong Province of China and China-Africa Development Fund invested a 200MW power plant in Ghana. Phase I of the project was completed in April 2009.; PPIAF-ID:136

title: Concessionary loans (Not a single project, duplicate of many)
description: LILONGWE, April 1 (Xinhua) -- Malawian President Bingu Wa Mutharika Tuesday expressed his sincere gratitude'The financial support from China will be granted in the form of concessionary loans over a five-year period,' Mutharika told a press conference in the Malawian capital.Mutharika, who paid his first visit to Beijing in late March, said China has pledged to offer financial aid in the next five years to several large projects in Malawi, including the construction of a 100-km road connecting Malawi's two northern districts of Chitipa and Karonga, and the parliament building in the capital.Mutharika said Malawi now enjoys the preferential trade regime offered by China under the framework of the Africa-China Forum, which will boost significantly Malawi's exports to China. The Malawian leader also defended his government's decision to establish diplomatic relations with China in late December, saying that the decision was among other factors based on the one China principle that have been adopted by the international community.

title: Economic and Technical Cooperation (same as project ID#742)
description: Panapress reports that China and Guinea-Bissau have signed a technical and economic co-operation accord under which Guinea-Bissau will receive US$3 million. The agreement, signed during visit to Guinea-Bissau by the Chinese foreign minister, Li Zhaoxing, marks the growing relationship between China and the West African country. It also provides preferential price status to 442 products from Guinea-Bissau. According to Panapress, China is expected to help build new government buildings, including a judicial palace, military hospital, and government ministries headquarters, and a dam on the Geba river.Significance: Guinea-Bissau's strengthening of ties with China will help inject much-needed investment capital into the economy and help prop up the government's weak revenue collections and fiscal deficit—Guinea-Bissau experienced subdued growth through 2006.The granting of preferential prices to 442 products will also help fuel demand for exports, which could help boost the Guinea-Bissau's ailing secondary sector. Strengthened ties with China, which has shown strong independence in its foreign aid policy, is very good news for the African country, which holds status as one of the poorest countries in the world and is currently experiencing ripples in its relationship with the World Bank.

title: Economic and Technological cooperation (Inactive: not a project-too vague)
description: In September 2008, China signed agreements on economic and technological cooperation with three countries, including Guinea-Bissau, during the Beijing Paralympics. No other information on the agreement was reported. It was likely just an act of diplomacy.

title: Preferential export pricing for 442 Guinea-Bissau products
description: In January of 2007, China granted Guinea-Bissau a donation of US$4 million and announced that is opening up its market to 442 products from Guinea Bissau that will have preferential tariffs. The protocol that made China’s support official was signed by the Chinese foreign minister, Li Xhaoxing in a 24-hour visit to Guinea Bissau.Linked to project #742. STAFF_NOTES: Preferential tariffs do not count as a project, and therefore this record has been deactivated.

title: $3 million euro investment in mobile phone network (Inactive: same as 788)
description: China is investing 36 million euros (48.5 million dollars) in modernising Guinea Bissau's obsolete fixed telephone network and another three million euros in the mobile phone network, a government minister said Thursday.'It only remains to launch the operation in 90 days,' Transport and Communication Minister Vicente Blute told AFP. The work will be carried out by the Huawei group.'China has come to replace Portugal and it is all working wonderfully,' said Blute, adding that the terms of reference allowing it to start its activities were ready.The telephone networks have up till now been jointly managed by Portugal Telecom (51 percent) and the government of Guinea Bissau (49 percent) but have been at the centre of a dispute between the two parties for some months, the minister said.Guinea Bissau wanted its agreement with Portugal amended to give it a more favourable deal. Portugal Telecom, having failed to get the government to change its mind, has pulled out.Huawei has also undertaken to improve the Internet network with top of the range broadband equipment, the minister said.As part of the agreement China is also to train and supervise local technical staff by offering scholarships.Three companies -- Orange, Areeba and Guinetel -- serve the country's 60,000 mobile phone subscribers.

title: Debt deratement (duplicate 19706)
description: On November 12, 2001 China and Madagascar signed an agreement termed the China Derate Debts of Madagascar. According to the agreement, China would derate Madagascar's debts of 30 million USD. The debt derating stems from the Sino-Africa Cooperation Forum. Due to the Sino-Africa Cooperation Forum, China agreed to derate about 10 billion yuan of the debt for heavily indebted and less developed countries in Africa. wThis Sino-Madagascar Agreement on Derate Debts fulfills that promiseProject linked with (signed at the same time as) #893 economic assistance grant and #10739 gymnasium technical assistance.

title: Not really a project- general story about African/Chinese cultural and economic exchange
description: 'Jacob Lukaka is optimistic about the future. When he graduates from the University of Nairobi later this year, the 23-year-old Kenyan student will start work for a travel company. Ordinarily, quite a few of his fellow countrymen would have been qualified to do this job; however, in this case, Lukaka is one of only a handful who have the requisite abilities. The tour operator in question caters for Chinese tourists, and he is one of the few Mandarin-speaking Kenyans.Lukaka knows what a great opportunity he has now. 'China is growing very quickly,' he says. 'It's now a driving force in the world, both economically and politically.' And he's keen to use this to his advantage. 'I hope I have the chance to get a masters degree in China, majoring in international relations.'Lukaka is one of the first 18 graduates of the university's Confucius Institute for Chinese Studies, which was set up late last year by the governments of China and Kenya to promote cultural exchange between the two countries. With similar departments opening in Zimbabwe and South Africa, the institute is the manifestation of the growing spirit of cooperation between China and Africa.Indeed, since Beijing hailed a new era of South-South cooperation in 2000, the Chinese have been making their presence felt in Africa. Trade has grown by 400 per cent in four years. In boardrooms all over the continent, Chinese executives are striking billion-pound deals for precious raw materials, while in markets and trade centres, Chinese businessmen are selling everything from clothes, shoes and handbags to mattresses, wardrobes and three-piece suites.At the same time, construction firms are changing the face of the continent, building everything from roads, bridges and railways to shopping malls, casinos and golf courses. And in schools and hospitals, Chinese professionals are working alongside their African counterparts in an effort to share knowledge and experience.While African leaders have been rolling out the red carpet for their new friends from the East, the media has reported warnings that the flood of cheap Chinese imports is destroying local industries and that Beijing's courting of rogue regimes is perpetuating corruption and human rights abuses. However, there is another side to the story, the impact of which looks set to affect us all.The fact is that China's economic expansion into Africa is triggering fundamental changes in the patterns of global trade, turning on its head accepted wisdom concerning international development and realigning political allegiances. And few people seem to have noticed. The implications can't be underestimated--not only upon trade, aid and diplomacy among developing nations, but on the economics, politics and security of the world as a whole.'

title: Kenya Rural  Telecommunications Development Project (Duplicate)
description: On January 23, 2006, Kenyan Finance minister David Mwiraria and Vice-President of China Exim Bank Zhao Wenzhang signed a concessional loan agreement  with the Chinese Export-Import bank for Ksh1.8 billion ($24.5 million). The 2% interest rate loan will fund the the Kenya Rural Telecommunications Development Project. The project seeks to provide each of the country's district headquarters with a minimum of 2,000 lines. Kenya's Information and Communications minister, Mutahi Kagwe also attended the signing ceremony. In 2005, reports show that Kenya signed a contract with Huawei Technologies to implement the project. The project also involved use of equipment from Chinese companies.Although it appears that preliminary reports had been conducted before signing the agreement contract with the Exim Bank and Huawei Technologies, whether the project has begun implementation and the amount of the project that has been completed are unknown.---1月23日，中国进出口银行副行长赵文章与肯尼亚财政部长戴维·姆维拉里亚在内罗毕签署了肯尼亚输变电网改造项目和农村电信网改造项目的优惠贷款协议，协议金额共4亿元人民币，主要用于肯尼亚电力和电信等基础设施建设。该项目标志着中肯两国间的经贸合作关系又上了一个新的台阶。

title: Pesticide manufacturing and distribution plants (Not a Project)
description: >'Chinese Vice-Minister for Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Mr Sun Zhenyu said yesterday his government had allocated special funds to support investment in Africa.>> >>A delegation of top businessmen from China is currently in the country to assess investment opportunities in several sectors.>> >>They are seeking to invest in civil engineering, pharmaceuticals, general advertisements, chemicals, energy and financial sectors.>> >>Mr Zhenyu said the Sichuan Chang'hong electronics group was preparing to set up a coloured TV assembly line in Kenya.>> >>He added that two other Chinese companies have joined hands to establish the Hua'yang International (Kenya) Ltd, which will specialise in pesticide manufacture and distribution.>> >>Speaking at a business forum between Chinese and Kenyan businessmen in Nairobi, the minister for trade and industry, Mr Nicholas Biwott, said the trade balance was tilted in China's favour.>> >>Kenya exported goods worth 4m dollars last year to China, while it imported 98m dollars worth of goods from China, the minister said in a speech read by assistant minister Albert Ekirapa.>> >>Kenya's exports to china are mainly primary and semi-processed goods, including tea, textile fibre, crude vegetable materials, tobacco, leather and leather products.>> >>Imports from China include hand machine tools, manufactured base metal, fabrics and textiles, lighting features and fittings, household equipment.>> >>At the same time, Mr Biwott said Kenya and China will sign three agreements to further enhance cooperation.>> >>Speaking at a luncheon hosted for the Chinese delegation, Mr Biwott said this was a follow up to a protocol signed recently covering trade, technical and cultural cooperation.>> >>He called on Chinese business people to invest in micro credit lending in partnership with local institutions.>> >>He also said the businessmen would take advantage of Kenya's location to penetrate various markets.>> >>'Chinese industrialists should move their manufacturing plants and use Kenya as a springboard to other markets in Africa and the rest of the world,' he said.>> >>He appealed to the 44 Chinese investors who have already invested in Kenya to increase investments in manufacturing…' >

recipient_agencies: Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd., Private Sector
